PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Plant Variety Rights
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government-

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that Legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs Regulations: Importation of Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Parliament of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, undersigned , shows that we strongly oppose the amending of Customs Regulations to allow the importation of video tape, video disc, slide or any other recording from a visual image which can be produced, which portrays scenes of explicit sexual relations showing genitalia detail; acts of violence and sex; sexual perversion such as sodomy; mutilation; child pornography; coprophilia; bestiality, or the use and effect of illicit drug taking, and our opposition is emphatically given because such material
Will be viewed by 20 per cent of all Australian children during their parents' absence, or at other homes.
Will introduce children during their formative years to sexuality in the context of violence and deviance.
Will become a powerful teaching medium which will establish violence as a behavioural norm for coming generations.
Will degrade women to an exploitable sexual commodity.
Will change the attitudes of men to their partners and all women.
Will give rise to a substantial increase in serious crime, crimes against the person, sexual offences, rape and incest.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that-
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia , namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation 's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

I present Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1983-84 in which appropriations totalling $121.9m-additional to those made by Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1983-84-are sought for capital works and services, payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory and for other services. The proposed appropriations are needed to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures for which provision was not made in that Act.

Almost half of the additional appropriations sought is for natural disaster relief and restoration; the remainder mostly reflects cost and price increases which have occurred since the time of the Budget and requirements which the Government has considered appropriate to meet this financial year.

Provision has been made under the Department of Finance for natural disaster relief and restoration amounting to $46.8m. This provision is based on the latest advice from the States and the Northern Territory of their requirements under the natural disaster relief arrangements. The main factors in the increase are:
underestimation by the relevant States of the continuing financial implications of the recent droughts in New South Wales and Queensland;
underestimation of the consequences of the April-May 1983 floods in Queensland; and

the impact of new disasters not provided for in the original 1983-84 appropriation, including floods in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland and developing drought conditions in Western Australia.

An amount of $15m is sought for payments in lieu of benefits for prescribed diagnostic services in respect of private patients in recognised hospitals. This reflects the difficulties the Government has experienced with medical practitioners over agreements relating to private practice rights of medical practitioners in recognised hospitals. This amount will cover circumstances where the Health Insurance Act 1973, as it would be amended by the Bill recently introduced by the Minister for Health, would not fully authorise Medicare benefit payments for diagnostic services provided to private patients in recognised hospitals from 1 March 1984. This expenditure will be offset by lower than estimated payments against the standing appropriation for Medicare benefits . I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This omnibus Bill seeks to implement a number of admendments of an administrative nature to the Fishing Industry Research Act 1969, and the Fisheries Act 1952 and Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968 pending completion of a comprehensive review of Commonwealth fisheries legislation. The amendments are designed to streamline and improve the administration of fisheries management arrangements for the benefit of both the industry and the Government.

The Bill will amend the Fisheries Act 1952 to simplify licensing requirements, overcome a number of administrative difficulties and include review provisions in relation to licensing functions and fisheries notices made under section 8 of the Act. In particular, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the removal of the requirement for crew members of fishing boats to be individually licensed. In future only master fishermen will be required to hold a licence.

There has been strong and continuing criticism from the fishing industry because the Commonwealth is maintaining a licensing system that is no longer necessary for effective fisheries management. The Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce in its report on the Australian fishing industry tabled last year also expressed similar concern and recommended removal of unnecessary licensing provisions. The amendments, which have the support of the fishing industry, will simplify existing arrangements by reducing the number of licences required, and associated administrative costs.

Another important provision of the Bill will enable the entry of unlicensed foreign fishing boats to Australian ports for major repair and similar purposes. The entry of unlicensed foreign fishing boats for these purposes, which has the potential to provide significant economic benefits for Australian industries, has been limited by restrictive port entry criteria in the Fisheries Act. Clauses 23 and 24 of the Bill will remove this difficulty by providing for the authorisation of entry into Australian ports for specified purposes. It is not intended that such authorisations be used for the purpose of allowing unlicensed foreign fishing boats to enter ports on an ad hoc basis for routine refuelling, or minor repairs.

Clause 9 of the Bill will provide a procedure for formally controlling the activities of research boats in the Australian fishing zone by allowing the granting of permits for scientific purposes. Clauses 5 and 7 of the Bill will permit the application of the Fisheries Act to Australian fishermen operating beyond the outer limits of the Australian fishing zone, should this be required under future international fisheries management arrangements. It is likely that if international agreement is reached on the management of highly migratory species of fish such as tuna, each country concerned will be required to control its own fishermen on the high seas.

The Bill will remove all references to ''traditional fishing'' from the Fisheries Act. Traditional fishing as defined in the Fisheries Act relates to fishing by indigenous inhabitants of Australia's external Territories, with particular application to Papua New Guinea. With the granting of independence to that country several years ago, that term is no longer necessary for fisheries management under the Act.

The Bill also effects a number of other amendments to the Fisheries Act to streamline administrative procedures. These include additional powers relating to the cancellation of licence endorsements, changes in licence conditions, and the endorsement of licences to exempt the licensee from a prohibition imposed by a specified fisheries notice. The Fisheries Act currently only permits licences to be endorsed in respect of one type of fisheries notice. These amendments will permit greater flexibility in implementing fisheries management arrangements.

The Bill also adds new provisions to the Fisheries Act to allow Parliamentary scrutiny of fisheries notices and administrative review in relation to certain licensing powers. In particular, I draw the attention of honourable senators to clause 11 of the Bill which provides that fisheries notices made under section 8 of the Act must be tabled in Parliament and may be disallowed by either House. This amendment was also recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce in its report on the Australian Fishing Industry.

The amendments in clauses 19 and 27 of the Bill provide for administrative review of decisions relating to licensing functions, other than decisions in respect of foreign boats or persons who are not citizens or residents of Australia.

These provisions reflect the Government's commitment to the principle that discretionary powers exercised under Commonwealth legislation should be reviewable. However, in this Bill special provision has been made to recognise the position of State officials acting under Commonwealth law. The States have been consulted on the implications of the proposed provisions and have not voiced any objections.

Decisions on licensing matters made personally by the Minister or the Secretary will be directly reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Decisions on licensing matters by delegates of the Minister or delegates of the Secretary, including State officials acting on behalf of the Commonwealth, although not reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, will be subject to reconsideration by the Minister or Secretary or a Commonwealth official delegated to review decisions. Any decision made following such reconsideration may then be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Decisions of a Fisheries Joint Authority itself will not be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Government considers that, as a policy making body comprising Commonwealth and State Ministers, it is not appropriate to subject a Joint Authority to Commonwealth administrative review. However, decisions of delegates of a Joint Authority may be subject to reconsideration by the Joint Authority itself or a delegated Commonwealth official. Any decision made by that official would then be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I would point out that while this Bill amends some provisions relating to the functions of Fisheries Joint Authorities as a consequence of other amendments to the Act and the inclusion of review provisions, implementation of the system of Joint Authority management of fisheries will depend on the outcome of the review of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement now being undertaken by the Government .

The Bill will also amend the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968 to extend the Act to apply to the seabed beneath the territorial sea of the Coral Sea Islands Territory. This amendment is necessary in the light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department that the Act does not apply to this area of seabed. The amendment, which will complement regulations under the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1975 in its application to the proclaimed nature reserve in the Coral Sea Islands Territory, will ensure that the Commonwealth has adequate jurisdiction over the seabed area to prevent the illegal taking of giant clams and other sedentary organisms.

Finally, the Bill will amend the Fishing Industry Act 1969 to authorise approval of a Northern Territory fund for the purposes of determining Commonwealth fishing research funding levels under the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account arrangements. Under the Act, the Commonwealth matches the amounts paid into recognised State funds on a $1 for $1 basis. The Commonwealth's contribution is appropriated for credit to the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account. The Northern Territory is not a ''State'' for the purposes of the Act and although, in 1979, it established a fund similar to that recognised in each State, that fund cannot be approved without an appropriate amendment to the Act.

In 1982, the Australian Fisheries Council noted the urgent need to amend the Act to include the Northern Territory fund with those of other States to give proper recognition to the Territory's contribution to fishing research. The proposed amendment will allow approval of the Northern Territory fund as one qualifying for matching Commonwealth fishing research funding.

Mr President, the foregoing amendments provide long awaited reforms to the fisheries legislation which will assist the Government to more efficiently discharge its management responsibilities for the valuable fisheries resources off our shores. The amendments come at a time when the Government is in the process of introducing new and improved management arrangements for a number of important fisheries to provide for the long-term stability of the fishing industry and at the same time protect the biological needs of those fisheries. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

The speech read as follows-
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1984 which is now before the Senate proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982.

The Bill contains 9 schedules and is necessary to enact tariff changes which have been introduced into the Parliament in the 1983 Budget sittings and the 1984 autumn sittings by Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 15-19 (1983) and Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 1-4 (1984).
Certain of the amendments contained in the Bill arise from the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on:
Copper and certain copper products (including removal of export control)
Fatty acids and certain aliphatic acids, their salts and esters; glycerol; tall oil
Lawnmowers, certain engines and parts
and the Temporary Assistance Authority's report on certain air conditioning machines.
The Bill also contains amendments relating to:
The implementation of arrangements resulting from the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand;

continuation of the textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy, including decisions taken by the Government in respect of the May 1983 report of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee;
concessions granted under certain trade agreements with nations of the South Pacific region and with Canada;
the insertion of provisions to allow imports of certain steel products from developing countries to be admitted under quota at concessional rates of duty; and finally,
amendments to correctly reflect the intention, scope or wording of certain provisions contained in the principal Act.

The changes in respect of TAA and IAC reports contained in this Bill are directed to the level of assistance accorded to certain industries. Some of these changes have the secondary effect of increasing or decreasing revenues. Decisions affecting levels of assistance are of course expected to have an effect on levels of imports and, therefore, the level of customs duty collected. The precise impact of these changes may also not become clear, in financial impact terms, until several months after the decisions of the Government are implemented. For these reasons, the financial impact of this Bill may only be broadly estimated at $6.96m in customs revenue foregone per year. It should be noted that bounty assistance is being provided as a result of the Government's decisions on the Temporary Assistance Authority's report on certain air- conditioning machines and the Industries Assistance Commission's report on lawnmowers, certain engines and parts. The financial impact of such bounty assistance is not included in the figure quoted above.

Administrative amendments contained in the Bill are expected to have little financial impact. In addition, there are no significant administrative costs associated with the measures contained in this Bill. A summary of amendments for each schedule contained in the Bill has been prepared for the information of honourable senators. Copies are available from the Records and Tables Office. I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, normally speaking this would be a simple procedural matter consequent upon the agreement yesterday for a composite debate on motions put forward by Senator Mason and me. But now, for all practical purposes, the deal that has been done between Senator Mason and Senator Evans, behind the back of the Senate, without consultation with the Opposition and without consultation with me, has in effect torpedoed the attempt that the Senate was making to give proper and due consideration to this matter. Senator Mason, after a great flurry of publicity against the flood of hard core pornography into this country, has in fact by the deal ensured that the importation and sale of hard core pornography will in fact be legalised in this country.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. My point of order is simply this: Senator Harradine is addressing himself to substantive issues involved in the debate, not to the procedural matter which is involved in this motion or the speech he is addressing to the motion.
—Senator Harradine might take that matter on board while he is addressing his remarks to the procedural motion before the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr President. The fact of the matter is that prior to Senator Mason putting down his notices of motion to disallow the regulations, I had determined to do the same but because he indicated that he was going to move to disallow the regulation I did not put down a motion to disallow the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment), the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment)--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I understand that under standing order 74 this is a procedural motion. I question the capacity of Senator Harradine to be debating it in this way.
—I uphold the point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in view of the comments of Senator Harradine I feel I must seek leave of the Senate to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have never before in this place sat and listened to the degree of rubbish and misrepresentation which was brought forward yesterday by Senator Walters and today by Senator Harradine over this matter. Senator Harradine has the effrontery to get up here and say that I changed my view on this matter. Anybody who reads the newspapers or looks at anything over the last three weeks will understand that there were two matters, and two matters only, which were required by the Australian Democrats. Those two matters were achieved yesterday. I will only say that anybody who gets up in this place and says that we have changed our minds on that matter is a liar and I will leave that statement hanging in the air.

SPEECH.PARA: The PRESIDENT: Order! The honourable senator should not use that remark. It is unparliamentary. I ask him to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it, Mr President. I will say that those people are tampering maliciously with the truth. The point is-and I wish to establish it quite firmly here-that two very enlightened and useful changes in the law relating to X rated video tapes-and, after all, this is what Senator Harradine was on about-have been achieved in that these tapes will be subject to censorship probably throughout this country on a compulsory basis and that there will be a situation where cruel, violent and sadistic material will not be allowed in under Customs. Those two matters have been our ground for three weeks . They are our reasons for raising our motions. We have made it perfectly clear that having achieved that our point would have been satisfied. I want that point to be clearly on record.

—by leave-Senator Grimes has moved a motion about which I think there is a great deal of misunderstanding. Perhaps if Senator Grimes explained what his motion did it would clear everything up for the Senate and we would not have a continuation of what seems to me to be an unnecessary debate. There is real confusion on this side of the chamber.
—If that debate is raised from your side you must expect replies to it.
—I am trying to get some sense into this place to which Senator Mason has not contributed much lately.

—by leave-Obviously the furore which resulted from this motion, as Senator Durack says, resulted from a misunderstanding. As Senator Harradine said, yesterday the Senate decided to have a cognate debate on all these matters. I think Senator Sir John Carrick is in fact in continuation. All the motion that I moved does is bring us back to exactly where we were yesterday, so that we can continue that debate and then proceed in the normal way. No deals have been done. There is no malice, nor is there any evil intent. I thought it was a sensible thing, as I think most people did, to rearrange the business to bring the debate back on, to resume from where it was yesterday. That is what is on the red order of business sheet and on the Notice Paper. There is no intention other than that to allow Senator Sir John Carrick and others who wanted to speak in the debate to continue.

—by leave-In respect of Senator Grimes's suggestion that we are being taken back to where we were yesterday, the whole point of my speaking was to show that we are not being taken back to where we were yesterday by reason of matters that have been dealt with outside this chamber. If we are going to proceed with a vote on these issues, as we were to proceed yesterday, that is a different matter. But as I understand it, the proposal is to adjourn these matters until 1 May. That places us in an entirely different situation from that of yesterday and in fact--
—This motion is not to adjourn.
—No, I know it is not to adjourn.
—This motion is not doing it. There will be a motion to adjourn.
—There will be a motion to adjourn and that then will not enable me to move the motions standing in my name, No. 3 and No. 4, and to speak to both of them.
—That is what you were doing yesterday. You agreed to a cognate debate yesterday.

—No. Because the Government has a deferral in the air it will be necessary for me to make out very clearly some case, particularly in respect of notice of motion No. 3, that it is essential for it to go forward at this time.
—You had that opportunity yesterday when you spoke.

—No, because it was understood yesterday that the reason that was being put forward by Senator Mason in respect of his notice of motion to disallow was substantive, namely, the flood of pornography into this country. Now he has of course sold everybody out in respect of that and gone-
—Mr President, I take a point of order.
—And he knows it as well as I do.
—Order! Senator Harradine will resume his seat.
—If he does not know, he is the only bloke who does not know.
—Order! Senator Mason is taking a point of order.
—I raise a point of order of the irrelevance of Senator Harradine' s contributions to this debate and the even worse aggravation of them by the fact that he is telling direct lies about-
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw it, but Senator Harradine has misrepresented what I said yesterday. My speech yesterday made it absolutely clear which two points the Australian Democrats wanted. He obviously did not take the trouble to listen to it or read it. I simply cannot see why we should sit here and have this misrepresentation under privilege by a Tasmanian senator.
—Order! No point of order is involved. Senator Harradine sought and was given leave to make a statement.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 April, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 331 and made under the Customs Act 1901, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in defending his reasons for altering the approach to this matter said yesterday that over the years the Customs laws relating to these matters were totally inadequate and were not enforced. He did not dilate on whether they could be made more adequate or could be enforced.
—I don't believe so.

—The Attorney-General says he does not believe that. That is a respectable view but, nevertheless, a view that should be tested. The essence of the matter is whether we can stop importation at the source when it is a trickle, or allow it through and then let it proliferate and become a flood . It is obvious that if one cannot stop through Customs regulations by policing, one cannot stop a proliferation elsewhere. I direct the attention of the Senate to the fact that there is a need throughout Australia to look to whether the Customs laws and regulations can be strengthened and can be enforced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General made some simplistic statements, on two of which I want to touch because they should not pass unnoticed. He invited honourable senators to look at an article published in the National Times suggesting that fantasising had therapeutic value for those kinds of people, particularly disabled people, who are unable to have normal relationships. That is not what this debate is about. There is no restriction at all on video films which show normal human relationships and normal acts of tenderness and love, including physical expression. What this debate is about is the depiction of gross, perverse and distorted actions so that any therapeutic value would be rejected. I know that psychiatrists will say that there is no such definition as normal and abnormal and they take the more absolutist view, but society itself takes the relative view and establishes norms.

The Attorney-General also quoted an American journalist, Ellen Willis, in an article which he commended. Ellen Willis said: 'What turns me on is erotic; what turns you on is pornographic'. If that were to have value, one should look at what the word 'erotic' means. 'Erotic' is derived from the god Eros and pertains to love. There is no suggestion at all that what we are talking about in this debate is love. We are talking about the distortion of human relationships in terms of the obscene and pornographic. I pause merely to say that one should not intrude into this debate over-simplistic comments.

It is fascinating in this debate that women's organisations covering the whole spectrum of women's thought-from those with more conservative views to those with more permissive views-have unanimously reflected their opposition to the present approach. They have taken the view that what is to be allowed to happen will continue the debasing and degrading of women. I want to see the matter widened. This is not a subject specifically relating to the debasement or degradation of women. If what they are saying is right, if the male of the species is the degrader or the debaser of women, then the male is himself degraded and debased. So both sexes are part of this situation. The cause should not be the preserve of womenfolk only, although I acknowledge what they are saying; these things debase and degrade both sexes. If they do that and if they are allowed to be represented to youngsters, of course the youngsters will be entitled to form a view that that is part of human relations, that is normal and that is part of the social mores and it is not wrong. This is the very heart of the problem. It is not good enough for the Attorney-General to lay down the principle in approach to this that what adults do by consent in the privacy of their own homes they should be allowed to do, including reading and seeing those various activities.

Let me give honourable senators an example. We do not allow assault. We are strongly opposed as a community to the importation and distribution of hard drugs, including mind bending drugs. We do not allow people to buy such drugs and, in the privacy of their homes, either abuse themselves or abuse others by consent. We intervene into the private castle of the individual in a number of ways. Therefore one should not accept the absolutist views that have been put forward. After all, the psychedelic drugs, the hallucinatory drugs, are the destroyers of the mind as well as the body, and many people believe that, for the young at least, the distortion of the pornographic videos does much the same .

What I have sought to do in this debate is to try to identify the kind of signposts that we should follow. We are not, as I have said, dealing with a choice between no censorship and some censorship. There is agreement from the Government and others that there must be some censorship, and there is a list of various matters that are to be censored. The real questions are where the line should be drawn and who shall make those value judgments. There has been considerable discussion upon whether one should ban 'extreme violence' or ' violence'. What do we mean? We should test that with the public. We should invite parents and individuals to tell us what this means. It is of fundamental importance that the very absolutists in this approach should not use paternalism by saying: 'I know what is right. I will enforce it'.

Let me say, without being combative, that it sits very strangely and uncomfortably with those here who talk of human liberties and say that they are in favour of human liberties to allow this when they have banned the whole of this community from achieving voluntary private health insurance. If ever we want to see how governments react to restrain we have that on our plate. So those who would do a particular thing in one respect, as they do with thousands of laws-because the socialist is the great law maker and the great regulator of the community-in this matter want to do otherwise.

Where are we on this? The situation with videos relates not to adults only but to children as well. We have the whole spectrum of womenfolk of this community saying that in any case they find the regulations unsatisfactory. They want something done. I remind myself of Shakespeare saying in Twelfth Night:
In nature there's no blemish but the mind; None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind.

He meant of course, in using the word 'unkind', the unnatural. None can be called deformed but the unnatural. In point of fact, what we are looking at is the kind of community we want to project for those around us to see. Fundamentally, the argument of those who advocate virtually absolute freedom is that the mature person is capable of withstanding anything; capable of making judgments and of looking at and absorbing violence and distortion, and that somehow or other that should be allowed. In point of fact, the test of maturity, as Mill and other great freedom fighters saw it, is that people would constantly say: 'The real test of my maturity is my willingness to concede some loss of my personal liberty in order that the total freedom and dignity of the community shall be established'.

I conclude on the point that we would do well to remind ourselves when debating matters of great moment like this what Parliament, or government, is all about. Government is not an end in itself and society is not an end in itself. Government is a means to an end; it is to create an environment for the individual and the individual family. We should never lose sight of that. We should never lose sight of community mores. We should seek to use our influence to create an environment which enables human beings to develop their dignity, their spirituality. This is a great problem. I commend the whole researching of this matter, a tossing of it back to the public and the seeking of an inquiry to find out what the public wants. It is paternalism for the liberationists to say they know what the public wants. I reject that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with the implications of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment), the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment), the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983, relating to the Australian Capital Territory, and its regulations. As we have heard, the existing Customs regulations are being abandoned to bring these regulations and the Ordinance into effect. We are told by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that the Customs regulations have fallen into disrepute and are not observed. He is the one who should tell the chamber why it is that they have fallen into disrepute and are not being observed because it is his responsibility to see that they are enforced and observed. The Attorney-General has clearly indicated to his people that it is not necessary for them to enforce these regulations, and of course he has done that in other areas as well. It is worth looking at the amendments to compare what we are abolishing with what we are bringing into effect. Regulation 4A at present states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) This regulation applies to goods . . . that, whether of their own nature or having regard to any literary or other work or matter that is embodied, recorded or reproduced in, or can be reproduced from, the goods-
(a) are blasphemous, indecent or obscene; or
(b) unduly emphasize matters of sex, horror, violence or crime, or are likely to encourage depravity,
and to advertising matter relating to such goods.

The section goes on to say that the people judging these things are authorised by the Attorney-General. Throughout all of the legislation it is quite clear that it is all his responsibility; he is responsible for appointing the relevant people.
What has the legislation been replaced with? Section (1A), which replaces sub- regulation 1 of the former regulation 4A, refers to:

(a) publications, other than films that are registered under the Customs ( Cinematograph Films) Regulations, that, in the opinion of the Attorney-General or a person authorized by him for the purposes of this sub-regulation-

(i) depict in pictorial form a child (whether engaged in sexual activity or otherwise) who is, or who is apparently, under the age of 16 years in a manner that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person;
(ii) promote, incite or encourage terrorism; or
(iii) gratuitously depict in pictorial form extreme violence or cruelty . . .

We understand the Attorney has agreed to withdraw the word 'extreme'. I wonder what that really will do to the legislation. In no way does the package proposed deal with the sort of pornography that we have spoken about in this debate-the exploitation and degradation of women. Having passed the Sex Discrimination Bill , it seems extraordinary that we should be faced with a situation where that sort of pornography is not any longer to be excluded.

It is clear that, as a result of the changes proposed in these regulations, the Attorney-General is allowing hardcore pornography to be a part of the scene in this country. As I said, if he claims that it already is, then it is because he has failed to administer the regulations for which he has responsibility. He made the claim yesterday that there was public demand for this sort of material, but he did not give any evidence whatever to support that assertion. To me it is a matter of extreme regret that Senator Mason has changed his approach to dealing with these regulations and the ordinance. His actions will ensure the legalisation of the sale of hardcore pornography in the Australian Capital Territory and the legalisation of its importation into this country.

Yesterday Senator Mason made an excellent speech. I thought it was one of the best speeches that he has made. In that speech he set out in an extremely effective manner the reasons that the ordinance and regulations should be disallowed. I am very disappointed indeed at the turn that the whole event has taken; I regret it. I believe that the ordinance still should be disallowed. In the Australian Capital Territory the Attorney-General is the chief, the person who appoints the officer who determines the classification of material, and the Attorney-General determines who shall be prosecuted in this area, as he does in other areas. It may surprise you to know, Mr Deputy President, that the running of a brothel in the Australian Capital Territory is illegal. According to the newspapers and the correspondence I get from constituents brothels abound in the Australian Capital Territory. Presumably the Attorney-General has a different attitude towards brothels because he has not prosecuted any brothel proprietors, even though police have raided brothels and obtained sufficient evidence to allow a prosecution to proceed. The only explanation that we know of for his inaction is that apparently he says that not enough people have complained about their existence.

The people of the Australian Capital Territory are very much in the hands of this man in determining what he regards as good for the community. He likes most people to have freedom in pursuing those activities that he believes in. However , he does not allow the same freedom to his own back benchers to make their own decisions about these matters. I think we need to examine the standards he brings to bear in making decisions on legislation such as this. As I said, he has been in a position to ensure the enforcement of those regulations that are in existence. I think the turn that the legislation has taken now will legitimise the flood into this country of this sort of material, and I am sorry that Senator Mason has been a party to that.

A report that appeared in this morning's Canberra Times about the classification of this material highlights what in fact has happened, namely, that video tapes, both good and bad, will be classified compulsorily in the Australian Capital Territory. However, the article does not go to the heart of the matter; namely, what material will in fact be allowed into this country. Another interesting aspect of the report of the debate in yesterday's Canberra Times is that it refers to the threats of the Australian Democrats and the Opposition to disallow the ordinance and regulations. The Opposition was serious in moving to disallow those regulations and that ordinance. It was not threatening to do so, but apparently the Australian Democrats were only threatening. In this article that word was used twice in relation to the Australian Democrats. It is reported in the same article that the Attorney- General said that if the disallowance motion had not been rescinded but had been proceeded with it would have been a particularly obstreperous use of Senate majority power. He does not seem to have much regard for the views of other people if those views differ in any way from his own. He said that the disallowance would have caused chaos, confusion and legal uncertainty in Customs administration and the Australian Capital Territory video industry. Of course, that would not have been the case if he had enforced the legislation that was in existence.

The Attorney-General now says that if this debate is adjourned he will put before the Senate the Government's intentions on the matter when the Senate resumes early in May. That may be so, but it will not allow the public appropriate time to examine the new proposals. I would have thought that it would be appropriate to allow the public time to examine this type of legislation. No doubt he will say that if he does not bring the matter before the Senate at that time there will not be time to deal with the motions of disallowance. I believe that these regulations and the ordinance ought to be disallowed so that proper discussions can take place as to what should occur. If they are disallowed today the regulations which exist can still operate and the Attorney-General can come back with something which is rather more appropriate than the present legislation.

I said that we are dealing with a man whose judgment we have to trust in these matters. I think that it is reasonable to question whether we would want to rely on his judgment. Yesterday we heard his reference to buying the votes of the Australian Democrats, using language that I would not repeat. Last year we spent some time examining his actions and his judgment in relation to the spy flights over Tasmania. I seriously doubt the judgment of any person who would have been involved in that in the first place. The Combe situation brought his actions to light. I found the matter of his interview of Mr Combe extraordinary indeed. There was the referendum issue. He was prepared quietly to change the nature of the ballot papers for the first time in history. He wanted $1.25m to promote his side of the argument, treating the electors at large as if they were idiots and not able to view the matter for themselves and had to be persuaded in this way. In his view, apparently we are better off by having a pretty fair flow of pornographic material into this country which people can see, but he will not give to this chamber a copy of the Menzies report on the Sala investigation. It seems to me that we either agree with him or he gets very angry.

People are concerned about this legislation. The matter was sent to the local House of Assembly. Honourable senators will recall that in the election campaign last year the then Opposition indicated its commitment to take notice of the views of the House of Assembly. As we know from the casino issue this Government does take notice if it suits the Government and does not if it does not suit the Government. The Attorney referred this matter to the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren). The Minister for Territories and Local Government referred it to the House of Assembly. He said:

My colleague, the Attorney-General, has asked me to refer the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 to the Assembly for its consideration and advice. The Attorney-General has asked that the following information be provided to the Assembly.
He went on:

The Ordinance was prepared as model legislation for implementation of the uniform censorship classification scheme agreed to by Commonwealth State Ministers with responsibility for censorship in July 1983. The scheme is expected to come into operation on 1 February 1984.

It is strange that we now have this legislation before us, but the States seem to be showing some reluctance to go along with it. I would have thought that alone would have warned the Attorney-General to proceed with somewhat less haste with this legislation when it was quite clear that the State governments were not proceeding in the same way. The Assembly was given a briefing by officers of the Attorney-General's Department last year. The fact is that the Assembly did agree to support the legislation. It did so because it believed at that time what it was told; that is, that it was to be complementary legislation between the States and the Territories and this was a necessary part of it. Subsequently , it found that was not the case. The matter came up before the House of Assembly last week. A motion was put to rescind the previous approval of the legislation. I am not aware of any disagreement which would indicate that members of the House of Assembly opposed it. The fact now is that the House of Assembly does not agree with this change of legislation in the Australian Capital Territory. Mrs Hocking, speaking in the debate, said:

I support the amendment. I believe it was misleading when we had a Press release of 25 January from the Attorney-General which said over and over again that there was to be censorship of publications and video tapes when in fact it was known all along that the Customs Regulations would bring in an open season approach to the admission of all types and any type of hard core pornography into this country. The article in the Sun Herald on 19 February says: 'That overseas distributors are planning to dump container loads of pornographic publications and videos as soon as the State Government gives the legal go ahead .'
Ms Walmsley also spoke against the legislation. Mrs Hocking, quoting Ms Walmsley , said:
This is one occasion when Family Team Members find themselves in complete agreement with their radical feminist sisters in strongly objecting to the abuse of women as things or sex objects.
From what I quoted earlier, it is quite clear that the legislative change which is proposed is correctly interpreted in those words. She also said:

It is useless to place warning signs outside restricted areas to protect those 18 year old and under, when their parents or older brothers and sisters can take the stuff home for unrestricted viewing in their own lounge rooms.

It is clear that in the Australian Capital Territory the majority of those representing the community in this forum do not agree with this legislation and do not want it. There is no adequate provision for protecting children from seeing these sorts of films in their own homes. As I said yesterday, Senator Mason dealt with a number of aspects. That with which he dealt most effectively was in pointing out the difference of being able to read and to see. Children can see video material. It can be on in their home and they have no ability to evaluate what they are seeing. By the time children can read, they may be able to read things which are harmful, but certainly children view videos at a much earlier age. They see violence, hard core pornography, extremely damaging material which would not be allowed in if the existing regulations had been enforced, and not these new ones brought in.

I have heard recently of two separate occasions of young boys being able to see this sort of material in their homes. One was a case of a group staying overnight at a birthday party. After the parents went to bed the boys sat around and watched video films which they knew to be in the house. On another occasion a boy had taken a key that he knew gave him entry into a cupboard where his father kept these films and all night viewing took place. It is not adequate to say that it is just a question of adults viewing this material in their homes. It is available to children if it is available at all. I regret that the Australian Democrats, in pursuing the matter as they have, have allowed this to come in. I thought it a bit ironic this morning that on the front page of the Canberra Times, right next to the article to which I have referred in relation to this debate, was an article headed 'Children's television standards issued'. It deals with a number of matters including:

Advertising standards designed to ensure that the vulnerability of children is not exploited through misleading advertising, undue psychological pressure, unsafe products, endorsements by children's program characters.

A standard requiring that no program, advertisement of other transmission during 'C' time may demean any group or class of people on the basis of sex, age , race, ethnicity, disability, religious beliefs or political convictions.

It is right and proper that there should be regulations within television to protect children during the times that children are likely to be watching television. But there are videos; these days many houses have videos. I certainly know of one three-year-old child who knows how to work a video machine in her house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that censorship standards should be governed by those appropriate for three-year-old children?

—What I am talking about is the possibility of children of all ages watching them. I have dealt with 12-year-old boys seeing material that is not appropriate for them. But if such material is in the country, they will see it. The rules applying to videos now are different from those applying to films. What I really get back to saying is: Why is there such a rush to change the regulations and bring in this regulation? Why not disallow the ordinances and start again, when they have been thought through properly and when there has been a much greater opportunity for consultation in the community? Why not enforce the legislation which exists at present? The House of Assembly certainly felt that it had been misled in what it was asked to do in the first place compared with what it now finds out to be the case. It regards it as premature.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that the Government has made a commitment to give financial impact statements. I refer to a speech by the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, on 7 September 1983 when he said that another major reform of the Government involves the presentation of financial impact statements. He said then that in the future all second reading speeches, would have significant information relating to costs, revenue and saving. He said that Ministers would attempt to assess the impact on industry and other sections of the community and get to know the financial and economic effect of their legislation. Most people welcomed that although we have not seen many of them as yet. In recent times we have all become familiar with environmental impact statements, the necessity for them and the reason they have become part of the legislative process.

I wonder whether it is not time that we started thinking about human impact statements when bringing in legislation of this kind. We should do some research and give some thought to the real implications on people of this type of legislation. It is time that we threw out these ordinances and got around to preparing a human impact statement on the changes, bearing in mind the availability of the videos, before we allow the introduction of hard core pornography which will flow from passing these ordinances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to occupy the time of the Senate for very long but I am very concerned at some misrepresentations and some allegations that have been made by honourable senators in this place yesterday and today. To put the matter into perspective it is important that the Senate be aware that this whole issue was raised in the first instance by Senator Mason of the Australian Democrats approximately three weeks ago. Since then Senator Mason, with the wholehearted support of the Australian Democrats, has used his leverage to bring about the changes to which the Government has now agreed. From all that I have heard from the Opposition, those changes are exactly what the Opposition has requested throughout this debate. We have achieved the changes that the Opposition seeks to achieve but lacks the ability to achieve because of its bulldozer approach.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be quite clear about what has happened in this debate. The Opposition has used it as a vehicle once more to express its views on standards within the community. It has ignored the real issue which is that at the moment, or up until recently, it has been open door for pornography. This is a move to close that door on the worst kinds of pornography.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been open door only since 1 February.
—It was open door while Senator Durack was in the Government. Let us make that quite clear.
—It was not open door. What rubbish.

—Senator Walters has not denied that throughout her speech. Let her deny now that it was not open door throughout the life of the previous Government. If it has not been open door, I would like her to explain how it is that we have all this pornography, to which Senator Reid referred, flooding the countryside at the moment. If that was not an open door policy, she should let us know what is an open door policy. The Australian Democrats specifically set out to achieve two improvements to these ordinances and regulations. I believe that those improvements, and possibly others, will be achieved over the next few weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to put a point to members of the Opposition because I was very saddened to see that nobody in this chamber was listening to Senator Sir John Carrick as he made a very good speech on this subject. It was an objective speech. It put the case from all points of view, as I understood him, and I believe that he put it into a perspective that members of the Opposition, particularly Senator Walters, would do well to read and to understand. What Senator Sir John Carrick said was that it is not up to us to impose our standards on the community. I repeat: It is not up to Senator Walters to impose her standards on the community. It is up to us to discover what are the community standards and to move in line with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Agreed.

—If that is agreed, perhaps the Senate would also agree that Senator Sir John Carrick said that, having discovered what the community standards are, somebody then has to set those standards. I know that Senator Walters would like to set those standards in her terms. She made that very clear throughout her speech. But Senator Walters is not only not in Government at this stage, she is also not in a position to impose her standards on the rest of Australia. The Government is in the position to set the standards. It is up to the Government to set standards acceptable to the community at large and up to the Senate to agree to or modify those standards. That is what this debate is about-modifying them, not throwing out those standards, as would be the case if we accepted what the Opposition proposes.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that over the next four weeks, as a result of this debate, we will have the input which was suggested by Senator Sir John Carrick. We will receive that input from parents and from the community generally and as a result of that input and principally as a result of the debate that will take place tomorrow between the State Attorneys-General and the Federal Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) we will have the potential to formulate new regulations and ordinances to embody the views of the community at large and not just one section of the community as represented by Senator Walters. Let it be very clearly understood that, as far as the Democrats are concerned, there is no fait accompli with these regulations and the ordinance. They are amendable. They are in the process of being amended and there is potential to amend them further. We heard a suggestion yesterday that the interpretation given by Janet Strickland is likely to be incorporated in the ordinance. I believe that that is a step forward. I suspect that the Attorney is sympathetic to that suggestion. However, that will not be open to just our Attorney-General; it will be the subject of discussion by all the Attorneys-General.

If I heard the Opposition suggest that the other Attorneys-General should have no input into this debate and should have no say on what will be set up as the model regulations and ordinances, I would wonder what had happened to States rights and the call for States rights from this side of the chamber. This is the ideal opportunity to get agreement from the States on the model regulations and ordinance. We should not impose our standards on the States but have their input and listen to their discussions so that hopefully we will arrive at a consensus with all of the Attorneys so that this is a real model which will be followed implicitly by all of the States. That is an ideal worth seeking to achieve.

I believe it is important to put Senator Mason's position into perspective. That was the main reason for my rising to speak. There have been gross distortions by Senator Durack by way of interjection, by Senator Walters who spoke yesterday and by Senator Harradine in his brief comments this morning. Senator Mason has already achieved the two vital changes that others seek to achieve. He has had a commitment from the Government that the first of those changes would effectively refuse admission to the country under Customs rules of gratuitously cruel, violent and sadistic video tapes that have sexual elements. Let us recognise the distinction that needs to be drawn because the existing regulation would let that material in providing it is not extreme. Perhaps Senator Walters and Senator Durack do not understand the difference between those two types of material but that is what has already been achieved. It would not be achieved, Senator Walters, by disallowance of the regulation. I ask you to deny that. If you disallow the regulation you will not achieve that objective .

TALK.START.PARA: —Then enforce the law.
—You would not achieve it. You would go back to open doors and let anything in.
—Rubbish, you would not go back to open doors.
—I am sorry, Senator, you do not understand the regulation and its effect.
—Senator Evans, I suggest that you direct your remarks through the Chair. I will then be able to hear what you are contributing to this debate.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Mason's second achievement was that, under the Australian Capital Territory ordinance, which is intended to be a model for all the States, censorship will be compulsory and not voluntary as it is at present. Once more I put it to the Senate that the Opposition wanted to achieve that objective and is very upset because the Australian Democrats, through Senator Mason, have achieved the objective that it sought to achieve but we have achieved it through negotiation and discussion and not through scoring points in this Senate chamber on broadcast day. We have achieved the objective through meaningful, positive, constructive discussions with the Attorney-General.
—Absolute rubbish!

—Senator Lewis said that it is absolute rubbish. I am not too sure what Senator Lewis is disputing. Is he disputing the achievement? That is there for all to see. Is he disputing that that method of achieving the objective is not the appropriate way to go about it? Perhaps he is suggesting that because he was not able to achieve it himself. Senator Lewis, the verbal browbeater of this chamber, has probably never been able to achieve an agreement with the party on the opposite side of the chamber through negotiation and discussion and thereby arrive at a constructive amendment that will satisfy most parties. That is what we have been after. We have been trying to satisfy most parties because one of the things that has been evident in this debate is that nobody in the Senate chamber represents 100 per cent of the views of the people of Australia on this subject. I do not believe that I represent 100 per cent of the views-nor does Senator Durack, Senator Walters or Senator Gareth Evans. None of us can do that. What we must endeavour to achieve in this debate is a degree of consensus that will satisfy the great majority of Australians in this very personal area. I quote from yesterday's Hansard a gross distortion of the Australian Democrats' position in this debate. It was done by Senator Walters when she rose, by leave, to make some comments. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to correct a few words I said in my speech. I said I had the pleasure of joining Senators Harradine and Mason in their move to disallow the regulations and ordinances. I now find that the Democrats have decided not to support the motion.

That is an absolute distortion of our position. I wish to have that withdrawn by Senator Walters when the opportunity arises in the future and in particular when she discovers that the Australian Democrats support the ordinance and regulations as amended and as the Opposition would have them amended and as I believe this Senate totally agrees to their being amended. Until that happens we will not change our stance at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the rest of what I said.
—I will read the rest of what Senator Walters said. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans has, as he said in his speech, been able to buy their lousy vote.
She continued later:
The Democrats have fallen for that and have changed their minds. Their vote has been bought and they no longer intend to support the motion.

(Quorum formed) I will just repeat the distortion made by Senator Walters yesterday of the Australian Democrats' position when she said: 'The Democrats have decided not to support the motion'. Not at any stage have the Australian Democrats announced or indicated that they were not going to support the motion of disallowance which was put forward by Senator Mason. Not at any stage has that been said inside or outside this chamber. So I refute absolutely the claim made by Senator Walters and I repeat that I hope that Senator Walters has the good grace to acknowledge that she was totally and absolutely wrong in that claim.

The Democrats have not ever indicated that they will change their stance which has been consistent right through. Despite the fact that we have been negotiating for the improvements we have retained our consistency on our position and we will continue to do so until we are totally satisfied that the ordinance and regulations are in line with what we believe the community wants them to be. We have simply at this stage agreed to a deferral. That deferral will come forward in due course and the debate no doubt will be resumed. I believe we will then be discussing entirely different regulations and ordinances . At that stage our position will be known and so will that of Senator Walters, Senator Lewis and Senator Durack. I would be surprised if all positions do not change as a result of the introduction of new regulations and ordinances. That would be a normal thing to happen. But as they stand now, the regulations and ordinance will be disallowed by the Australian Democrats. Is that adequately clear because that is precisely our position. It has not changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —When? Next month?

—Do not give me the red herring of timing. Senator Walters said yesterday that we were not going to disallow. Let it be quite clearly understood: We have not changed our position. The regulations and ordinance will be disallowed within the time allowed for disallowance. That is our position and it has not changed. I am saying that the regulations and ordinance as they now stand will be disallowed by the Australian Democrats. That position has not changed and is not likely to change.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a number of interjections from my rear, which is quite an appropriate place for them to be coming from because of the nature of them, indicating that the Australian Democrats will allow a flood of child pornography into Australia. I indicated earlier-I thought the honourable senator would have been wise enough to recognise this-what is being proposed and the dreadful hiatus that would be caused if we disallowed the regulations and ordinance and replaced them with nothing. Let us just have a clear understanding that, if disallowed, the hiatus that would be created would allow a flood of material into this country such as we have never seen because of the potential for porno merchants getting into the gap that is going to be created, before new regulations and ordinances are introduced thanks to the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand the effect of disallowance.

—I am sorry; I clearly understand because we have already seen a trickle of it. The honourable senator does not understand what is likely to be the effect of allowing the trickle to develop into a flood. That would be the effect. Of course, one wonders what the motives are for this disallowance being pushed through.
—Surely, the friend of the porno merchants.

—One wonders whether, through innocence and ignorance, people who purport to be opposing the porno merchants are in fact helping the porno merchants. That would be the likely effect if these regulations and ordinance were to be disallowed today.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps out of the debate yesterday we can get some common sense. It has become evident that the present situation is unsatisfactory. I think that all sides have agreed that under the present regulations and under the present modus operandi, the Customs officers are not preventing the importation of pornographic material. There has to be a change. It is recognised by everybody that there has to be a change. All we are suggesting is that the change be effective and not just a series of words that are going to satisfy some of the wordsmiths in this House and let people flood a market in Australia which the Senate is trying to look after and protect.

All that the Australian Democrats' position represents is a means of improving the regulations and ordinance; a means of having input from all Attorneys- General, State and Federal, towards that improvement; a means, as Senator Sir John Carrick suggested, of getting some input from the rest of the community; and then, probably on the very next day that this Parliament sits, having the opportunity to consider those new regulations and ordinance. I hope and believe that as a result of the discussions and as a result of this debate the new regulations and ordinance will be acceptable not only to this chamber and to the people of the Australian Capital Territory but also to all of the Attorneys- General and to the people of all of the States of Australia.
Motion (by Senator Robertson) proposed:
That the debate be now adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will speak to that.
—I would like to raise a point of order.
—Order! You will not debate the motion to adjourn this matter.

—I am not debating it. I want to raise a point or order before the motion is put. Madam Acting Deputy President, I am very concerned that there should be a possibility of any vote being taken on this matter while the Australian Democrats are under a complete misapprehension as to what is the legal effect of a disallowance because a disallowance revives a previous regulation.

—I take a point of order on the point of order. My point of order is that Senator Durack's point, whatever else it is, is not a point of order. He is simply using the occasion in order to make a substantive contribution to the debate and to make a plea to the Senate as to why the matter should not be voted on.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I am taking a point of order. I should like to be able to be heard on the point of order without interruption.
—Is it a point of order and not a point of law?
—The point of order I am taking is that the Senate should not proceed to a vote where honourable senators are under misapprehensions as to what the effects of the vote would be.
—Senator Durack, that is not a point of order.
—I have simply pointed out that the effect of disallowance is to revive previous regulations, not to leave a complete vacuum.
—The Chair does not normally recognise points of law . I will not rule on that. That is not a point of order.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for 2 May 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move an amendment to that motion, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'for', insert '12 noon this day'.

I wish to speak to this amendment because Senator Jack Evans has just finished speaking to the Senate and he has misled it; he has misled anyone who followed what he said in regard to what the law currently is in Australia in regard to the disallowance of a regulation. It is a matter of grave concern--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. This contribution of Senator Lewis is no more directed to the substance of his amendment than was Senator Durack's alleged point of order earlier on in this debate. He is addressing himself to a substantive question of law; it is an argumentative submission. It is not one directed to the timing of the resumption of the debate .
—There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I will come to the reason why we need to resume this debate at 12 noon today. The Australian Democrat senators in this Parliament are apparently under the delusion that if a regulation is disallowed there is an hiatus.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know where the Democrats got that information from. I suspect they got it from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) who does not want them to know the truth of the matter. Mr President, I direct these remarks through you specifically to Senator Jack Evans. The situation is that in 1982 there was an amendment to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981; namely, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act (No. 1) 1982, Act No. 26 of 1982. If Senator Jack Evans does not believe me-of course he will not believe me because I am one of those stupid Liberals-I suggest he talk to the Clerk of the Senate or one of his assistants who would be able to advise him that the result of that legislation which was passed through the Parliament was as follows:
'(7) Where-
(a) a regulation . . . is disallowed . . . and
(b) the relevant regulation repealed, in whole or in part, another regulation that was in force immediately before the relevant regulation came into operation ,
the disallowance of the relevant regulation-

TALK.START.PARA: —What makes you think they do not know that? That is A-B-C.
—I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: or the operation of sub-section (3) in relation to the relevant regulation, as the case may be, has the effect of reviving that other regulation from and including the date of the disallowance . . .

For honourable senators here to interject that something is simple and elementary after we have just heard an honourable senator stand up and say that that would not be the case is an absolute nonsense. The Attorney-General sits across there in the chamber smirking and going on because he knows he has absolutely conned the Democrats in this matter, bought their votes. He said yesterday to the Senate that if that is what he had to do to win the Democrats' lousy vote he was prepared to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator should withdraw that expression.
—Mr President, with respect, I would be prepared to withdraw it, but may I quote to you from yesterday's Hansard?
—The honourable senator is quite entitled to quote.
—Senator Gareth Evans, as recorded on page 1182 of the Hansard for 4 April 1984, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would prefer to wait until the meeting on Friday if it is possible there may be some better formula. I am certainly prepared to do it by tomorrow if that is the price of buying the honourable senator's lousy vote . . .

Yesterday morning I heard most of Senator Mason's speech and it seemed to me to make good sense. I thought that I would not have to speak on the subject of disallowance because clearly the Democrat senators and the Opposition would combine to disallow the regulation. That was as at yesterday. What happened was that some time yesterday afternoon the Attorney-General bought their lousy vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. This is a fascinating contribution to the substantive debate on the merits of the argument for disallowance, but it has nothing whatever to do with the matter in issue. Senator Lewis's amendment relates to the timing of the resumption of the debate. I suggest that he be ruled out of order.

—On the point of order, I believe Senator Lewis's contributions are relevant because the importance of this issue is that tomorrow the Attorney-General and his fellow Attorneys-General meet. Therefore it is essential not only for this chamber but also for the Attorneys-General to be aware of the facts of the situation as described quite rightly by Senator Lewis.
—It may appear somewhat tenuous, but I am allowing Senator Lewis some latitude to develop his argument as to why the debate should be adjourned until 12 noon.

—Thank you, Mr President; I appreciate what you are doing. Let me explain why I am saying that this debate must come on again today. Our choices are either 12 noon today or much later this afternoon when the Senate will be about to rise. If the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations are not disallowed today, under those regulations this filthy, rotten, pornographic material will be legally imported into this country.
—Legally.

—Yes, legally, under regulations brought down by the present Government. For the first time blasphemy will be allowed into the country, filthy, rotten stuff, and the attack on women will be allowed to take place via material brought into the country under existing regulations. If the regulations were disallowed today, the old regulations would be revived. That would be the situation. If the Democrats would only listen, they would understand that if the Senate takes the opportunity to disallow these regulations today, the old regulations would be revived and the material stopped from entering the country. But what will happen today, if this motion is carried, is that this debate will be adjourned and for the next three or four weeks, because the Senate will not be sitting, this filthy material will be brought into the country. We could stop it here today. What the Democrats have said to the Parliament is that when the debate comes on in three or four weeks' time within the total 30 sitting days, or perhaps within the next 15 sitting days from the notice of motion, the Democrats will then support the motion for disallowance.
—Unless they change their minds.

—One of my colleagues says: 'Unless they change their minds'. In the meantime it may be that the Attorney-General will be able to con them further. This is a matter of vital importance for the Senate to consider today, not in three or four weeks' time. What will happen to the country in that period of three or four weeks? This filthy material will be brought into this Territory , the Australian Capital Territory, and disseminated from here around the nation , to the detriment of the people. Everybody on this side, including the Democrats, agrees that it will be to the detriment of the people of this nation. The Senate can do something today if it deals with the matter now, whereas if we accept the amendment that this debate not be continued till 2 May, it means that between now and then it will be open slather for all these crims, all sorts of people with terrible ideas of pouring this stuff into the community. Once it is in here the tapes can be reproduced by all sorts of relatively cheap equipment and the material will be distributed around the nation to the detriment of the people. It will be to the detriment of anybody with any decency or morality, certainly to the detriment of children and women. It is nonsensical to suggest that this debate be adjourned to 2 May. That is why I put the case so strongly that we resume the debate at 12 noon today, take a vote on the matter and disallow these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis said that he wishes to bring the debate on at noon in an effort to educate the Australian Democrats, I gather.
—It has nothing to do with education.

—He certainly spoke extensively about the need to educate the Australian Democrats. The whole of the first part of his speech was devoted to the fact that he thought he had to educate us on the simple matter that when a regulation is disallowed the earlier regulation takes its place. It is absurd of an honourable senator to consider that we have not given that degree of attention to our work. I take it as a gross affront by Senator Lewis. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has made this point and one listens to the Attorney-General. He is, after all, the Attorney-General and has certain responsibilities. He made the claim and, so far as we can see, he substantiated it. His point is that regardless of the fact that the old ordinance will be in position, it will not have the desired effect. That point has been made again and again in this debate. Senator Lewis has not answered that point. Therefore, his argument is spurious and on behalf of the Australian Democrats I reject it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a second point at issue. I am amazed that the Liberal Party has not taken it into account; perhaps it is behind hand in its information. I understand from the Attorney-General that the change to this ordinance removing the word 'extreme' was signed by the Governor-General last night and will be gazetted today. Therefore, Senator Lewis is chasing something that was not there originally. He and his colleagues have put themselves in a totally absurd position.
