They are attempting to destroy something which has made an enormous degree of progress. Most newspapers and correspondents have said that this is of value and fundamental and that the word 'extreme' should be removed from the definition of violence. By doing so, one would put an effective bar on entry into Australia of violent material which is gratuitous and associated with the sex function. That is what the honourable senator and his colleagues want to vote against. It is the amended regulation that we are not considering. It has been amended; the Governor-General signed it last night at a quarter to six, and it will be gazetted today. They have put themselves in a totally false position. I do not see why this matter should resume at noon today, and certainly the Australian Democrats do not support that suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the one person in this chamber who feels most up in the air is me. I had understood that by Senator Mason moving to disallow the Classification of Publications Ordinance, the Customs ( Cinematograph Films) Regulations and the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, the Australian Democrats were seeking to stop the importation of and trafficking in hard core pornography that is going on now simply because the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) will not enforce existing laws.
—It is going on now. If you disallow the regulations it will continue to go on.

—Who said so? Are we to allow the Attorney-General to continue to get away with allowing breaches of the law? We have had an example put forward by Senator Reid as to what the Attorney-General is doing or not doing as the case may be, in regard to prostitution in the Australian Capital Territory. The laws are there, as has been explained quite explicitly by Senator Lewis-the amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act which last year were adopted by the Senate. Under those amendments had we disallowed these regulations, as proposed by Senator Mason, that would have revived the old regulations. As I said, all that was needed to stop this material was the Attorney-General implementing the law as it stands today.
—Ask Senator Durack whether he enforced them.

—I have said that in my speech on the disallowance motion. I have pointed out the situation not only so far as the Customs regulations are concerned but also so far as objectionable publications ordinances of the Australian Capital Territory are concerned. I explained where the rot set in, and the rot set in with the former Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, in 1973.
—What about Senator Durack?
—I gave him a serve.
—Which Attorney-General is going to implement them?
—That is what I say; this is the Attorney who should enforce the laws. Because the laws are not being enforced the Democrats are saying: 'We have an open slather situation, now let us legalise it'.
—No, we are not.

—The Democrats are saying that. Let me prove that. Let me prove what they are doing because they do not know as they have been absolutely conned. Let me just explain to the Democrats how they have been miserably conned . I am concerned about that because in good faith I said to Senator Mason: 'You can go ahead with the disallowance motion. I will not move for the disallowance. I will just move for the disallowance of the regulations'.
—You moved them on the same day.
—I did not move them on the same day. The honourable senator should read his Notice Paper. I did not move for the disallowance.
—You gave notice of it on the same occasion.
—I did not move for the disallowance. The honourable senator has said that I moved for the disallowance of the ordinance on that day and on the other regulations, but I did not.
—You gave notice, Senator, on the same day.
—Senator Mason is saying--
—You gave notice.

—Let us hear what he said. He is saying now that I gave notice on the same day that he did for the disallowance of the ordinance and for the disallowance of the Customs regulations. Did everybody hear him say that? Would everybody please go to the Notice Paper? This is how ridiculous these Democrats are. They do not even know what is on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like to discover what it is that we are debating. I have been trying to find out for the last five minutes. I ask whether the current debate has anything to do with the adjournment.

—The question before the Chair at the moment is: 'That the words proposed to be left out by Senator Lewis's amendment be left out'. I am allowing a fairly wide-ranging debate because it is relevant to the urgency of the motion and some of the material being put before the Senate is relevant. But I ask Senator Harradine not to spend too much time on minute details in the Notice Paper.
—I am responding and showing that the Democrats do not even read their Notice Paper.
—That is not very relevant to the adjournment of the matter .
—Well, it is relevant to me because I did not move for the disallowance of the Australian Capital Territory ordinance. I did not move for that, as Senator Mason has suggested.
—You did.
—I did not. Look at the damn Notice Paper. That is not even there. I did not move that because I was going to but Senator Mason said to me on that day that he would do so.
—I did not; you asked me.

—But now, Mr Deputy President, what we have is his pulling the rug out from under those of us who were concerned to see that the disallowance proceeded to a vote on the issue. That is what the Democrats have done, and in so doing they have been absolutely conned by the Attorney-General. Let us have a look at the big deal that they have got. According to Senator Mason's Press release the big deal is that they have got compulsory censorship-whatever that might mean-in the Australian Capital Territory. What is compulsory censorship? I suppose they mean compulsory classification. That might seem to be a minor point , but it is quite important. So they say that they have compulsory classification in the Australian Capital Territory. Now bear in mind that we are talking about so-called model rules for the rest of Australia. I can tell honourable senators now that so far as the other States were concerned, particularly Tasmania, Queensland and one other State, they were not going to cop anything less than that at the meeting of the Attorneys-General tomorrow.
—Pure speculation on your part.

—I happen to have had discussions about this matter and I know that they are not going to cop anything less, and the Attorney-General knew that so he gave the Democrats nothing, nothing that would not have been dealt with tomorrow at the meeting of the Attorneys-General. What is the other great gift of the Attorney-General to the Democrats for 'their lousy vote'?. Let us have a look at what the other one was. It is in effect to amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations by deleting the word 'extreme' contained in proposed regulation 1A (iii). That is all. Did honourable senators hear Senator Jack Evans get up here and say that the Democrats would not support the regulations as they now exist? He gave that undertaking to us. Although, of course, last night the Governor-General in Council amended these regulations to delete the word 'extreme', so presumably we will see the Democrats vote against the regulations; or will we?
—You have misrepresented the position.
—All right, so they are not. They are satisfied with that.
—We wanted the word 'extreme' out.
—The Democrats are satisfied with that, are they? I hope they are not satisfied with that.
—Aren't you satisfied that that is a step forward?
—No, I am not satisfied that that is a step forward because at the present moment, by law, Customs must send video tapes to the Chief Censor.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. As engaging and fascinating and informative as this contribution to the debate may be, may I suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that it has nothing to do with the timing, which is the subject of the amendment before the House at the moment.

—I have been listening with some concern to this debate, but because of the nature of the motion before us, which is that it should be brought on for urgent consideration, I have to allow debate on the importance of the change to be made, but I would ask honourable senators to be as brief as possible. Senator Harradine is in order.

—Mr Deputy President, it is of vital importance that this matter be determined today because what people do not seem to understand, and of course the Press has missed it altogether, is that unless we reject and disallow these amendments, for the first time-by courtesy of the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, and the Australian Democrats-the importation, sale and distribution of hard core pornography in this country will be legalised. Not only that but also, as Senator Lewis said, the question of blasphemy has been taken out too. Nobody has said anything about that. That is a matter which may be of concern to a lot of people in this country. I have not examined that situation carefully but at least the people of the nation ought to know that for the first time, by courtesy of the Attorney-General and the Australian Democrats -unless we disallow this ordinance now-we will have institutionalised in this country hard core pornography and extreme blasphemy.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the situation proposed by Senator Mason. Under the existing law-if it is enforced-this material can be kept out of the country. He has made a great deal of the deletion of the word 'extreme'. So what do we have? The only material that is not allowed legally into the country will be that depicting child pornography, terrorism and violence. I will be careful and quote this section; it concerns 'goods' which:
gratuitously depict in pictorial form violence or cruelty, especially when combined with any sexual element, to the extent they should not be imported . . .

That is the other leg of the con-'to the extent they should not be imported'. Who will decide that? The Attorney-General! He will decide that, so he has conned the Australian Democrats both ways. I feel very strongly about this because I thought that Senator Mason would give the Senate the opportunity to disallow this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has not been taken from you. The Senate is still able to look at the points you have made; all we are debating is the adjournment.
—Will the Australian Democrats consider what we have said when we come back to this matter and not agree out the back door to a fait accompli? If they will give that guarantee, I will sit down.
—I have taken your point.
—Right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jack Evans said in debating Senator Lewis's amendment that I had misrepresented the Australian Democrats' stand last night when I had said that the Democrats had backed down and that their vote had been bought by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. We will see how they vote today. Following Senator Mason's media release saying they would not vote for the disallowance today but would put it off until some time in the future because they had won certain points from the Attorney-General-and they took the kudos for doing that-I will be interested to see how they vote. To begin with, the Attorney-General has backed down on the compulsory section of the regulations. He was able to see that, on the numbers, he would lose on that anyway. That was part of the price paid. It is ludicrous and stupid, and typical of the Democrats, for them to say the Attorney-General backed down as a result of the Democrats' numbers. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that the Opposition has a few more numbers than the Democrats and without the Opposition' s assistance the Democrats could not do a darn thing. So for heaven's sake, they should not tell us that they accomplished this, because they did not. They did nothing about it. The Democrats have five votes, but there are also the numbers of the Liberal and National parties and Senator Harradine. So do not try to take your kudos from your five.
—Senator Walters, will you address your remarks to the Chair, please?
—Mr Deputy President, it is a bit irritating when a party with five votes tells us this action is as a result of its numbers.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I suggest that Senator Walters ought not only to address her remarks through the Chair but also ought to address them to the motion. So far she has not come within a bull' s roar of addressing herself to the timing, the importance or the urgency of the matter.
—Senator Walters, you must confine your remarks to the reason why the resumption of the debate should be at 12 noon rather than on 2 May.

—As I said, the Democrats have been proved to have been bought, to have changed their minds and they will not support the disallowance of the motion at midday today. The extreme urgency of this matter is obviously completely misunderstood by the Democrats. They have said that if they move today to have this legislation disallowed it will be open slather for people to circulate hard core pornography all around the country. What on earth do the Democrats think has been happening since 1 February when the Attorney-General brought in this regulation? Exactly that. It is because this hard core pornography has been circulating around the country we are moving for a disallowance today. The Democrats want to put this matter off until some time in the future, maybe May. If the disallowance does not take place we will have the present situation for another month. If the disallowance takes place we will go back to the law of the country as it stood before 1 February. The Attorney- General could enforce that law and we would not have the open slather that we have at present. It would continue to occur if he chose not to enforce the law.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that some of the hard core pornography will get through Customs. Pornography will always be able to be hidden and will always escape the Customs net. But that does not mean that it is legal. It does not mean that it can come into this country in a legal fashion and be sold in every video shop in an open way. It has had to be done in a clandestine way; now, of course, it is open slather. Senator Jack Evans also said-I think these were his words-that I would like to set the standards according to my own ideas. If he had bothered to read the speech I made yesterday on this matter he would know that I called upon the Attorney, to prove support for his proposal, he having previously said that all the Australian people were behind him and wanted this-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters, you must not resume the debate. The motion is purely concerned with the timing of the resumption.
—No, I am not. I am expressing the urgency of this matter. I said to the Attorney-General: 'Find out before you do this'. I will read my comments from Hansard. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Attorney-General whether he has any evidence at all that suggests that the Australian people support the expansion of the range of hard core pornography available in this country. The range has been expanded to include X rates or Category 2 material.

I asked the Attorney-General to find out from the people of the country whether they agree with him before he opens up the regulations, as indeed they will be opened up if we do not disallow this motion today. I am quite sure they will not agree with him. I am interested to see whether the Attorney-General will find out. Senator Jack Evans was incorrect when he said that I was putting up my ideas in this regard as the ones to be adopted. I asked Senator Evans to find out what the people of this country wanted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. We have the interesting situation where the debate on this motion has been overtaken by the clock. I seek your ruling on the point that the debate be resumed at 12 o'clock. It is now 12 o'clock.

—Order! This situation has arisen before. A motion for the resumption of a debate at 12 noon, in accordance with practice, is interpreted as meaning at 12 noon or as near thereto as possible. In the past debate has been permitted to continue past the time mentioned in the motion, and I so rule on this occasion.

—Sentor Mason said that one of his great victories in this matter was making compulsory the seeking of a classification of this sort of material. I believe that the Opposition was responsible for extracting from the Government that compulsory element. I come now to deal with material depicting extreme violence. If the Attorney-General removes the word 'extreme' what does that leave us? Will it mean that no material depicting violence will be able to come into the country?
—But that is forbidden entry. Those are things that cannot come in .
—I am well aware of that, Senator Mason. Will it mean that material that depicts no violence at all can come into the country?
—In those terms.
—In those terms.
—Order! I ask Sentor Walters not to respond to interjections.

—It will be interesting to see whether Senator Jack Evans sticks to that ruling of excluding material depicting extreme violence so that no material depicting any violence at all can come into the country. I have a feeling that he will come up with a different set of words rather than simply removing the word 'extreme'. It will be interesting to see whether he does. I shall take the Senate's time for only a couple of minutes more. The Classification of Publications Ordinance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, where the Censorship Board decides that a film-

(a) depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a manner that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person; or
(b) is unsuitable for the viewing of a minor,
the Board shall approve the classification of the film . . .

However, that approval will be on a restricted basis. So we have the situation where the Censorship Board can allow in on a restricted basis material that is revolting or abhorrent in such a manner that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person. The Attorney-General said that if material is revolting or abhorrent it will be allowed into the country but it will be given an X- rating. However, he says that material will not be let in if it offends against standards of morality, decency and propriety. What on earth is the Attorney- General talking about? If it is revolting and abhorrent and causes offence to a reasonable adult person, he will let it into the country anyway. But if it offends against standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by a reasonable adult person, he will not let it in. I really do not understand what the Attorney-General is talking about, and I am darned sure that the rest of the Australian community does not understand what he is talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he does.

—Yes, he does. He sees a big difference between something that is revolting and abhorrent and something that offends against standards of morality, decency and propriety. The Australian Democrats also see the difference between those two things. They are willing to allow all this sort of stuff to flood into the country and to be available to the Australian population for the next month or so. Indeed, the Australian Democrats have backtracked. They have let us down badly. They have done a deal. They have been bought. Senator Evans said in his speech, 'If that is what it takes to buy your lousy vote, I will do it'. That shows the sincerity of the Attorney-General of this country.
—And he did it yesterday, what is more.

—He bought the vote of the Australian Democrats. As Senator Mason said, he did it yesterday. This is the sort of language and sincerity we have in this place from the Attorney-General of Australia. The Opposition will not have a bar of that sort of sincerity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply wish to indicate briefly that the Opposition will support the amendment moved by Senator Lewis. That motion seeks to bring on the debate on this matter at 12 o'clock today, but since it is now after 12 o'clock it will be at a later hour this day. If Senator Lewis's amendment is carried it will mean that the debate will continue as soon as this matter is resolved by the Senate. As Senator Lewis has already explained , the Australian Democrats seem to be under a very severe misapprehension as to what the effect of disallowing these regulations will mean. In fact, the effect of that disallowance would be that the old regulations would be revived. As I pointed out in my speech yesterday, there are a number of other laws in this country which, if enforced and administered by the States, would be able to deal with the sort of material we are talking about. Those laws would not be able to deal with that material in a totally satisfactory way, but certainly no hiatus would be created simply by disallowing these regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats brought forward the motion seeking to disallow the regulations. When they did that they must have been aware of the situation that would arise if they succeeded in that endeavour. Yet now they are using as an argument against their own motion the effect that disallowing the regulations would have. They have adopted a completely illogical position in relation to this matter. They have done a complete U-turn in relation to their attitude to these regulations. They are satisfied with one miserable amendment that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) rushed through yesterday in order, as he said, to buy their lousy little vote. Yesterday the Attorney-General rushed through an amendment to these regulations. Have honourable senators ever seen anything more pathetic than an Attorney-General or a government in the course of a debate in this chamber rushing out to Government House for the purpose of making an amendment to their own regulations, regulations which the Attorney- General believed were a great bellwether for the new scheme in relation to which he thought he had the agreement of the States?

Senator Harradine and other honourable senators have made it perfectly clear that as a result of the Attorney-General rushing ahead in bull-at-a-gate fashion and bringing down regulations at the federal level the matter is now a complete mess. He rushed through those regulations before the States had brought in their own complementary legislation, before the States had set up their new administration, before most States had made a decision about whether this material would be classified by the Censorship Board or by their own offices. A vacuum has been created as a result of the Attorney-General rushing ahead and bringing in these regulations before complementary State legislation was introduced. I have always admitted that the previous laws were not entirely satisfactory. When I was Attorney-General the Government of the day had commenced consideration of the matter and had sought Commonwealth-State agreement in relation to it. I fully acknowledge that obtaining Commonwealth- State agreement is the desirable course to follow. But we now have the worst of all worlds. A vacuum has been created at the federal level by these regulations, because whatever controls existed at the federal level have been virtually removed by the introduction of these regulations and by the fact that Customs officers have been given new instructions virtually to turn a blind eye to all of this sort of material.

TALK.START.PARA: —You knew how effective the system was under you. You know how effective it was.

—Senator Evans knows that new instructions have been given to the Customs officers about how these new regulations are to be administered. He has said himself that very little material would be prohibited under the new regulations.
—To bring them more into line with long-standing practice and you know it.

—The Attorney believes that very little material will be prohibited under these regulations. A flood of this material has come into the country. It has come in because of those regulations and because of the attitudes and policies of the Attorney-General which he is pursuing ahead of the establishment of any effective alternatives to the present laws. That is the immediate problem. That is why these regulations should be disallowed today. Then, when the Attorney-General meets with others Ministers responsible for censorship matters tomorrow-not all are State Attorneys-General-they will know clearly where this Senate stands in relation to the matter. They will then have a clear direction that they have to think again and come up with something much more satisfactory than they have so far. We will strongly support the move to have this debate continue and conclude and an attempt being made today by the Senate to disallow these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I will only take a minute of the Senate' s time to say that I am appalled at the ignorance of the Australian Democrats in denying the right of Senator Lewis to put his part in what is a most important motion. We have had many examples from the Democrats that they do not understand they have been conned by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). There would be very few people whom the Attorney-General could con in this place, but the Democrats seem to have been. At present the Senate is considering a very important issue. That is why Senator Lewis is so urgently seeking to be heard on the matter, which is his right.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember the time when I first became a member of the Senate. At that time the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Country Party of Australia had a majority in the Senate; they had the numbers to say what went in this chamber. After I had been bored to tedium beyond expression by a member of the Australian Labor Party talking about something, I said to one of my colleagues in the Liberal Party who was sitting beside me: 'Isn't it time we moved to close off the debate?' and he replied: 'I have been here for a long time, and it is the right of everyone in the Senate to be heard. It is not a senator's right to be agreed with but it is a senator's right to be heard'. The Democrats have never learned that. I never expected the Labor Party, with its totalitarian, jack- booted approach to socialism to have those ethics, but I thought the Democrats, with their talk about fairness and justice in the community, might recognise the fundamental right of a senator to be heard in this chamber. It would be more appropriate if they were down in the House of Representatives, because they have that sort of mentality.

The reason Senator Lewis must be heard is that there are no barriers under this Attorney-General's regulations to the importation of hard core pornography other than child pornography and publications which incite terrorism and publication containing extreme violence and/or sexual violence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not extreme. The law has been changed-last night.

—My apologies. We will leave out 'extreme'; we are just fooling with words. It really has no relevance to the subject before us, which is the importance of hearing Senator Lewis. The only buttress we have against this apparently is the judgment of the Attorney-General, a judgment that is so bad that his own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is publicly ridiculing him before meetings in this country; the judgment of a man who, it is rumoured, will be shortly removed and replaced by another Attorney-General, a man who, when Senator Reid pointed out that Canberra has brothels and that brothels are against the law, interjected: 'I haven't had enough complaints'.
—Senator MacGibbon, you are getting rather wide of the point of why this debate should continue. Come back to the issue please.

—Mr Deputy President, I take your point. The urgency of hearing Senator Lewis's case is that we have to rely on the judgment of this man , the highest law officer in the country, whose basic approach to law is that it is not what the law says that is the determinant of action, but the number of protests about the law being broken. On those grounds I state that Senator Lewis should be heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the amendment moved by Senator Lewis. There is patently an urgency that this debate should continue and the motion be put to the vote. Indeed, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated that it is important that the Senate debate and the expression of the Senate should be made known to the State Ministers when they meet tomorrow. I ask the Attorney-General, as a matter of imperative need, to ensure that the Hansard of the whole debate be made available for perusal by the State Ministers before they reach their conclusions.
—What were we doing all day yesterday? There was a cognate debate all day yesterday.

—The Attorney-General asks, by way of interjection: ' What were we doing all day yesterday?' All day yesterday we were under the impression, which was clearly given by the Attorney-General and the Whip to me, that we would have a full debate and that we would vote on the issue. So we know what we were doing yesterday; we were debating an important subject that had an urgency to it, an urgency which is implicit in Senator Lewis's amendment, that the expression of the Senate should be given to the State Ministers. There is now even more urgency because the debate has opened up a series of problems far wider than the two hasty clandestine amendments that were sneaked in last night by the Attorney-General.
—There was only one and it was not clandestine. It was the most open exchange of views we have had in a long time.

—On the contrary, at no stage yesterday did the Attorney-General have the courtesy to inform the Senate in a debate that was proceeding that he intended to take steps which would be imperative to the substance of the debate. That was a grave and gross discourtesy to this chamber. Let it be known: The amendment was certainly clandestine; nothing else. If there is a duty of a Minister to this chamber it is to respect the substance of the debate. To do something that is an insult to this chamber is, of course, part of the pattern and par for the course. To now say that there is no need to have a continuation of the debate and no need to put the matter to a vote is to imply that State Ministers are to draw a conclusion that the Senate is satisfied by the expedient amendments of last night. Fundamentally, the debate itself could not have shown in any way that by those two steps, whatever their merits, that is so. I give an example of that because I want to direct myself purely to the urgency aspect and not to the substance.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that was implicit throughout the debate was a statement by the Attorney-General that there would be some absolute values and sanctions, and that a line would be drawn in a particular place. But the public outside had been arguing that the line might be drawn somewhere else; that, in fact, this is a wider and much more important subject. I wonder whether the Attorney-General and Senator Mason are interested in rejecting, for example, the views of a body called the New South Wales Women's Advisory Council. That body was set up by Mr Wran. It is scarcely some kind of prudish body; scarcely some body that is not representative of people. That body said fundamentally one thing; that the categories excluded were not good enough by far. The Council did not direct itself only to the word 'extreme' in terms of extreme violence. The Council said that material showing 'sexually explicit subordination of women, including showing women as things, commodities or objects' ought to be excluded. That is a pretty important kind of subject, is it not? What is happening is that the Senate is being invited to say to the Ministers meeting tomorrow: 'We have tidied this up. We had a debate and a couple of factors emerged'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Back to the Middle Ages.

—Including a very garrulous Attorney-General, who is in retreat as always. We have tidied it up in terms of the word 'extreme' and in terms of making something compulsory. But, fundamentally, making a category compulsory does not enforce it. Indeed it does not get to the very heart of this .

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Government doing to prevent video tapes, which parents would reject as inappropriate for juveniles, getting into the hands of those juveniles through corrupt measures? Nothing has happened. That is the very essence-the very guts, to use an Australianism-of the debate. Nothing has been resolved. The Australian Democrats can take no pride in this because they have failed to get to the important point: How do we protect juveniles in this situation? Secondly, how do we draw the line between what should and should not be excluded? Thirdly, how do we enforce those decisions? None of those questions has been asked or answered. In order to get what looks like an expedient result to save the face of the Attorney-General, there has been a compact between them to close the debate. It is a disgraceful tactic on the part of Senator Mason and his people. Let it be said that throughout the whole of this debate they have not directed themselves to the substance of the material. They are now, by a form of larrikinism, trying to force the people of Australia to believe that what they have done is good and wholesome and solves the problem. It does nothing of the kind. There is an urgency today that we express to the State Ministers tomorrow the grave concern of the Senate not only about the word 'extreme', not only about the compulsory or voluntary methods, but also about the whole range of matters. By this device of adjourning, the Democrats are trying to exclude that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to pre-empt that meeting?

—Senator Mason, in one of his usual inane interjections , said: 'Do you want to pre-empt that meeting?' He asks that now. The fact is that what we want to do is to bring the views of the Senate to that meeting. Do the Democrats not want to bring the collective views of the Senate to that meeting? Do they want to pre-empt a situation in which that is so? Let me test this. I will ask the Attorney-General to give an assurance to the Senate that the whole of the transcript of this debate be made available to the State Ministers in time for them to read it before they actually come to their deliberations. I ask him to acknowledge that that will be done. I hope I do not have to take procedures in this place to see that it is done. Could I have his assurance on this?
—Certainly. No problem. I have already made arrangements for yesterday's Hansard. Whether they will get today's in time I do not know.

—The Attorney-General will acknowledge that to this point in the debate I have tried to keep the substance of this debate non- combative. It is a great pity indeed that the intervention of the Democrats has made it into a form of warfare. They can take no credit for this. What was a very important debate on human values which was imperative to the understanding of the State Ministers tomorrow-it should not have been a debate on a word or two words but a whole debate on the philosophy of human values which was to be expressed to the State Ministers-has been denied to the Ministers by the action of the Democrats. When they vote against this amendment, it does not get them off the hook. They have not solved the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim was to have the status quo restored until a new situation had been developed. It is the normal practice of a parliament, and the Democrats must know this, that when something is being challenged, when it is shown to have grave defects as this has been shown to have grave defects, one resorts to the status quo while the new initiative is planned and implemented. What is happening is that instead the Democrats have refused to do that. They have taken part in a snide arrangement resulting in a patched-up situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still under review.

—Here is another interjection from Senator Mason. My goodness, the brain fever birds are busy in this community. Those who know the habits of the brain fever birds can understand how the Democrats get their candidates. Senator Mason, by interjection, said: 'The fact is that it is still under review'. How much more important is it that the yeasting should have been allowed to go on, that the problems that still remain should be brought to the surface and a message sent to the Ministers? But no, none of the yeasting, none of the bringing out of the other points is allowed because the gag will be applied.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the clear understanding of the Democrats, given and accepted in good faith, was that this debate would proceed to a conclusion, there would be a vote and the expression of that vote would be conveyed to the State Ministers. Let this be on the heads of the Democrats. At least the Attorney- General has given an undertaking, and I respect it, that the transcripts will be made available to the Ministers so that they will have an understanding of it. Let it be understood by those Ministers that the Senate is far from satisfied that what happened last night is in any way an approach to the totality of this subject. It is looking at pimples and not looking at the body politic itself. In my judgment, the action of the Democrats is a disgrace. I therefore support Senator Lewis's amendment. (Quorum formed)

That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Lewis's amendment) be left out.

DEBATE.TITLE: TORRES STRAIT TREATY (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984TORRES STRAIT FISHERIES BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 April, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Torres Strait Treaty ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1984 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill 1984 deal with a very complicated subject and, as such, unfortunately are somewhat complicated. However, they certainly deal with a matter which is of very great importance to relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea and to Federal- State relations particularly in relation to Queensland. The Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1984 implements the Torres Strait Treaty of 1978 which was made between Australia and Papua New Guinea as a result of very extensive discussions that the Commonwealth Government had with Queensland. The Torres Strait Fisheries Bill implements arrangements made under the Treaty in regard to the administration of what is known as a protective zone and the establishment of a protected zone joint authority. I will have something to say about the details of that fisheries legislation at a later point in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The determination of the boundary between Australia and Papua New Guinea has had a very long history. In 1879 the islands lying to the south of Papua New Guinea were annexed by the then colony of Queensland. A line was drawn roughly between the coastline of Papua and the islands to its south, notably the islands known as Boigu, Saibai and Dauan. Their northern coastlines lie within three miles of the Papuan mainland. In 1972 the Whitlam Government opened negotiations with Papua New Guinea and there were also discussions with Queensland in relation to the problem. By that time the islands had become inhabited by persons who were Australian citizens but who crossed the narrow straits to fish and farm on the mainland. Equally, Papua New Guinean citizens travelled freely into Australian territory. At one stage the Whitlam Government sought to remove the matter to the International Court of Justice. Fortunately, that was not necessary. Negotiations commenced and were greatly hastened by the proposition of an environmental zone to cover this area.

In 1974 the Queensland Parliament passed a motion calling on the Commonwealth to establish a marine park in the area. In all events, after the Fraser Government was elected and particularly due to the enthusiasm and a great deal of attention given to this project by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Andrew Peacock, the present Leader of the Opposition, a treaty resulted in 1978. The major feature of the treaty is the delineation of a clear border between Papua New Guinea and Australia, the median line being drawn between Papua New Guinea and the islands of Boigu, Dauan and Saibai. This line in fact is a little to the south of the earlier 1879 line to which I referred.

I also mention that a protected zone is to be established, the boundary of which will encircle the area from the north of the Thursday Island group to the islands off the Papua New Guinea mainland. The Torres Strait Islanders and coastal Papuans will be allowed to travel without restriction in this protected zone. As I said, there were separate negotiations between Papua New Guinea and Australia in relation to shared rights in this zone. A separate fisheries jurisdiction line is identical with the seabed line except in the Torres Strait area in the protected zone where it is drawn to include the islands of Boigu, Dauan and Saibai. But concessions had to be made in order to obtain a sensible balance between the rights of Papua New Guinea and those of Australia. If every island in the Torres Strait owned by Australia were given a territorial sea of 12 miles, the fishing rights of Papua New Guinea would virtually have been extinguished. So the islands did not extend the territorial sea beyond three miles and the fishing jurisdiction line is designed to restore rights to the islands which were lost to them in the decision to hold to a three-mile territorial sea. The fishing administrations of both countries are involved in balancing the conservation of species on which the traditional fishermen depend for a subsistence livelihood with the requirements of commercial fishermen.

The administration of the conservation aspect will certainly present problems. The legislation empowers the Minister for Primary Industry to regulate commercial fishing by prohibition of certain activities; setting legal minimum or maximum lengths of fish; prohibition on the use of certain equipment; reserving certain fisheries for the local community and so forth. Australia must co-ordinate its arrangements with those of Papua New Guinea if the zone arrangements are to work for the purpose of conservation objects. Moreover, the Australian position has to be co-ordinated between the Commonwealth and the State of Queensland. A joint Commonwealth-State authority will administer the policies to ensure a co-ordinated approach. The main aim is to keep the condition of fisheries under review and to formulate forward policies and plans.

What has been worked out, however, between the Commonwealth and the State of Queensland and between Australia and Papua New Guinea is a very great tribute to the process of negotiation and consultation. As I said, this work was put in place by the Fraser Government, particularly during the period that Mr Peacock was Foreign Minister. It is a very important example of the capacity of those who have the will to achieve co-operative federalism to work both at a State level and, of course, on an international plane.

The Opposition is clearly in support of both these measures. I will move an amendment at the Committee stage to the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill 1984 but I do not propose to detain the Senate with details of that kind during this second reading debate. As I said, the Opposition is happy to support both Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1984 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill 1984. We are very happy to see that, with the passage of the Bills, Australia will at least be able to ratify the 1978 Torres Strait Treaty. We have been impressed, having read the Bills, by the complexity of the task in preparing this legislation to complement the treaty. Finding consensus positions is never easy in such diverse matters. We can certainly find nothing in these Bills with which to disagree. I congratulate the Government on the legislation and look forward to similar legislation being introduced by the governments of Papua New Guinea and Queensland. As I said before, the Australian Democrats will be voting in favour of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Senate for its support and I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1983-84 provides the opportunity for some consideration to be given to one of the major problems that confront Australia today and that is the plight of the Australian manufacturing industry. All honourable senators will be aware of the massive decline of the manufacturing sector over the last 20 years. Honourable senators with an interest in manufacturing will also know that the lack of considered community discussion on this subject is a matter of concern. Unfortunately, a change in methods used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics means that figures before and after 1968 are not comparable and because of this detailed analysis largely has to be limited to the last 15 or 16 years. Unfortunately, they are not a very happy 15 or 16 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The statistics group of the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library has at my request compiled a table which demonstrates how the manufacturing sector fared in the period 1968-69 to 1981-82. I will seek leave to have that tabled incorporated in Hansard subsequently. One of the things that is revealed in the table is a decline in employment in the manufacturing sector. In 1968-69 the manufacturing sector employed an average of 1,264,037 Australians . This meant that more than one in every four working Australians were employed in manufacturing. In 1981-82 the manufacturing sector employed an average of 1, 154,659 Australians, approximately 110,000 jobs fewer than in 1968-69. Thus, in 1981-82 one in five Australians were employed in the manufacturing industry.

Those who are more concerned about money than people should also take note of the share of gross domestic product contributed by manufacturing. It dropped from 27.2 per cent in 1968 to 20.2 per cent in 1981-82. As bad as all these figures sound they do not include the massive shake out that took place in the second half of the calendar year 1982. The magazine Australian Business reported that in the 12 months to October 1983, last year, 93,000 jobs were lost in the manufacturing sector. That means that employment in manufacturing contracted to around 16.5 per cent of the work force by October last year. Approximately one in every six Australian workers therefore is employed in manufacturing.

Of some importance is the fact that Australian Business also reported last October that the idle capacity in manufacturing was at an all time record level. Fortunately, the situation is changing but it has to be of great concern. It is quite obvious that to a very large degree this crisis in manufacturing was directly associated with the large jump in unemployment in Australia in the second half of 1982. Of course, these matters spell bad news for all Australians . An economy with high levels of idle productive capacity and unemployment is an unhealthy economy. The Hawke Government has taken a whole series of decisions in attempting to turn round the situation that we inherited a little over a year ago. I remind honourable senators and you, Mr President, that the dole is, at $ 73.50, well below the poverty line. On that kind of income the struggle for basic acommodation, food and clothing is demoralising and debilitating. The most prudent individuals in that situation face such a rapid decline in their savings that they will take a great time to recover even when they gain employment. Clearly, the two problems, the manufacturing crisis and unemployment, create a mutually reinforcing dilemma.

The consumption of goods and services and the health of the manufacturing sector depend largely on the level of disposable income in the hands of ordinary Australians. When a significant proportion of Australians are unemployed and their disposable income is drastically reduced, consumption, or demand as the economists would refer to it, must be adversely affected. However, in the last few months there has been an upturn in the economy that the Hawke Government can claim so much credit for. The Bureau of Statistics reported on 27 February that there had been an increase in production across almost all the manufacturing sector in the last three months. This follows the pick-up in retail sales in the final quarter of last year.

Whilst this undoubtedly reflects in part the breaking of the drought and perhaps to a lesser extent the important developments in the United States economy, the simple position is that two policies of the Labor Government have laid the basis for the increase in demand. The first is the implicit development of the 1983 Budget and, of course, the fillip to the economy that that Budget caused and the second is the rejection of the Fraser wage freeze and the reintroduction of wage indexation. Yesterday's decision means that there will be more money in the pockets of wage and salary earners. Disposable income will increase and this will assist the mass consumption and production that society depends on.

I believe that full indexation ensures the maintenance of demand for goods and services. Without indexation, of course, and if we were to accept the piecemeal policy that the Opposition seems to be wedded to, we would lose the stimulus to the economy that yesterday's decision will finally mean. Despite the recent improvement, however, unemployment remains at an unacceptable high of 9.4 per cent. Getting back to the manufacturing industry I think that to put it in perspective, we have to compare the sectors of the economy, and look at the agricultural and mining sections. In those sections 7.5 per cent of the work force is unemployed. Any increase in mining or agriculture will certainly not significantly reduce unemployment. Of course, I have always taken the view that Australia cannot afford to be a mine or quarry and that if we follow that path we will become a Third World country. That is the reason why I put so much emphasis on the revitalisation of the manufacturing sector. It is the productive engine of the economy and as a nation we must be determined to revitalise the manufacturing sector in order to revitalise the Australian economy. This Government is doing that but I express concern with the general decline in the manufacturing industry over the 16 years to which I have referred.

I refer to an industry that I have had some experience with, the printing and paper industry and kindred trades. The printing industry is a significant industry. It is the same size as the fabricated metal segment of the metal industry. The statistics group of the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library has compiled at my request, a table which shows how the printing, paper and allied industries fared between 1968-69 and 1981-82. I will seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard at the conclusion of my speech. The table shows that there has been a loss of some 5,000 jobs in the paper industry in the period to which I have referred. In contrast, employment increased by some 6,000 in the printing sector, giving a relative balance to the whole industry. Again, however, the Bureau of Statistics' figures on which this table is based do not include the period from July 1982. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has estimated that employment in the printing, paper and allied industries has decreased by some 10,000 since November 1980. Clearly this parallels the decline in employment in the manufacturing industry generally. The figure of 10,000 represents a decline of 8 .7 per cent in employment in printing.

Two factors have a major impact on the printing industry. They are typical of the problem in manufacturing industry generally. The first of these is the trend towards taking printing off-shore. I give this particular emphasis because it is a great threat to the printing industry. In 1980-81, $286m worth of printing products were imported into Australia. This amount rose by 11 per cent in 1981- 82 to $318m. In the last financial year, 1982-83, imports of printed products into Australia rose by 13 per cent to $360m.

Much of this off-shore printing is being done in countries such as Singapore and Hong Kong, both of which receive preferential treatment in relation to tariffs because they are classified as developing countries. Yet multinational corporations have injected large amounts of capital into printing operations in these countries to ensure that they are equipped with the most up-to-date machinery. This means that Australian printing workers are competing against workers in Singapore and Hong Kong. Those non-unionised workers are paid between 20 per cent and 25 per cent of the wages of their counterparts. It is no wonder that they can sometimes print more cheaply.

In response to these developments, the printing employees and the Printing and Kindred Industries Union have combined to support a campaign to keep printing in Australia. I speak partly today in support of this campaign. The printing employers organisations and the Printing and Kindred Industries Union realise that they have to take this step for the health of their own industry. They believe that if the $360m in off-shore printing were done in Australia it would produce 12,500 jobs for Australians. Part of the recovery we so much need would be achieved by this.

I referred to the factors which have a major impact on printing in Australia. I have indicated that the first is off-shore printing. In the very short time I have left I will refer to technological change. It is another factor that has affected the printing industry in leaps and bounds as it has affected other parts of manufacturing. I do not have time to develop the argument about technological change because I want to refer to some research that was compiled by the Bureau of Industry Economics. It indicates that the labour co-efficient will drop by half in the printing industry between 1979 and 1990. I have indicated the rate of change in the printing industry which is reflective of the rate of decline in employment in manufacturing industry generally. It is of great concern that, if the estimate is correct, employment in the printing industry will decline by 50 per cent, and only half the number of people will be required to produce the same output. Alternatively, if employment is to be preserved in the printing industry, it will be necessary to increase its production by 100 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Townley has agreed for me to precede him in this debate and I thank him for that. I use the opportunity of the first reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1983-84 to highlight some points with respect to the nuclear industry. Of course, this subject is of great significance to Australia and has been the subject of many debates in the Senate chamber over the last year or so. It seems that a lot of the debate hinges on whether there is a demand in the world at the moment for our uranium and a lot of debate has surrounded the motive argument of how to deal with radioactive waste. Later I would like to incorporate in Hansard some facts associated with the disposal of high level radioactive waste.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that the Press is at last recognising intelligently some of the points that members of the Opposition have been trying to make with respect to the significance of the nuclear industry and our capacity to provide resources for the rest of the world. In the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday there was an interesting article headed 'Asia on the nuclear high road'. The article was written by Michael Richardson, reporting from Singapore. The first paragraph states:

As Australian unions and the ALP agonise over whether to permit full-scale uranium mining and export, the list of Asian nations committed to using nuclear power to generate electricity is growing steadily longer.

The article goes on to demonstrate how the expansion of electricity production through nuclear power stations is going on in that part of the world. Rather than waste time quoting from that article I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Asia on the nuclear high road

As Australian unions and the ALP agonise over whether to permit full-scale uranium mining and export, the list of Asian nations committed to using nuclear power to generate electricity is growing steadily longer. Michael Richardson reports from Singapore.

One newcomer, Vietnam, put its name on the nuclear energy roll-call last month. Two others, Indonesia and China, confirmed their intention to take the atomic route, and Malaysia announced it would build a nuclear research reactor with help from Pakistan.
Many parts of Asia are going nuclear, whether Australia likes it or not.
The question the Labor movement must decide is whether Australia will exploit its valuable uranium resources and exercise some influence over the course of events.

Although the nuclear power industry has been bedevilled in recent years by controversy over safety and high capital costs in a number of Western countries, many Asian nations see it as essential for their future economic health and independence.

In Asia, planners have been looking at the experience of Japan and two other rapidly industrialising countries in the region, South Korea and Taiwan, where nuclear power so far has proven to be cost-efficient and relatively trouble-free .
Japan, the only country ever attacked with atomic weapons, has managed to contain public anxieties about nuclear power since the first commercial reactor went into operation in 1966.

It now has 24 nuclear plants putting electricity into the national grid, 13 under construction and seven more planned. The atom generates 19 per cent of the country's electricity and the target for 1990 is 27 per cent.

Japan which imports nearly all its oil and more than 83 per cent of its coal, has found that a kilowatt of nuclear energy costs 5.2 US cents, compared with 5. 8 cents for the same amount of electricity generated by coal and 7.3 cents for power from oil.
South Korea's three nuclear power plants provide about 17 per cent of national electricity needs.
Six more plants are due to come on stream by 1989 and will lift the nuclear share to 47 per cent.
Taiwan has four atomic stations providing 40 per cent of total electricity generated.

As Asia goes nuclear, three principle concerns are emerging within the region and outside: operational safety standards, disposal of spent fuel rods and dangerous by-products, and whether development of nuclear power for electricity generation will provide the means, and perhaps the inducement, to produce nuclear weapons, triggering a new and even more dangerous version of the arms race.
NUCLEAR POWER: THE ASIAN VIEW
South Asia may be on the threshold of just that kind of nuclear rivalry.
India and Pakistan, which have fought three wars since British colonial rule ended and the subcontinent was divided in 1947, have both got nuclear power stations producing electricity.
India has four plants which provide 3 per cent of electricity output and one more station is being built, with eight on the drawing boards.
Pakistan has two nuclear plants, but they provide less than 1 per cent of electricity generated.
But neither India nor Pakistan has signed the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty, which binds signatories not to manufacture nuclear weapons.
And both countries have moved beyond using nuclear power for producing electricity and have begun to scramble higher up the nuclear ladder.
India exploded a nuclear devise in 1974, but insists its atomic program is entirely peaceful.
In February last year New Delhi denied US reports that it had started stockpiling plutonium suitable for use in nuclear bombs.

Vietnam announced on 19 March that it would build nuclear power plants to generate electricity, a move likely to worry its arch-rival China and some of its non-communist neighbours in South-East Asia, which fear that it will give Hanoi the ability to develop nuclear weapons.

Vietnam said it had put its first nuclear research reactor into operation with Soviet assistance. It said the 500-kilowatt reactor, in Dalat in the central highlands province of Am Dong would be used to train personnel ''for the country 's future nuclear power generation program, analysing mineral or biological samples and producing necessary isotopes for medical and agricultural research institutions''.

Vietnam's announcement coincided with a similar statement in Indonesia, where a new 30-megawatt research reactor, designed by a West German company, is being built at Serpong, 25 kilometres south-west of Jakarata.

At the same time, a spokeswoman for the Energy Ministry in Manila confirmed that the Philippines which is heavily dependent on imported oil, is preparing to bring South-East Asia's first commercial nuclear power plant into full operation early next year.
The big 620-megawatt station, nearing completion at Morong on the Bataan Peninsula north-west of Manila, will provide about 16 per cent of the nation's electricity.
Indonesia-which has abundant supplies of oil, natural gas, coal and probably uranium-already has two small atomic research reactors in the cities of Bandung and Jogjakarta.

The 30-megawatt Serpong reactor is due to become fully operational in 1987 and official spokesmen have said in the past that the Government would wait until then before deciding whether to launch a nuclear power program.

However, President Soeharto was quoted last December by the official Antara news agency as saying Indonesia would need nuclear energy to provide power for future industrial development and should not become over-reliant on oil for future energy needs.

Both Indonesia and the Philippines have ratified the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty (NPT) and agreed to allow all their nuclear facilities to be inspected by the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).
So has Malaysia.
The agency was set up in 1957 to promote peaceful use of nuclear energy and prevent its diversion for military purposes.
Spent fuel from nuclear plants and research reactors contain by-products, including plutonium, which can be used to provide the massive explosive power of nuclear weapons.
Eight kilograms of plutonium 239 would be enough to make an atomic bomb as powerful as that which devastated the Japanese city of Nagasaki at the end of World War II.

More than 110 of the 158 members of the United Nations adhere to the non- proliferation treaty. Japan, South Korea and Taiwan have all ratified the NPT, and Vietnam has signed a safeguards agreement with the IAEA.
But China has refused to sign the NPT, on much the same grounds as India and Pakistan: that it discriminates unfairly between members of the original nuclear weapons club and other countries.
China has built and tested nuclear weapons but does not yet have any nuclear power stations in operation.

But Vice-Premier Li Peng, in a report on energy development to the people's consultative conference in Peking last month, said two nuclear plants would be built by 1985 and another two between 1986 and 1990.

Construction had already begun on a 300-megawatt plant in Qinshan, Zhejiang province, and preparatory work had started on a 1,800-megawatt pressurised water reactor station at Daya Bay in Guangdong, which is being planned in co- ordination with nearby Hong Kong.
Mr Li said China would set up a national safety supervisory committee and adopt strict protective measures for peaceful use of nuclear energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —An article in today's Australian was written by Mr Leslie Kemeny who is a senior lecturer in nuclear engineering at the University of New South Wales. The article commences:

SPEECH.PARA: At the beginning of 1984, Australia stands at the crossroads in respect of its full scale development of the uranium mining industry and its potential involvement in other aspects of the global nuclear fuel cycle.
I seek leave for that article to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIA STANDING AT NUCLEAR CROSSROADS
By Leslie Kemeny

At the beginning of 1984, Australia stands at the crossroads in respect of its full scale development of the uranium mining industry and its potential involvement in other aspects of the global nuclear fuel cycle.

With proven economically recoverable uranium resources which are possibly the greatest in the western world and the possibility of effective market penetration to meet the energy requirements of our industralised trading partners over the next four decades, the Australian producers are confronted with enormous challenges and opportunities.

Unfortunately, the imponderable and unpredictable socio-political interferences of successive Australian governments with both the free market forces and the informed realism of technologists, economists and industrialists could adversely affect the industry.
Unless care and discernment is exercised by our elected decision makers, Australia's reputation as a responsible and reliable supplier of a valuable fuel could suffer irreparable damage.

The Hawke Government's recently announced willingness to modify the Labor Party 's official platform on uranium mining has, so far, enabled two existing major producers to fulfil contractural obligations and a third major producer has been able to take first steps to enter the market place.
Senator Walsh, Minister for Resources and Energy, now appears prepared to recommend even further steps to expedite the growth of the industry.
Competition
However, the socio-political implications of a Federal Government and a Caucus divided on nuclear energy issues has already created tremendous problems in State-Commonwealth relationships.
Antagonisms now exist between Canberra and State governments, which completely transcend party political affiliations.

A typical example of this is in the Northern Territory, where both Labor and Liberal parties, the Aboriginal people and the Northern Land Council wish to see uranium mining proceed post haste at Jabiluka (Pancontinental Mines) and Koongarra (Dennison Mines).
The declaration of Stage II of Kakadu National Park is seen by many as a blatant example of political expediency.

The commonly held view, supported by professional ecologists and State legislators, is that the two projects should be allowed to proceed in their approved mining lease ''corridors''. Their impact on the environment would be minimal, in no way negating the tourist potential of the area.
It is further recognised that the economic benefits to Aboriginal people, the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth Government of these two projects would be enormous.

Meanwhile, Australia's giant South-East Asian neighbours-designated patronisingly as ''Third World'' or ''developing'' countries-have all but eclipsed Australia in their practical development of nuclear power technology and their commitment to the peaceful use of the nuclear fuel cycle for base-load energy production.
Within two decades, it is possible that Australia will have regressed to a position of being the poor, under-developed country of the Pacific Basin.

All the buzz words of ''technological innovation'' and ''sunrise industries'' will become meaningless as we face the competition of cheap labor, plentiful and cheap energy and the aspiration for develpment shown by the ASEAN countries, China, South Korea, Taiwan, the countries of the Indian subcontinent and, in particular, our nearest neighbor, Indonesia. These countries represent over half the world's population.

Recently, in China, I was a guest of the Ministry for Nuclear Industry and had the opportunity to visit many nuclear installations, to lecture and to take part in high-level discussions concerning China's nuclear power program.
Construction
At the Southwest Reactor Institute, near Chengdu, Sichuan Province, I was amazed to see a 125mW engineering test reactor of Chinese design.
This facility will assist in the design and construction of two small power reactors in the Shanghai area, one for electricity production and the other to supply steam to the Shanghai Chemical Works.

I was informed that negotiations were far advanced for three major nuclear power stations of possibly 1000mW each to be supplied by, perhaps, a French- English consortium. This could add as much as 20 per cent to China's presently installed electrical generating capacity.

Even the impoverished nation of Bangladesh has established the technological, financial and environmental advantages of a small nuclear power station to be built at Roopoor, some 120km southwest of Dhaka.

In Indonesia, the professional staff of the Atomic Energy Agency has been steadily increased in three separate research establishments to nearly four times that of our own Australian Atomic Energy Commission.

The construction of a 30mW multi-purpose research reactor is well advanced in the vicinity of Jakarts in anticipation of the building of Indonesia's first power reactor-a 650mW unit-on the west coast of Java, 180km from Bandung.

This unit, which could be either a Canadian Candu or pressurised water system, will itself add some 25 per cent to Java's total installed electrical generating capacity supplying a population of nearly 100 million people.

While Australia continues to limit the staff and technical program of its Atomic Energy Commission and may downgrade the activities of its educational institutions in the field of nuclear engineering and nuclear technology, Indonesia has established a second major centre for the teaching of nuclear engineering at Yogjakarta at the Gadjah Mada University.
The present enrolment in this department is in excess of 100 and steadily increasing.

What could well have been a true ''sunrise industry'' for Australia two decades ago, leading to a significant high technology role for this country in the South -East Asia region, has been allowed to pass to more resourceful and more highly motivated hands.
Mr Leslie Kemeny is senior lecturer in nuclear engineering at the University of NSW.

TALK.START.PARA: —I maintain successive governments have failed to recognise the significance of this industry to Australia. I say that in criticism of the previous Government. We were restrictive in allowing the industry to develop initiatives in this country. While we are failing to establish those initiatives other countries are taking advantage of our sluggishness and capturing a market that will be very important to the world from about the year 1990 onwards. The articles that I have incorporated in Hansard demonstrate how the demand for electricity through nuclear power stations will grow for that period onwards. I will read an extract dealing with prospects for increased uranium requirements in the United States of America. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Statistics show that most US nuclear utilities fail to produce as much kilowatt hours from their plants as comparable foreign utilities produce from theirs. With only improvement in control of plant outage time and without additional plant installations a potential annual increase in uranium requirement of about 1,000 tonnes could reasonably be expected in the United States of America alone.

We listen to arguments from the left wing of the Labor Party and also from the Australian Democrats about making bombs through nuclear power stations. Those of us who have studied this matter know that it requires a special type of plutonium to make a bomb. It is certainly quite uneconomical even to contemplate making a bomb with plutonium that is produced by a commercial power station. That is a lot of nonsense and it ought to be exploded totally from a scientific and engineering point of view. I am talking about an emotional explosion.

It interests me to learn that radiation is with us in our own environment. Senator Townley and I did a little research on the radiation occurring in the vicinity of Parliament House yesterday. An instrument called the scintillation counter measures gamma radiation. We found in the garden of Parliament House that the natural radiation emitted was about a third of the radiation evident in my office. The radiation in Canberra is probably about eight times that which would be evident in Melbourne. So I think it is about time we looked at the associated scientific facts. In the last few moments I have in which to speak I will talk a little about radioactive waste management. Before doing that though, I want to say that I read with great interest the other day that the New York railway station is emitting more radiation at any one moment than would be allowable in nuclear power stations in that country. I do not hear the environmentalists in America wanting to tear down the New York railway station. They would not do that, but if they only realised that that building is irradiating more than a nuclear power station would ever be allowed to they might start ripping down buildings throughout the world.

I suggest, Mr Deputy President, that the documents I have relating to the disposal of high level radioactive waste would be of interest to people who read Hansard and others who might be interested in this subject. The documents come from a collection of organisations interested in uranium and nuclear energy. I will read a few paragraphs from the first page. It states:

In public debate and the statement of political positions regarding the acceptability of uranium mining and nuclear electricity generation it is often asserted that there is no demonstrated method of isolating high level radioactive waste materials for periods sufficiently long to ensure the safety of future generations.

Whilst it is true that no material has yet been actually placed in terminal isolation there is a high level of confidence amongst competent national and international bodies that this can be satisfactorily achieved.
The following 24 excerpts assembled by the International Atomic Energy Agency of Vienna in 1982 give an indication of the level of confidence that exists.
A background statement reads:

A public concern about the worldwide development of electricity production by nuclear energy is the possible danger arising from high level radioactive materials which result from the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel.

These so called high level radioactive wastes emit intense and dangerous radiation and whilst their radioactivity decays with time it is esential that they be effectively contained and isolated for several hundred years to ensure that neither the contained radioactive fission products or nuclides (i.e. high atomic radioactive elements) enter the atmosphere, water supply or food chain.

Spent fuel, which contains the highly radioactive fission products from nuclear electricity power stations, has been handled and stored for 25 years and in some countries the reprocessing of spent fuel is now well established.

The amount of high level waste produced by the nuclear electricity generating industry is quite small, of the order of 1,000 kilograms of material in solid form per year of operation for a 1,000 megawatt power station which under Australian conditions would serve the needs of approximately 750,000 people.

Because high level wastes generate heat as a result of the radioactive decay processes it is necessary that they be contained in specially designed equipment for several decades before consignment to a permanent isolation repository. This is necessary in order the maximize the stability of the material before final intended disposal, in stable geological structures deep underground.

Mr Deputy President, I have shown these document to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and he has agreed to the incorporation in Hansard . I seek leave to incorporate the documents in Hansard.
Leave granted.

URANIUM AND NUCLEAR ENERGY
THE DISPOSAL OF HIGH LEVEL RADIOACTIVE WASTE

In public debate and the statement of political positions regarding the acceptability of uranium mining and nuclear electricty generation it is often asserted that there is no demonstrated method of isolating high level radioactive waste materials for periods sufficiently long to ensure the safety of future generations.

Whilst it is true that no material has yet been actually placed in terminal isolation there is a high level of confidence amongst competent national and international bodies that this can be satisfactorily achieved.
The following 24 excerpts assembled by the International Atomic Energy Agency of Vienna in 1982 give an indication of the level of confidence that exists.
Background

A public concern about the worldwide development of electricity production by nuclear energy is the possible danger arising from high level radioactive materials which result from the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel.

These so called high level radioactive wastes emit intense and dangerous radiation and whilst their radioactivity decays with time it is essential that they be effectively contained and isolated for several hundred years to ensure that neither the contained radioactive fission products or nuclides (i.e. high atomic weight radioactive elements) enter the atmosphere, water supply or food chain.

Spent fuel, which contains the highly radioactive fission products from nuclear electricity power stations, has been handled and stored for 25 years and in some countries the reprocessing of spent fuel is now well established.

The amount of high level waste produced by the nuclear electricity generating industry is quite small, of the order of 1,000 kilograms of material in solid form per year of operation for a 1,000 megawatt power station which under Australian conditions would serve the needs of approximately 750,000 people.

Because high level wastes generate heat as a result of the radioactive decay processes it is necessary that they be contained in specially designed equipment for several decades before consignment to a permanent isolation repository. This is necessary in order to maximize the stability of the material before final intended disposal, in stable geological structures deep underground.
