TALK.START.PARA: —We are all concerned about the possible proliferation of nuclear weapons in the world. Nobody could be more concerned about that than I and my colleagues who represent the Liberal and National parties in the Opposition. But it seems to me that the sensible way for Australia to exercise a strong voice with respect to international safety standards and the non-proliferation of weapons is to become a major supplier. We have something like 25 per cent of the world's uranium readily accessible in our country and I believe that if we were to start now to develop our interests overseas and exercise a strong voice on the matters we are concerned about that would be the right path for us to follow . It must be remembered that it takes years before the uranium industry can compete on the world market effectively. As I said, the demand for uranium now may not be great but by 1990 countries like South Korea will be generating 51 per cent of their electricity requirements through nuclear power stations. That is one example. I have told honourable senators about the United States which certainly will become a major importer of that material probably within the next two decades, if not a decade. There is a tremendous opportunity for Australia to progress our interest in that industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from exercising a strong voice in dealing with international safety, other things would flow from the development of our uranium such as employment, subsidiary industry development and so on. It interested me the other day to read that Red China is offering to store highly radioactive waste from other parts of China. It might be an interesting point to make that Australia, having a geologically stable environment, and the synroc technology that is being perfected at the Australian National University, may well think about that. The Chinese are not silly. They recognise that they can profit by the storage of these highly radioactive wastes and perhaps, in the future, they will use that material to generate power through their own power stations. So there are many things that we ought to be thinking about.

Another thing we should do as a government is provide more scientists to assist the International Atomic Energy Agency in scientific audits in power stations that are using Australian uranium today. We need to educate the people. We should spend more money educating science teachers in Australia so that the children of today can be presented with scientific fact and knowledge about this important subject that will very seriously affect our future unless we embark upon an accelerated program in the development of this significant industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Jessop's speech I have a few points to make in regard to uranium and its useful purposes. As I have often said in this place, I am very much against the use of uranium for anything but peaceful purposes but I think our attitude towards not exporting it because it may be used in bombs is quite crazy. We might as well say we will not export wood because it might be used in spears or we will not export steel because it might be used in bombs or tanks.

SPEECH.PARA: Radiation in this world is quite a natural thing. We all live surrounded by it all the time; we are bombarded by it. Yesterday Senator Jessop and I took a scintillation counter out on to the lawns of Parliament House. We were able to measure the gamma radiation by means of this detector. We took it out on to the lawn and then brought it back, as Senator Jessop said, into his office and into my office. We found that the reading inside his office was almost double what it was outside, a little away from the building. The machine operates by counting the number of gamma radiations that pass through a little crystal that is inside it. Honourable senators will be pleased to hear that it is operating now and the radiation level is roughly the same as it is outside the building so they do not have as much to worry about as Senator Jessop and I do in our offices. People in Canberra, as Senator Jessop said, get much more gamma radiation from outer space than people in Melbourne. That is because of the altitude. I do not think he quite made that clear. The clouds stop a lot of gamma radiation; they split up the radiation that comes in, absorb it and change it. In fact, people who fly in aircraft a lot get considerably more radiation than those who stay at sea level.

We had hoped to demonstrate to the Senate with this machine that things like red wine, brazil nuts and even some brands of mineral water are recognisably radioactive but because of the surrounding radiation that is now making this little machine tick as it is we would have had to wrap the whole thing in lead to stop the ambient radiation before we could have shown honourable senators those things. So we did not go ahead with the experiment because if the machine were wrapped in lead we would not be able to hear it ticking anyway. There are, of course, some people who say any radiation is bad but it cannot be avoided. I think that members of parliament who encourage hysteria about radiation do a lot to damage this country. As Senator Jessop said, they should be trying to educate the people on scientific facts about what radiation does and how much of it there is around rather than tending to scare people. There is radioactivity in the air, in sea water, in our houses and in hotels and buildings. As I said, those who live at altitude get more radiation from outer space than those who live at sea level. But if we go into the sea, we cannot get away from it because , I think, something like 5,000,000 tonnes of uranium is dissolved in the oceans of this world. We grew out of the seas, so for aeons past the human race has been associated with radiation. It has actually been shown to be possible, but expensively possible, to make yellowcake from treating sea water.

Before I go on about educating people and talk about what I call hysteria about uranium I wish to seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two articles. I have mentioned them to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). One is a letter in the Australian. I am not sure of the date. The other is an article from Mining Monthly of March this year. I seek leave to have those articles incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Hysteria over nuclear waste

The Eldridge letter (9/2) left a lot unsaid on the matter of nuclear waste dumping in the ocean. Our Australian policy in this matter had been determined without any public debate and with little, if any, regard for the facts.
It is entirely understandable that the popular environmental movements should be concerned, with the evidence before their gaze of polluted rivers, estuaries and coastal waters.

It is unfortunate that the abysmal lack of numeracy, coupled with a general unwillingness (or incapacity) to research published scientific data, had led to an entirely emotion-based campaign of hysteria.
Within the constraints of a letter to the editor, let me set down a few salient facts:

1. Courtesy of Mother Nature, there is dissolved in the ocean over a billion curies of uranium 238 with tens of millions more in the top five centimetres of the ocean floor. Just one of the world's rivers, the Mississippi dumps some 365 curies a year into the Gulf of Mexico!

I have no figures for the great rivers of Asia pouring into the western Pacific , but we are certainly looking at orders of greater magnitude. Now against this background we are talking of dispersing, in very slow release form, no more than tens of curies a year.

2. Ocean water is radioactive, each litre decaying at around 750 disintegrations a minute, mostly due to potassium 40. Apart from potassium 40 of which the ocean contains some 400 billion curies, there is at least 100 million curies of radium, as well as 40 billion curies of rubidium 87.
Marine organisms tend to concentrate polonium 210, and have done so for tens of millions of years as it is the decay uranium-radium polonium. They have evolved to cope.

Further, the radio nuclides produced by man are shorter lived and generally less toxic than the natural ones which have existed since creation. Long after all the plutonium created by man has gone (assuming we are too stupid to use it as fuel), the natural uranium in the ocean, replenished by the world's great rivers, will be providing radium, polonium and rubidium to marine organisms.

3. A Japanese laboratory scale pilot plant has successfully (expensively, but successfully) extracted uranium in the form of yellowcake from sea water. There are at least five billion tonnes of uranium in the oceans of the world-and man evolved from primitive life in these very oceans!

4. My concern as to the innumeracy of the emotional protesters may be illustrated by this example of the vastness of the ocean. If the entire continent of Australia were to be dumped in the Marianas Trench and Basin, it would disappear with at least a kilometre of ocean above it! So the insignificance of, in volume, a couple of container loads of packaged waste is obvious.
And we are objecting to the conclusions of comprehensive multi-disciplined research, recorded in disciplined scientific reports which must by now exceed in bulk the waste we are talking about!

Please let us have a properly conducted public debate on this matter in the form of a proper judicial inquiry (like Parker J; Flowers J; and now the Sizewell inquiry) with evidence properly introduced before we dash off in all directions with policies relating to one of Australia's-and the world's-most significant energy resources determined solely by the vote-catching emotionalism typifying our present posturing.
D. S. STEWART Dural, N.S.W.
MEDIA HYSTERIA ABOUT URANIUM
By John MacPherson

On the subject of social and controversial aspects of nuclear-generated electricity, one of the observations recorded by Bernard Cohen, oft-published physicist at the University of Pittsburgh in the United States, is the news media propensity for gross overkill over events purported to expose the public to great danger but which, in fact, present no danger whatever to anyone. The word more likely than any other to trigger that condition in news media is radiation.
This observation was clearly illustrated yet again in an incident at a Canadian uranium mine recently.

An open-pit operation at Key Lake in Northern Saskatchewan lies in an area where the water table is relatively high. Surrounding the exterior and ringing the interior of the pit are huge ''dewatering'' wells intended to steer the ground water into the wells and away from the pit. But for a small degree of seepage into the pit, the system is effective.

The water in the wells is pumped into reservoirs and is used in the milling process. In this way the water not only serves the mining operation, but it receives decontamination before it is returned to the environment.
On January 5, one of the reservoirs was inadvertently allowed to fill to overflowing. About 70,000 cubic metres overran the embankment and turned to ice on the frozen muskeg.
What followed is by now all too familiar to the nuclear power industry.

The early news coverage, capped with front page headlines conveying such messages as ''Danger Spill'' and ''Big Radioactive Spill,'' described a chaotic scene in which radiation 400 times the level acceptable in drinking water had escaped containment.

The next round of coverage brought out the unionists and the opposition politicians with hints of cover-ups, speculations as to blame and urgent telegrams to governments remindful of all the other aspects of nuclear power that also are worrisome.
Next came the anti-nukes.

From these appeared such reports as scare stories exposing the perilous position in which the industry places the public. Expressions of fear that the water would find its way into other lakes and streams and contaminate them and demands that legal charges be laid.

Meanwhile at Key Lake, instruments checking the environment directly above the surface of the spill were unable to detect change in the background radiation level for that area. In the water itself, the alpha emissions measured 17 becquerels per litre, a rate not 400 times above drinking water acceptability but 45 times, all of which would have been pertinent had the water the least likelihood of being consumed. It hasn't of course.
The presence of arsenic in the water was not deemed worthy of mention-only the dreaded radioactivity.
Nevertheless, the coverage continued for days.
But by this time, instead of 400 times above acceptable drinking water levels, it was reported simply as 400 times above level acceptable for any use.

During the 10 or so days following the leak, anyone receiving news from Canadian radio, television or print media was told that the Canadian candu: Finally had been exposed as unsafe. Was as dangerous as 1,000 Hiroshima bombs. Violated the Canadian licensing requirements. Produced the most deadly substance on earth-Tritium. Finally had been exposed as too costly to continue with. Was not perfect. Had been infiltrated by Libyan terrorists. Would not sell nearly as well now and would not be wanted by anyone anyway.

No part of that picture, presented to the public as fact and in some cases repeated daily, carried any degree of accuracy whatever. Further, the President of the Canadian Nuclear Association submitted to the country's three largest print operations articles correcting the gross misinformation. All three refused to print the material submitted.

John MacPherson is a graduate of Edinburgh University and Glasgow College of education in Scotland. A former teacher and radio/television producer with the British Broadcasting Corporation, he joined the Atomic Energy of Canada Limited in 1972. Since 1977 he has been the Manager of Public Affairs for Candu Operations, the AECL Power Engineering Group.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that Mining Monthly of March 1984 Mr Don Zimmerman details the history of radioactive research in the world and in Australia. He also points out in that article that elemental uranium averages about three to four grams per tonne in the earth's crust. That is about the same amount as there is tin in the earth's crust. Granite is even more concentrated. Up to 20 grams per tonne is not uncommon in acid volcanic rocks in and around the eastern gold fields of Australia. I think it would be of benefit to the Senate if I were to seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
URANIUM COMMON ELEMENT
By Don Zimmerman
Uranium was discovered as a naturally occurring element in the mineral pitchblende in 1789, while the First Fleet was struggling to establish Australia 's first European settlement in Sydney.

Roentgen discovered X-rays in 1895, and in 1896 Becquerel recognized that uranium ores gave off rays similar to x-rays. Madame Curie named these rays radioactivity in 1898 when she also showed similar emissions are derived from thorium. This was also the year she succeeded in isolating radium, one of the products of radioactive decay of uranium. She and her husband had joined Becquerel in his research in 1895 and she continued to work with highly radioactive, concentrated uranium oxide, mainly as pitchblends, until her death in 1934. She is the only person to win two Nobel prizes, and one of her daughters also earned a Nobel prize in 1935.

Few people realize uranium is a relatively common minor element in the earth's crust, or that it formerly played a significant role in medicine for the first half of this century, in what is now known as nuclear medicine. Radioactivity from artificial isotopes is now used extensively in sterilisation of materials and some foodstuffs.

Elemental uranium averages about 3-4 g/t in the earth's crust, roughly the same concentration as tin. Uranium also occurs in sea water which has been researched as a possible supply source. Higher concentrations are found in the more acid ( siliceous) rocks such as granites and acid volcanics. Concentrations of 20 g/t U308 are not uncommon in the more acid granites of the Eastern Goldfields district of Western Australia.

Uranium now has the dubious distinction of attracting more political attention than any other commodity, including oil. This is because it is the most concentrated form of naturally occurring energy yet discovered. One pound of uranium oxide is equivalent in energy to about 8 tonnes of black coal or 25t of brown coal. Controlled release of this energy was mastered in the forties under military stimulus to survive and outgun the aggressors. The effects of nuclear weaponry at Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945 were so devastating and horrific that many observers believe they have discouraged major wars since then.

In the 1950's the energy in uranium was harnessed as electricity for military ships and domestic power, first by Russia. The first commercial nuclear-powered electricity station in Russia started in Obinsk in 1954, while the first Western one started at Calder Hall in the United Kingdom in 1956. The demand for uranium for electricity sparked a boom in exploration in the early 50's which, as usual, turned into a slump by 1960 after apparently adequate supplies had been found. This boom saw the discovery and development of Australia's first three significant uranium mines-Rum Jungle, Northern Territory, Mary Kathleen in Queensland, and Radium Hill in South Australia. Other significant discoveries were made in the South Alligator River valley, Northern Territory, where several small, rich mines operated briefly, and in the Pandanus Creek-Westmoreland area- straddling the Northern Territory-Queensland border 100km south of the coast.

By the mid 60's nuclear electricity was well established in the major industrial countries, and far-sighted planners recognized that future demand would again expand. Predictably exploration for uranium again began to accelerate in Australia, U.S.A., Canada, Africa and South America. Many new discoveries were made, the most notable of which were the large, high grade Rabbit Lake deposit in Saskatchewan in 1968, and the large tonnage, low grade Roessing deposit in Southwest Africa (now Nambia) shortly afterwards.

In Australia Bill Siller, formerly of Oilmin, was one of the first to resume uranium exploration by reactivating search in the crystalline rocks of the Mount Painter area in South Australia in 1967. This led to the discovery of the Beverley deposit in the outwash sandstones of the Frome Embayment some four years later.

The spectacular discoveries for Australia came in 1969-70 when systematic airborne radiometric/magnetic surveys of the East Alligator River-West Arnhem Land (now called Kakadu) district disclosed several hundred anomalies; three of these were quickly proved as economic discoveries, viz., Ranger, Nabarlek and Koongarra, respectively by the Peko-E.Z. joint venture, Queensland Mines Ltd and Noranda Australia Ltd.

Systematic exploration on a small piece of ground in this area by the Pancontinental-Getty joint venture found the first of the Jabiluka deposits in 1971. Meanwhile the Cluff Lake deposits had been found by the French in Saskatchewan, and in Western Australia, Western Mining Corporation had anxiously awaited the end of a ban on claim pegging to stake the large, new-type Yeelirrie deposit in calcrete host-rock in January 1972.

In the space of two years Australia repeated the story of iron ore reserves whch had expanded exponentially after the export embargo was lifted in 1961. Uranium reserves in 1969 were a few thousand tons but by 1973 well over 200 000 tons of economically recoverable reserves had been drilled out. Australia had earned a place as potentially a major supplier of uranium, for which it had no use domestically. It had also identified two new uranium provinces-the Alligator Rivers district, Northern Territory, and the Northeast Yilgarn, Western Australia.

Regrettably however, through a lack of confidence and purpose, Australia literally 'fumbled the ball' and blew many of its opportunities to gain markets at that time, and so it did not capitalize on these remarkable discoveries. In 1973, while Australia was moving to reduce foreign investment and control, and to entrench tight government control of all energy resources, the OPEC oil price shock occurred. The uranium price had started to move in 1973 from its long time level of $6 US per pound U3O8, and it climbed through $30 per lb in response to the OPEC shock and bullish predictions of expanded nuclear electricity to reduce oil dependency, especially imported oil. The then Australian Minister for Minerals and Energy, the late R. F. X. Connor, recognised the potential and value of uranium by supporting the reopening of the Mary Kathleen Mine, initiating government exploration, and a government take-over of 50 per cent of the equity in Ranger. By 1979 the price was around US $43 per lb U3O8 but it has since declined to less than US $25 per pound currently, due to soft demand, excess inventory and high interest rates during the recent world-wide recession.

In Australia exploration of the rich Alligator Rivers district was quickly choked off by a combination of environmental enquiry, and withdrawal of most of the area as national park, government reserve or aboriginal land.

Intense exploration in Western Australia failed to find any more ''Yeelirries'' though minor deposits were found nearby at Lake Way. Small deposits were also found in the Frome Embayment of South Australia, and the Georgetown district of North Queensland.

Meanwhile in 1975 the discovery of the large, very rich (2-3 percent U3O8) Key Lake deposit in Saskatchewan catalysed another exploration boom there resulting in several more discoveries. Exploration also boomed in the USA throughout the 70's, resulting in a significant increase in high cost, sand stone uranium reserves. Exploration has continued in Saskatchewan virtually without restriction since 1975 while the only known geologically comparable area-the Alligator Rivers district-has remained inaccessible. Key Lake was discovered in 1975 and commenced production in October 1983. Australia's Nabarlek and Ranger, discovered in 1969-70, commenced production in 1980 and 81 respectively; Koongarra, Jabiluka and Yeelirrie are ready to start but have to get markets and then government approval. Neither seem attainable at least until the Hawke government rationalizes its policy on uranium. While the companies controlling these deposits are not authorised to seek sales contracts, Australia's competitors-Canada, USA, South Africa, Nigeria and other Central Africa suppliers-are very active securing most of the available market, even into the longer term.
Australia has blown many opportunities

In the meantime three more significant discoveries have been reported in Australia. These are WMC's massive Roxby Downs deposit, first drilled in 1975; press reports only of a discovery east of Kalgoorlie by the Japanese PNC Exploration (Australia) Pty Ltd in 1982; and the French Total Group's small vein deposit in Ben Lomond, west of Townsville, Queensland.
Mining Monthly, March 1984

At the end of 1982 Australia's reasonably assured reserves, recoverable economically within a sales price of US$80 per kg U3O8 (US$30 per lb) were 370, 000 tonnes U3O8. An additional 435,000 tonnes were estimated recoverable within this price structure. These reserves amounted to about 22 percent of the Western World's reserves as estimated by the OECD for 1982.

The latest estimates of reserves at Roxby Downs mentioned 450 million tonnes averaging 0.08 percent U3O8, plus copper and precious metals. This amounts to 360,000t. U3O8 or 45 percent of Australia's assured and estimated reserves in 1982.

If the global reserves for Roxby Downs of 2 billion tonnes averaging 0.06 percent U3O8 are mineable economically, they amount to about 1.2 million tonnes of uranium oxide, or 60 percent of the Western World's reasonably assured reserves, or one-third of its total reserves as known in 1982. In addition to Roxby there is significant uranium potential in the Alligator Rivers district, Northern Territory, and this has remained effectively unexplored since 1973. A respected consultant, Mr G. S. Eupene, who worked on the Ranger deposit from 1970, and who has remained familiar with geology and exploration in the district to the extent possible since then, has expressed his belief that ''at least one million tonnes of U3O8 will be recovered from the Alligator Rivers Uranium Province.'' The presently known reserves are about 350,000 tonnes limited to the four known and explored deposits.

Thus by combining Roxby Downs and the Alligator Rivers district we have potential global reserves of 2.2 million tonnes of uranium oxide. Thus Australia potentially, has nearly 60 per cent of the presently known uranium reserves of the West, (3.6 million tonnes oxide) or 43 percent when these local potential reserves are added to those of the free world. Undoubtedly Canada can further dilute Australia's percentage with its new discoveries such as Waterbury Lake and Mid-west Lake. However, it is almost certain that Australia would have 30-40 percent of the Western World's uranium reserves if exploration and mining were allowed to proceed as they are in Canada.

Regrettably the recent declaration of Stage II of the Kakadu National Park by Prime Minister Hawke and Environment Minister Cohen suggests to the rest of the world that Australia is not interested in realizing its uranium potential. In his submission to the Aboriginal Land Commissioner hearing evidence for an Aboriginal Land Claim over the proposed Stage II of Kakadu in 1981, Mr Eupene stated his belief that ''at least 500,000 tonnes are likely to be extracted, in time, from within the area subject to the Alligator Rivers Stage II Land Claim ( including the Jabiluka resource'' (of 208,000t)). Thus if the Federal Government proceeds with the declaration of Stage II as a National Park, and does not allow exploration and mining in the Park, it will be locking away uranium resources of one and a half times Australia's current reasonably assured reserves.

Applying the general factor that one pound of uranium is equivalent to the energy of about 8 tonnes of coal, this is equivalent to locking away 8,000,000, 000 tonnes of coal! This is hardly a decision to be taken lightly. According to 'The Bulletin', Minister Cohen promoted the idea of declaring Stage II of the National Park by circulating a folio of photographs, most of which were of Stage I of the Park. Such an enormous potential energy resource surely deserves more in-depth consideration than a folio of scenic photos. Worst of all, the advocates for the Park seem unable to accept the practicality that a National Park and mines can coexist and support each other, even though the example of Ranger is already working in the area for all to see!

Uranium is now used to generate more than 10 percent of the World's electricity , or more than one percent of total energy use. Belgium, France, Finland and Sweden each have more than 40 percent of their electricity from nuclear plants. This will give them a significant cost advantage in future manufacturing because the uranium fuel is a minor part of the cost of nuclear electricity compared to the cost of construction, particularly in terms of 'present values' at the respective times incurred. By way of contrast fuel is a major, escalating cost in oil and coal-fired power plants.

The OECD Nuclear Energy Agency and the IEA forecast at the end of 1982 that ' total domestic coal production in the OECD countries is expected to increase by more than twice between 1990 and 2000, while the nuclear component . . . is expected to quadruple.' The West German marketing agency Nukem recently reported that '1983 will probably be the first year during which total consumption exceeds uranium production.'

Coal is coming under more and more criticism environmentally because of fears of the 'greenhouse' and 'acid rain' effects. However there is no way uranium will replace coal even in the mid term, but environmental regulation will cause the cost of coal power to increase.
Nuclear waste disposal technology exists and is being demonstrated.

Australia's SYNROC process offers another alternative about to be pilot tested in joint Australia-United Kingdom-financed research. In any case the amount of waste to be disposed of is miniscule compared to ash and emissions from coal, e. g. all the highly active liquid waste from the entire United Kingdom nuclear electricity program since 1956 would fit into a four bedroomed house.*

Nuclear proliferation remains a threat but commendably, Australia is taking a leading role in trying to strengthen non-proliferation and safeguards treaties. Australia can only remain credible and effective in this area by continuing as a stable and reliable supplier of uranium for peaceful uses. If it becomes a major supplier, commensurate with its reserves, obviously it will have more say internationally.

Australia could also play a major role in stabilizing world uranium prices, and the supply of uranium for peaceful purposes, by accelerating development of its known deposits and encouraging exploration of its potential reserves.

Uranium is currently Australia's ninth most valuable export worth $360 million in 1982-3, and fourth in the ranking of mineral exports after coal, bauxite and iron ore. Australia needs this revenue to maintain its standard of living and social programs. However trade is a two-way matter; while Australia may wish to dictate terms on uranium unilaterally the facts of economic life will dictate otherwise. No such major item of trade can be considered in isolation.

Once again Australia has the chance to 'grab the uranium ball' and run with it. The 1984 ALP biennial conference will review uranium policy and it will be the single most important event in deciding whether Australia takes its oportunity or fumbles and loses it once again. There may not be a third opportunity! Canada and the USA as major supliers will be most interested spectators.
* See the CEGB and Nuclear Power. Questions and Answers 1981, P.41.

Don Zimmerman is the General Manager of Uranerz Australia Pty Ltd, and a recognised expert on the peaceful use of nuclear energy. His views are presented as the final part of Mining Monthly's special uranium feature.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an article today in the Australian headed 'Australia standing at nuclear crossroads' by Leslie Kemeny, who is a senior lecturer in nuclear engineering at the University of New South Wales. I think we have to recognise that that is very true. The world dependence on electrical energy supplies, in particular nuclear generated energy, I think will continue to increase into the next century. This continued expansion of the nuclear power industry seems assured regardless of Australia's attitude or actions. This seems particularly true of nations such as France, Japan and Korea whose national energy security needs can be met only by an ever-increasing reliance on nuclear power.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has on this continent, under one single government, one of the largest national resources of uranium in the world. Despite a generally depressed world uranium market at present the prospects for Australian exports appear bright for several reasons. The first is the generally high grade of ore and its low cost recovery. Secondly, I believe we have a better political stability compared with other essential suppliers such as Namibia. Thirdly, there is a perceived tendency for the United States to link its nuclear fuel supplies to foreign policy rather than to non-proliferation considerations and, fourthly, there is the ever-increasing reliance of our trading partners on the use of nuclear energy. However, as Mr Kemeny from the University of New South Wales said, the situation is fairly fragile and could easily be irreparably damaged by a government that is seen by some in the industry as essentially hostile to resource development and inately contemptuous of private enterprise. At present Australia is regarded as a supplier of last resort. That to me is not good enough. What is required is a stable and reasonable uranium export policy by the Federal Government to restore confidence in Australia's ability as a reliable mineral exporter.

The whole nuclear fuel cycle is one area in which Australia may be able to play a significant strategic role. If Australia is to effect an improvement in the possibility for nuclear non-proliferation and safety standards it will be by active participation and direction and not by a futile policy of isolation and non-co-operation. If the world is to develop into the next century with its goods, welfare and quality of life shared peacefully and more equitably great demands will necessarily be made on the earth's energy resources. Such demands will require the optimal use of all available sources. Certainly, I believe, there will be an ever-increasing dependence on electricity generated from nuclear power. It is important, I think, to distinguish between two forms of energy. Firstly, primary energy is energy in the form of its natural resource, for instance, wood, coal, wind or hydro-power. Then we have secondary energy forms-those to which primary energy may be transformed for distribution or direct use by customers. The share of electricity in total energy consumption is expected to increase from 31 per cent in 1980 to 46 per cent by the year 2000 in the more industrialised nations. For the developing nations this rate of increase will be even more dramatic with electricity's share of total energy consumption doubling from 16 to 32 per cent over the same period.

Those figures come from a publication entitled 'Nuclear Power, the Environment and Man' which is a joint publication of the World Health Organisation and the International Atomic Energy Agency. It was printed in Vienna in 1982. It is expected that concomitant with this increased reliance on electrical power will be an increase in the share of that power generated from nuclear energy sources. It is estimated that this increase will be twofold during the next five years and more than threefold during the next 10 years and by a factor of between six and seven during the next 20 years. Those figures came from page 17 of the same publication.

At 1 January 1983, there were 294 nuclear power stations in operation in 25 countries around the world. There were also a further 215 such power stations under construction in some 27 countries. This will mean that by 1990 to 1992 there will be 31 countries world wide generating electricity from nuclear power stations with a capacity of over 350,000 megawatts which is, I think, more than 10 times Australia's total coal fired capacity. That figure comes from the International Atomic Energy Agency. Uranium fuel generation accounts for about 11 per cent of the world's total electricity production and by the mid-1990s that figure will rise to more than 25 per cent. Mr Deputy President, I would have liked to have continued reading this document. I do not have time to finish it and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. It is a straightforward document.
Leave granted.
The document reads as follows-
SYNOPSIS

World dependence on electrical energy supplies, and in particular nuclear generated electricity, will continue to increase into the next century. The continued expansion of the nuclear power industry seems assured regardless of Australia's attitudes or actions. This would seem particularly true of those nations such as France and Japan whose national energy security needs can only be met by an ever increasing reliance on nuclear power.

Australia has on one continent, and under the sovereignty of a single Government, one of the largest national resources of uranium in the world. Despite a generally depressed world uranium market at present, the prospects for Australian exports appear bright for several reasons:
(i) the generally high grade ore and low-cost recovery.
(ii) political stability when compared to other potential suppliers such as Namibia.
(iii) a perceived tendency for the United States to link its nuclear fuel supplies to foreign policy rather than non-proliferation considerations.
(iv) the ever-increasing reliance of our trading partners on nuclear energy.

However, any optimism is rather fragile and could easily be irreparably damaged by a government that is seen by some in the industry as essentially hostile to resource development and innately contemptuous of private enterprise. At present Australia is regarded as a 'supplier of last resort' for uranium. What is required is a stable and reasonable uranium export policy on behalf of the Federal Government to restore confidence in Australia's ability as a reliable minerals exporter.

The nuclear fuel cycle is one area in which Australia may be able to play a significant strategic role. If Australia is to effect an improvement in the possibility for nuclear non-proliferation and improved safety standards, it will be by active participation and direction, and not by a futile policy of isolation and non-cooperation.

If the world is to develop into the next century with its goods, welfare and quality of life shared peacefully and more equitably, then great demands will necessarily be made on the earth's energy resources. Such demands will require the optimal use of all available source of energy and, almost certainly, an ever -increasing dependence on electricity generated from nuclear power.
World Electricity Generation from Nuclear Power:

It is important to distinguish between two forms of energy: Primary energy refers to energy in the form of its natural resources, e.g. wood, coal, oil, wind, hydropower etc. Secondary energy forms are those to which primary energy may be transformed for distribution to, or direct use by, customers, e.g. petrol , electricity.

The share of electricity in total energy consumption is expected to increase from 31% in 1980, to 46% by the year 2000 in the more industralised nations. For the developing nations, this rate of increase will be even more dramatic, with electricity's share of total consumption of energy doubling from 16% to 32% over the same period.1

It is expected that concomitant with this increased reliance on electrical power, will be an increase in the share of that power generated from nuclear energy sources. It is estimated that this increase will be twofold during the next five years, more than threefold during the next ten years, and by a factor of between six and seven during the next twenty.2

As at the 1st of January 1983 there were 294 nuclear power stations in operation in 25 countries around the world. There were also a further 215 such power stations under construction in 27 countries. This will mean that by 1990- 1992 there will be 31 countries world-wide generating electricity from nuclear power stations with a capacity of over 350,000 megawatts (which is more than ten times Australia's total coal-fired capacity)!3
Uranium fueled generation accounts for around 11% of current world total electricity production. It is estimated that by the mid-1990s this figure will have risen to more than 25%4
However, many of Australia's trading partners are far more dependent on nuclear generated electricity than the 11% world average would tend to indicate. For example:5

The share of nuclear power for electricity generation in some of these countries, notably Finland, France and Japan, may rise to as much as 70-80% by the year 2000.6
Australia and the World Uranium Market:

The part played by minerals and energy in Australia's export economy has increased dramatically over the last ten years. In 1971-2, minerals and energy exports accounted for 20% of total Australian exports. By 1981-82, that figure had risen to 35% of the total, and energy alone accounted for 17%7.

This year, Australia will export about 4,000 tonnes of uranium to the U.S.A., Western Europe and South East Asia, with a total value of over $400 million. The Department of Trade and Resources has estimated that Australian exports of uranium will expand to about 10,000 tonnes per annum8. This will increase the annual value of uranium exports in the early 1990s to some $1200 million ( expressed in today's prices). This is a figure comparable with the current revenue from the export of wool, wheat, meat or iron ore.

However, it is clear that Australia's uranium resources will only maintain their value if there is a market for them in the future. An estimate of world- wide demand for uranium indicates that some 900,000 tonnes of uranium will be needed up until the year 2000 for reactors currently in operation or under construction. In the United States alone, it is estimated that there is a need for 200,000 tonnes of uranium, between now and the end of the century, which is not as yet covered by contracts.9

It should be noted, however, that at present there is a marked slump in the world uranium market. Production of uranium is now several years in advance of demand because of a slowing down in nuclear power station construction. This in turn is due to a number of factors: general world economic recession; and increased emphasis on energy conservation leading to decreased energy consumption, including electricity; opposition to nuclear energy in a number of countries giving rise to highly restrictive licensing procedures, notably the United States. This has led to a decrease in the price of uranium by almost 50% since 1978.10

However, Australia is uniquely well positioned to continue to prosper even under these depressed market conditions. There is a good prospect that Australia can take a more dominant stance in the uranium market because of, among other things, a greatly reduced production capability in the United States which will see that country become a net importer of uranium for the first time. The National Energy Advisory Committee has predicted an increased demand for Australian uranium towards the end of the 1980s, stating that ''utilities can be expected to seek major contracts commencing around 1987-7''.11

Also, Australia has a number of advantages in terms of the competitiveness of its mining operations. Australian producers are favourably placed, because of new plants and high grade ore, to protect themselves against extreme fluctuations in price, by long term contract negotiations independent of the '' spot'' price.
THE POLITICAL DEBATE:

The policies of the Liberal/National Party coalition, and those of the Australian Labor Party remain almost diammetrically opposed on the question of whether to continue to mine and export Australian uranium.
The Liberal and National Parties are committed to:
1. International uranium trade subject to proliferation and waste controls.
2. A minimum of interference by the government with free trade market forces.
3. The development of new uranium mining projects and the sales of uranium concentrate to energy deficient nations.

4. The operation of all mining and concentrate preparation with the goals of special regard for the health and safety of the workers, the surrounding environment and the economic viability of the mines themselves.
The ALP has adopted a platform that is very much contrary the one outlined above. Two particularly relevant statements of policy from the ALP platform are:
63 (c) . . . our minimum position would be a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry.
(d) as an ALP government we give total commitment to preventing any new mines from being developed during our period of office.12

On the 7 November 1983 Labor Caucus decided, by a vote of 55 to 46, to continue to export uranium and to approve the development of the Roxby Downs/Olympic Dam uranium reserve. This was apparently not inconsistent with Labor Party policy, in that section 64 (c) of the ALP platform states that in government they would 'consider applications for the export of uranium mined incidentally to the mining of other minerals on a case by case basis and on the criteria of whether in the opinion of the Labor government the mining of such minerals is in the national interest;' (The Olympic Dam Project will also produce copper, gold and silver.)

However, it was restated that 'with the exception of Roxby Downs if commercially feasible, the Government will not permit the development of any new uranium mines.' The future of Australian exports of uranium is to be determined by the report of an inquiry to be conducted by ASTEC under Professor Ralph Slatyer; the report is to be produced no later than May of this year.

Caucus also decided to continue the existing suspension of uranium exports to France. The decision would not be reviewed until the report of the Inquiry was received, or until some progress was made towards cessation of French nuclear testing in the Pacific.
The Federal Labor Government has also announced its intention to declare Stage II of the Kakadu National Park, although this will not actually occur until some time during 1984.

This declaration does not include the Jabiluka and Koongarra uranium reserves, although one press report indicated that it will effectively cancel more than three hundred mineral exploration leases. When the Kakadu National Park Stage I was proclaimed in April 1979, it excluded the land proposed for the develoment of Koongarra. The land remained Aboriginal land. The government is now expected to open negotiations with the owners to acquire the Koongarra and Jabiluka areas so that it can be included in the Park and thereby preclude mining.

The Federal Government's actions have not pleased either the Northern Territory Government or Aborigines who stand to lose a considerable amount in royalty payments. For example, in 1982-3 the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account received $ 11.7 million from the existing Ranger and Nabarlek operations (which are unaffected by the declaration of Stage II).
Opposition to mining and export of Australian uranium:

Most groups opposing the mining and export of Australian uranium (including the ALP as stated in their platform), base their opposition on two main points: First, that the nuclear power industry contributes to the proliferation of nuclear weapons; and second, a perceived safety risk in the nuclear power industry.
Nuclear proliferation:

It is difficult to understand exactly what the ALP platform is referring to when it claims 'the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war'. It is significant to note that most technologically advanced countries (e.g. Israel, Brazil) could now produce nuclear weapons if they chose to do so, irrespective of whether or not they have nuclear power stations. This can best be illustrated by noting that all the present nuclear weapons states, except India, produced their nuclear weapons several years before they had a nuclear power station, and all did it without help or information from countries possessing nuclear weapons . Moreover, it is certain that India did not use its power station to make the material for its 'explosive device'. In other words, not one nuclear weapons state has acquired its weapons through civil nuclear power.

The simplest and cheapest way to produce weapons grade uranium 235, uranium 233 or plutonium 239 is with low-power, research-type reactors, or via isotope separation techniques which separate U235 from natural uranium. These reactors can be built quickly and with relatively simple technology. Thus it would seem that even if banning civil nuclear power were a feasible objective, which it is not, it would not significantly hinder those countries who wanted to produce nuclear weaponry.

Thus, it would seem clear that technologically sophisticated countries can eventually develop a weapons capability in the absence of civil nuclear facilities. However, it may be that such countries could produce weapons more quickly (in the order of a few months) using fast reactors and reprocessing plants which were built for civilian use. Fast reactors are particularly sensitive because they routinely produce large quantities of weapon-useful plutonium in their breeding blankets.

Two points should be noted with regard to these plutonium fast-breeder reactors . Firstly, all signatories to the Non Proliferation Treaty agree to allow IAEA staff to inspect their facilities, set up monitoring facilities etc. This acts to ensure that any reactor fuel which is diverted from its normal use will readily be detected. The Australian Government will only sell uranium to countries which accept international safeguard procedures and which are party to the Non Proliferation Treaty.

Secondly, Australia may be inadvertently encouraging the growth of the plutonium market and fast-breeder reactor programmes. These reactors require far less uranium fuel, and in fact produce 20% more plutonium fuel than they consume . Thus, by making reliable supplies of uranium more difficult to obtain, Australia may be encouraging some nations which rely on nuclear power to build plutonium reactors in preference to the thermal uranium type reactor.

Australia cannot hope to stop the possible development of a nuclear weapons capability in other countries by simply refusing to export uranium for use in civil power programmes. It may be able to play a far more useful role by becoming more involved in both the technological and energy utilization strategies of uranium.
Nuclear Safety:

One apparent safety threat arises from the risk of terrorists using nuclear materials such as fission product waste or plutonium to hold communities to ransom. Uranium ore and fuel for thermal reactors do not represent good potential weapons for the terrorist. They are extremely difficult to convert into nuclear weapons, and are much less poisonous than many other commonly found substances.

Fission products and plutonium also present a difficult problem. In order to steal the fuel, the terrorist must take over the power station, be able to use the fuel loading and unloading machines; then he must choose between tranporting the fuel in an ordinary truck, in which case the radiation will swiftly become lethal, or use a heavy, slow and easily detectable fuel transport truck.

The threat is increased, however, after the plutonium has been reprocessed as it can be handled relatively easily and in certain chemical forms is extremely poisonous. Plutonium from moderm commercial ractors is stored in the reprocessing plant as plutonium oxide. A crude nuclear weapon can be made from this rector-grade plutonium oxide, although the critical mass is 25 kg and as well, the terrorists would need to have access to machining equipment and conventional explosives expertise at a very sophisticated level. The theft of 25 kg from a reprocessing plant would be extremely difficult because plutonium is detectable in very small amounts, of one gram or less.

The misuse of plutonium in small quantities could be achieved by threatening water supplies etc. However, plutonium in water is less dangerous than some common weedkillers. Far more devastating effects could be achieved through release of anthrax, foot-and-mouth virus, or a host of other poisons and diseases.

Possibly the most potent threat would come from exploding a device wrapped in plutonium oxide. The oxide particles dispersed into the air would form a lethal aerosol. However, the area would not presumably be too large to evacuate and decontaminate. Also, those people who do inhale the aerosol would not be immediately, or necessarily, adversely affected. This would tend to deny the terrorist any swift and spectacular effects.

In short, whilst the development of civil nuclear power generation will increase the opportunities for terrorists, they will be extremely hazardous, difficult to achieve and unrewarding compared to the many options already available. Unfortunately, with the current state of misinformation and irrational fear of nuclear energy, such an event would probably have a publicity value far beyond the real threat posed.

The IAEA in reviewing three decades of nuclear commerical power plant operation reports that nuclear reactors have now accumulated approximately 2800 reactor- years of operating experience.13 In the United States alone electric utilities have accumulated more than 730 reactor years, over 25 years, in which time no member of the public has been injured or killed by a reactor accident at a commerical nuclear power plant; and no plant employee has exhibited clinical evidence of serious injury from radiation. The accident at Three Mile Island did not alter this record. In that accident the radiation escape was 20-30 man Sieverts, which gives rise to a probability of only 1 in 3 or 1 in 4 that a single death will occur in the next ten to twenty years!14

As far as the radiation released during the normal operation of the nuclear power industry is concerned, the levels recorded are so small as to be almost insignificant. One year of operation of the nuclear power industry at 1981 levels is estimated to yield a collective exposure, delivered at a varying rate over the next 10,000 years, corresponding to about one day of natural background radiation!15 In other words, the radiation dose from all stages of the nuclear fuel cycle, reactor operation and waste disposal was about .01% of that of naturally occurring background radiation!16 In fact, a study conducted in the U. S. by Professor N. Rasmussen has calculated the risk of an accident large enough to cause at least 10 cancer deaths over the next 10-20 years as being 1 in 100, 000 per reactor per year.17 By way of comparison, in California alone there are 12 dams with failure probabilities estimated to be as high as 1 in 100 or 1 in 1000 per dam per year, whose failures could cause between 10,000 and 250,000 deaths!18

The number of direct and developed deaths from the mining of sufficient uranium to supply England's current needs for electricity is less than 1 per annum. This compares with the death rate, if the same electricity were generated from coal, of 5 miners killed in accidents and 30 to die later from pneumoconiosis contracted at work.19 It has been said that the media generally pays far more attention to the risk of fatalities from commercial nuclear power plants than they do to actual deaths that occur in the production of other forms of energy. In 1982 there were at least 16 non-nuclear energy related accidents that resulted in 1662 deaths.20 The recent fire in a Japanese coal mine that claimed the lives of more than 80 miners is a tragic example.
Further prospects for Australian involvement in the Nuclear Fuel Cycle

The fundamental nature of the nuclear fuel cycle means that low-, medium-, and high-level radioactive waste products will occur at different stages. Those which cause the greatest concern are the high-level radioactive wastes which have both a long half-life and intense radioactivity.

The fission of uranium in nuclear power reactors produces a wide range of highly radioactive by-products, including caesium-137 and strontium-90, and the actinide elements, including plutonium and neptunium. These ''high-level'' wastes are removed from the spent fuel by reprocessing. It is essential that these wastes be isolated from the biosphere for long periods of time, at least 10,000 years and possibly as long as one million years.

Spent fuel from uranium power stations may be stored indifinitely in above ground facilities in its original form; the main reason for seeking long-term storage or disposal arrangements are economic. The World Health Organisation stated in 1981 that the methods for the management and interim storage of high- level radioactive wastes are operational and well proven.

While various concepts for the long term disposal of radioactive wastes have been proposed, it is widely accepted that underground disposal, with the wastes suitably immobilised, would provide the necessary protection to man and the environment. Such a system effectively establishes two major barriers to the possible reintroduction into the biosphere of dangerous radionuclides: an immobilisation barrier, and a geological barrier. A typical scenario may be: first-the liquid wastes are incorporated into a matrix that will immobilise them in a stable and insoluble form that will not leak or corrode when placed in the earth for long periods.

Australia has made a significant breakthrough in this field with the development of a substance called SYNROC (synthetic rock) by the Research School of Earth Sciences at A.N.U. working in conjunction with the Australian Atomic Energy Commission.
Secondly-the glass/synroc will be surrounded by metallic cannisters composed of titanium and lead which are highly resistant to corrosion by groundwaters.

Thirdly-when finally buried, the cannisters will be surrounded by highly absorbent ''over-packs'' of compacted betonite which will greatly impede access of ground water and will selectively absorb and bind any radioactive elements which might be released from the waste package.

Finally-geological disposal of the waste packages. Traditionally this had been envisaged in terms of a mined repository consisting of a vertical shaft to a depth of 500-700 metres, in a favourable geological environment, at the bottom of which would be a series of horizontal drives, and in these, short vertical holes in which the waste would be placed.

However, Professor Ringwood of the Research School of Earth Sciences at A.N.U. has suggested an alternative. This would involve initial immobilisation in SYNROC and then burial in single discrete holes. These holes would be as deep as four kilometres or more with diameters of one to three metres. The bottom 2500 metres of the hole would be filled with waste cannisters, and the top 1500 metres backfilled.21

It may well be that if Australia is to be effective in seeking to limit the proliferation of nuclear weapons and improve the safety standard of waste disposal, it will need to become more involved in the world fuel cycle, rather than retreating into futile isolationism. For example, Australia could seek to develop a reprocessing industry to extract uranium and plutonium from spent nuclear fuel for future re-introduction into the fuel cycle. The resultant high level wastes could be converted into SYNROC for burial in deep geological formations. It is almost certain that Australia possesses many sites which are geologically suitable for the disposal of such wastes, combined with the advantage of large expanses of arid, unpopulated land. It would seem preferable for such measures to be undertaken here rather than in geologically unstable areas such as Japan, or even in deep ocean trenches in the Pacific. In this manner, plutonium produced from Australian mining and export of uranium would remain under Australian control at all times. Reprocessing and solidification services are in great demand and firm markets could readily be secured. These services would, in addition, provide considerable leverage in obtaining export contracts for Australian natural or enriched uranium.

Australia should recommence its study of the feasibility of establishing a uranium enrichment plant here. Whilst it would appear that Australia alone does not possess the technological capacity at present to develop an enrichment industry, one should not forget that the value of yellowcake is roughly doubled by conversion and enrichment. The Federal Labor Government has withdrawn from the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia which was investigating the viability of establishing such an industry in Australia. This needlessly negative approach by the Government came despite the belief of the chairman of the group (which was established by four major Australian companies-CSR, BHP, Peko-Wallsend and WMC) that the case for establishing an enrichment industry in Australia was encouraging.
Nuclear Energy vs Fossil Fuels

The relative safety records of uranium mining and coal mining have already been discussed (p. 12 above). However, it is worth noting that the actual impact on the environment, in terms of the pollutants emitted during power production, is actually far greater from coal-fired stations than from nuclear stations.

Nuclear energy is inevitably connected with the production of large amounts of radioactive materials that must and can be controlled. However, nuclear energy releases into the atmosphere neither the chemical and particulate pollutants, nor the large amounts of carbon dioxide associated with the burning of fossil fuels. These waste products of coal and oil fired power generation have an effect on the environment that has yet to be fully assessed but the so-called '' greenhouse effect'' and ''acid rain'' may have consequences that prove far more catastrophic than any possible nuclear power station accident. As well, coal stations produce sulphur dioxide and a product which is a known carcinogen, benzopyrene. In fact, it has been estimated that one hundred times more cancers are produced as a result of coal generated power than by nuclear powered production of electricity!22
APPENDIX I
The Uranium Fuel Cycle

Uranium is mined generally as low grade ore, and processed at the mine site to concentrate the uranium into a form which can be transported economically. Commercial concentrates of uranium ore are called ''yellowcake''. It is frequently represented as U3O8, although it is really a complex mixture of oxides.

Naturally occuring uranium contains only about 0.7% of the fissionable isotope of uranium, U235. Nuclear reactors currently in service generally require fuel that contains about four times the proportion of U235 that occurs naturally. Thus, the crude yellowcake is first converted to pure uranium hexafluoride, a compound of uranium which is readily vapourised by heating. Once vapourised, the 'light' (U235) and 'heavy' (U238) atoms of uranium in the vapour are altered in their proportions of the total, such that the product contains 3 to 4% U235. This process is referred to as ''enrichment'' of the uranium. Commercial enrichment processes operate on the principals of gaseous diffusion, where light molecules pass faster than heavy molecules through a porous barrier, or gaseous centrifugation where a mixture of atoms is rotated at high speed allowing the heavier atoms to accumulate at the periphery of the rotating cylinder.

The next step in the cycle is fuel fabrication. This requires the processing of the enriched UF6 into UO2 (uranium dioxide) which is then pressed and sinterd into fuel pellets, each about 1.5 cm long and 1 cm in diameter. These pellets are then loaded and sealed into tubes which are then assembled into precise mechanical array to form a fuel element.

Fuel elements are normally left in a nuclear power reactor for about three years. After this 'burn up' period, the depletion in the proportion of U235 in the element through atomic fission requires that it be removed and replaced.

Used fuel elements can be reprocessed to separate and recover uranium containing U235 atoms, as well as plutonium that has been formed from uranium in the reactor. Both of these products can be reintroduced into the fuel cycle. Reprocessing also separates out the highly radioactive waste products formed by the fission of uranium and plutonium atoms.
For a typical 1000 megawatt electrical (MWe) light water reactor the annual fuel materials requirements (assuming a 6lb/tonne ore) are as follows:
69,000 tonnes of ore are mined, to produce 158 tonnes of yellowcake, which is then converted into 183 tonnes of UF6.
this is then processed in an enrichment plant to produce 29.8 tonnes of enriched UF6 which is processed to produce 29.5 tonnes of fuel.
this in turn produces the same quantity of spent fuel which on re-processing produces 6 tonnes of high level solid waste.
By way of comparison, the annual fuel requirements of a 1000MWe plant operating at a capacity factor of 75% would be:
69,000 tonnes uranium ore
2.5 million tonnes coal
10 million barrels residual fuel oil
64 billion cubic feet natural gas
25,000 acres of solar cells.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The plight of Indo-Chinese refugee students is a matter that I have referred to previously and which I wish to raise again because a solution has not yet been found to the problem. I urge the Government to make special arrangements for these students, if not sooner then at least in the Budget this year. I seek leave to incorporate a copy of a letter that I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 12 July 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
The Rt. Hon. R. J. Hawke, A.C., M.P.,Prime Minister,Canberra
My dear Prime Minister,
I am writing to you concerning a matter which came up recently in discussion with a constituent-but it has also been raised with me on previous occasions.
It is a matter which may fall within the ambit of Social Security, Education or Immigration but it seemed important enough-in my opinion-to draw to your personal attention.

As far as young refugees are concerned, if they come to Australia on their own, they presently receive a Special Benefit for the first six weeks. They then go on to unemployment benefits, in which case they are only able to go to school for about eight hours per week.
If they wish to proceed with their schooling-and I am talking about people between the ages of 18-21 years, there are two different situations which apply:
(a) If the young person has an elder brother or sister, they can apply for a Family Allowance and a double Orphan's pension to assist in the support of the student, or
(b) if there is no elder brother or sister, there is no benefit to allow a person of this age to pursue schooling.

In any event, the point I have raised in (a) may be the case as far as the elder brother or sister is concerned, however, I consider that probably both of them should be full time at school, if they are going to receive the best possible opportunity of developing themselves and participating in our society.

In some situations, I understand that they are in fact encouraged to receive unemployment benefits and to go to school part-time which, of course, is not permitted. In actual fact, they are really being encouraged to 'work the system' from the early stage of their arrival in Australia, which is most undesirable.
I would be grateful if you could have this matter investigated.
How can we best enable young people in the age group to which I have referred, obtain the education we should make available to them?
Yours sincerely
MARGARET REIDSenator for theAustralian Capital Territory

TALK.START.PARA: —I set out in that letter the problems which refugee students are faced with in getting education in this country. If they are on unemployment benefit they are able to go to school for only about eight hours per week which is nothing like adequate and there is no other benefit which specifically enables them to live and study. The special secondary student allowance of $1, 076, of course, is quite inadequate for the purpose. I had a letter from the Prime Minister acknowledging the matter and indicating that he had referred it to relevant Ministers. I received a letter from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in which he acknowledged the problem and specifically referred to the work that his Department was doing and the report that was being prepared. I had a letter from the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) in which she acknowledged the problem. The Indo-China Refugee Association also wrote to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) and I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the contents of that letter, dated 24 October 1983. The letter refers to the Association's delegation meeting with Senator Ryan and also points out to him the two suggestions it made to deal with the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave grant.
The letter read as follows-
I.C.R.A. (A.C.T.) Inc.
INDO-CHINA REFUGEE ASSOCIATION A.C.T. (INC.)
Griffin Centre, Bunda St P.O. Box E269 Canberra City, A.C.T. 2601 Canberra A.C.T . 2000 Telephone: (062) 47 9532
24 October 1983
Senator the Hon. D. Grimes
Minister for Social Security
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

In response to ICRA delegation to Senator Ryan's office on the deplorable situation of young people dropping out of school for lack of income support, we have just received a most hopeful reply from her. Senator Ryan has promised to take up with you and Mr West the urgent need to help refugee young adults.

Our delegation made two suggestions to fill the gap in present income support provisions for students wanting to study fulltime at the secondary level who are ineligible for any income support. We think the quickest and most cost-effective interim measure is for the Government, through your Department, to give them Special Benefits until other more suitable arrangements are agreed to by the bureaucrats.

Our second suggestion was to recognise all intensive English courses such as that at the Introductory English Centre at Telopea Park High School in the A.C.T . in such an official way that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs could pay students over the compulsory school leaving age the Living Allowance available to them if they attend courses which are part of the Adult Migrant Education Programme. That would advantage only a small proportion of the students in need. It would also most certainly take a lot of time to implement, were the Department willing to do this.

Young refugees are dropping out of education every day. The strain of poverty on top of end of year exams and assessments and the personal traumas of all new settlers, is too much. If they drop out now, what chance that they'll re-enrol next year? The Participation and Equity Program courses for young people disadvantaged and 'at risk'' aren't the answer: mainstream schooling with specialist help is.

Our purpose in writing to you direct is to urge you to act now, so some young people can see the year out and continue in 1984. Our Association has lobbied on this issue for more than three years. Your predecessor was sidetracked into looking at more longterm equitable solutions, and finished up doing nothing. The rounds of interdepartmental discussions did not come up with a Governmet solution to a very real problem. We don't think these young Australians of the future are expendable. Please direct your staff to help them this week.
Yours Sincerely,
Marion Le
President ICRA (A.C.T.)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Association received a response from Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security. I acknowledge his awareness and interest in this matter in that I had a meeting with him myself with some members of the St Vincent de Paul Society who were concerned about these students. He acknowledged my remarks in this chamber on another occasion. His letter deals specifically with the question of education. It refers more to the problems that a number of full time students have in continuing as full time secondary students and supporting themselves. Nobody is denying that there are students who have that problem. Why I specifically refer to the Indo-Chinese refugee students is that we hold ourselves out as a nation that accepts refugees and we bring young people here frequently without their parents, maybe with only relatives of a more distant nature, perhaps sometimes with another brother or sister. We are not giving them any opportunity whatever to become integrated into our community if we do not give them the opportunity to study, learn English and acquire the sorts of skills that will give them some prospects of making a life for themselves here.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that I am not denying that there are other full time students who have difficulties but I urge the Government to recognise the refugee young people as a special category of people that we have brought here, holding out to them that this country has something to offer them. It is at the very beginning of their stay here, when that they need the education that we can provide, that they ought to be supported in a way which will enable them to pursue their education. I had a letter from the Indo-China Refugee Association at the beginning of this academic year. It says that its members and its committee of management have reached the end of their tether. I seek leave also to incorporate this letter which sets out the despair, of those in our community who are working towards assisting the young people, who are right there with them and who are most aware of the problem. As I said, if it cannot be solved sooner the Government should at least introduce some special benefit in the 1984 Budget to provide relief in this area.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
I.C.R.A. (A.C.T.) Inc.
INDO-CHINA REFUGEE ASSOCIATION A.C.T. (Inc.)
Griffin Centre Bunda St P.O. Box E269., Canberra City, A.C.T. 2601 Queen Vic. Terr. Telephone: (062) 47 9532 A.C.T. 2600.
24 February, 1984 Senator Margaret Reid,
City Mutual Building,
Hobart Place,
Canberra. 2601
Dear Senator Reid,

Members of I.C.R.A. and its Committee of Management have reached the end of their tether. We have reported a crisis situation to all relevant Ministers and Departments, over some years, without success and are very disheartened that at the beginning of the 1984 school year young adults in the ACT have their participation in full-time education jeopardised by a lack of adequate and appropriate income support.

Sponsors and friends of young Indo-Chinese students and the young people themselves are in a moral quandary. Do we encourage or turn a blind eye to the illegal practice of receiving Unemployment Benefits and studying full time? Do we counsel young people with no family support to stay honest and starve? Do we undermine their independence by offering them charity? Do we advise them to drop out and qualify for U.B.? or to take an inappropriate TAFE or PEP course? Do we tolerate the illegal recipients of Unemployment Benefits sneering at those who stay honest?

If the CES rigorously applied its regulations, between 50-100 Indo-Chinese and an unknown number of students of other backgrounds including the Australian born will be forced out of our school system and increase the level of youth unemployment in the A.C.T.

An interim solution to the immediate problem is the payment of Special Benefits by the Department of Social Security. It is already paid to homeless youth under 16 years of age, we would be grateful for your urgent public and political lobbying for this interium solution and your public support for those young people who struggle to stay honest.
Yours Sincerely, MARION LE, President

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to another matter that has been raised with me by residents of Hall, which is a small village just outside Canberra. The specific letter that I mention firstly came to me from Robyn Murray. In part she says:

SPEECH.PARA: I personally came to Hall 4 years ago, looking for a peaceful, quiet place to live after originally moving to Canberra from a small country town. Until recently I found it a very pleasant place. I used to take my small baby for a walk at the public recreation area each evening until being nearly attacked by a German Shepherd dog. Luckily, a passing motorist saw what was happening and stopped his car to chase the dog away.

She refers to similar problems that other residents of Hall have had and the dog control vans which control in the area from time to time. Since raising this matter the residents have apparently been told that there will be more patrols in the area. It raises the question as to whether the dog control ordinance is adequate to protect people from the events which are described in a letter, dated 20 November 1984, to the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren). Rather than read out the whole of that letter I seek to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Feb. 20, 1984 The Right Honourable T. Uren,
Minister for Territories and Local Government,
Parliament House
Dear Sir,

We, the undersigned residents of Hall, are writing to express our developing concern over the increasing number of German Shepherd dogs being housed in what used to be our small (approximately 70 household), quiet village, and the effect this is having on the other residents of Hall.

We believe that one household has from 10 to 15 dogs housed in the back yard. Another has approximately five dogs, and recently a new homeowner in Hall has brought three more fully grown German Shepherds to the village. There are other households with one or two German Shepherds. Some owners are using their residential leases for breeding purposes.

Our objections are on two main grounds. One: That the twice-daily exercising of the dogs in public areas of the village is limiting use of these facilities for other residents, since the dogs are uncertain in temperament, often not adequately controlled. Two: That there has been a quite significant increase in the level of noise in the village due to these dogs, to the extent that several of the immediate neighbours have seriously considered selling their properties. One resident who did try to sell her expensively renovated home was unable to do so because interested buyers were horrified at the dogs, noise and kennels over the fence.

The use of public grounds by the German Shepherd dogs for exercise is causing growing discontent. There have been various incidents which indicate that the dogs are not kept under proper control. Without detailing each of these, it could be said that such incidents generally occur when the dogs are being exercised in public places. They have bailed people up, run aggressively at people and horses while their owners have attempted to call the dogs to order, and one dog has actually bitten a child, causing serious injury.

Apparently children playing in the recreation areas have been told by the dog owners to leave while the dogs are being exercised. Parents of some children no longer allow children to play in recreation areas because the dogs may be there. Morning joggers and afternoon strollers alike prefer to stay at home rather than risk a possible confrontation with the dogs. Details of these incidents can be provided on request.

The noise created by so many big dogs housed in a small residential area is considerable. It often goes on intermittently all day and night and can be heard blocks away. This is extremely aggravating, especially since the owners of the dogs are often away at the time and therefore don't have to endure the noise themselves. One household arises at 6 a.m. to be begin taking their dogs to the public park, much to the annoyance of neighbours who are woken each morning at this time by the loud barking of the dogs as they are loaded into their vehicle.
Even casually walking past the blocks where these dogs are housed usually causes a session of loud barking and one wonders what might happen if any of the dogs were to escape.
