Many residents over the previous year have made numerous complaints to the Dog Control section of the Department, but we have had little or no effective response. It appears that there is very poor legislation in this area, there being no limit, as far as we understand, to the number of dogs which may be kept on one residential lease.
*The Hall Progress Association has also written to the relevant D.C.T. department on this subject, without reply.

Because of the large number of residents concerned about the effect these dogs are having on their pleasant lifestyle in Hall, especially with regard to children's safety, we request that you begin immediate action to limit the number of dogs that may be kept on a residential block in Hall to two, to discourage any further migration of 'dog packs' to our village.
We would like to point out that we are not objecting to the particular breed of dog concerned.
Many people in the village have pet dogs but they are not kept in large numbers and consequently are less of a health hazard, nor have they demonstrated aggressive behaviour . . .
* Following the writing of this letter, a reply has been received from the Deputy Dog Controller stating that the Dog Control Van is prepared to patrol the Village after hours on an ad hoc basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is signed by 100 people who live in Hall. It sets out details of what has occurred. It alleges that there is one household that has from 10 to 15 dogs housed in the back yard and another with five dogs. Apparently these dogs are allowed out into the oval recreation area and they make it impossible for people to enjoy that area when they are there. Of course honourable senators will appreciate as well, I am sure, the fact that these dogs also foul the area and make it a place unsafe for babies and young children to play. That is a matter of concern to the residents. Perhaps the legislation needs to be reviewed to see whether some tightening is necessary in relation to the number of dogs that can be kept in any one suburban sized house block and whether the rules for allowing dogs out in public are adequate. I have no doubt that most of them appear to be under control if the dog patrol happens to pass by but I think the Minister ought to note the complaints of the residents in this area and give his attention to the steps that might be taken to make it the place that most people want Hall to be, that is a pleasant village to live in.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.38 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Grimes will be absent from the chamber this afternoon and that Senator Ryan is absent as she is ill. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Grimes should be directed to Senator Evans and those to Senator Ryan should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface it by wishing Senator Ryan a speedy recovery. I preface it further by reminding the Leader of the Government of the resolution of the Senate of 30 March which called on the Government to make a full statement as a matter of urgency on the content of and decisions taken by the Government on the document known as 'Strategic Basis of Australia's Defence Policy 1983' and the steps taken by the Government to keep the document secure. I also remind the Leader of the Government that in Question Time yesterday the Attorney-General provided some additional information about the distribution of the document and the joint Australian Secret Intelligence Service and Australian Federal Police investigation into the leak to the National Times and that the Leader of the Government promised Senator Durack a reply as soon as possible on the question of the timing of any statement from the Government. I again ask the Leader of the Government whether the Government will abide by the terms of the resolution and make a full statement on this matter. If so, when does it propose to make that statement?

—I am unable to help the Leader of the Opposition as to a precise date when the Government might make a response to this matter. The Prime Minister has announced that an inquiry has been set up to deal with it. The inquiry has already begun this work and when the task is completed the Parliament will be informed of the result.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question just to make sure that I fully understand that answer or so that it is fully understandable to all of us. Is the Leader of the Government saying that in fact the Government will make a statement in the terms of the Senate's request when the inquiry is completed?

—I cannot answer that with absolute precision. The Government will make a response at the appropriate time when the task has been completed. I am sure that the Government will do all it can to meet the requirements of the terms of the Senate resolution, but I cannot be more precise than that.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications aware of a ruling by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal last Friday rendering illegal a television commerical for the Australia Ballet Trust which mentions the Ballet's major sponsor, the Benson and Hedges Co. Pty Ltd, and which contravenes section 100 (5A) of the Broadcasting and Television Act? Is he further aware that the commercial in question belongs to the Australian Ballet, not the Benson and Hedges company, and that the Australian Ballet is faced with the possibility of losing its $400,000 sponsorship from Benson and Hedges as a result of this Tribunal's decision, thus creating a major financial crisis? Is there any avenue of appeal open to the Australian Ballet over this decision; if not, will the Minister for Communications intervene on its behalf to see whether a compromise can be reached over the continued screening of this commerical in view of the value to Australia of a viable national ballet company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a somewhat complex matter. It is true to say that with regard to the Australian Ballet advertisement the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on 13 March this year decided that that advertisement was an advertisement for cigarettes within the meaning of section 100 (5A) of the Act. In its decision the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal stated that the advertiser is the Benson and Hedges Company. The reason it gave for that decision was that the advertisement contains a sponsorship announcement which is identical to that in the test cricket advertisement called 'Field of Battle'. That advertisement was found to be in breach of section 100 (5A) of the Broadcasting and Television Act. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal stated:

ANSWER.PARA: An advertisement placed by B & H (rather than the relevant sporting body) which gives as much prominence to promoting the B & H Company as this advertisement does can reasonably be assumed to be intended to promote, or obtain goodwill for the only product universally identifiable with that company, namely cigarettes.

I understand that the Australian Ballet Foundation contacted the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal requesting that the matter be reconsidered. The Foundation advised that the advertisement in question was produced and paid for by the Australian Ballet and was not the subject of any input from the Benson and Hedges Company. In its response to this approach the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal issued its amended decision of 30 March, which stated:

While the fact that such an advertisement has or has not been placed by the B & H Company is relevant, it is only one factor to be taken into account. Primary intention must be focused on the actual form of the advertisement itself.

The Broadcasting Tribunal maintained that the advertisement seeks to promote cigarettes; that is the relevant point. The question of who placed the advertisement is not as relevant as what it seeks to promote. The Tribunal has advised that the ruling could be challenged or appealed against in the Federal Court. I just make the point again that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is an independant body and under section 16 of the Broadcasting and Television Act it has the responsibility for regulation of both public and commercial broadcasting services. The Minister for Communications has no power in relation to this matter. The Broadcasting Tribunal has power which it can exercise and which is capable of appeal to the Federal Court from any decision of the Broadcasting Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Has the Government decided to hold a referendum to change the Australian Constitution in conjunction with the next Federal election which it proposes to hold later this year? If so, what questions will go to referendum at the time of the proposed early election? If the Government does not propose to hold a referendum at the time of the election, does it propose to do so at any other time?
—The Government has made certain decisions in this respect. They will be announced in due course.
—I ask a supplementary question. Could the Attorney-General be a little more forthcoming and enlightening as to when the announcement will be made?
—No.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Does the Commonwealth have any plans to dispose of the Toowoomba rifle range or the Army Reserve property in Margaret Street, Toowoomba ? If so, what are the details of those plans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services, whom I represent in this place, in his first year of that ministry has been very energetic in reviewing all of the properties owned or used by Government as well as reviewing properties for which we pay a substantial amount of rent. I am advised that as part of the ongoing land review program the occupants of these properties in Toowoomba, that is the rifle range and the Army Reserve property that have been referred to by Senator Colston, have been identified as having potential for relocation on the basis that the uses of the subject sites were not commensurate with their land value. The Department of Administrative Services is seeking agreement from the Department of Defence. Consultation is taking place with the Department with a view to relocating both the sites referred to by Senator Colston. If agreement is obtained from the Department of Defence the proposals would be put forward for consideration in the context of the 1985-86 Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: That indicates that there will a thorough-going review of the sites in question . All the factors will be taken into consideration, including local interests, the requirements of the Department of Defence, and the question of whether the Government is getting the best utilisation of the assets held by the Commonwealth. I assure Senator Colston that all factors which need to be taken into consideration will be taken into consideration by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government aware of a report in yesterday's Canberra Times that for the second time in a month the Australian Capital Territory's liquor ordinance has been found to be defective and that it now appears that a prosecution for selling liquor to under age persons is impossible? Is he further aware that in the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court last week the ordinance was described as 'screaming for attention'? Will the Minister say whether the Government will undertake as a matter of urgency whatever action is necessary to ensure that minors are not able to be served alcohol in the Australian Capital Territory in contravention of the intention of the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be agreed that health authorities in general are concerned about the over-consumption of liquor, whether by over age or under age persons. Certainly the Government is concerned about the general social problem that exists not only in the Australian Capital Territory but throughout the Commonwealth. All State governments are plagued with the same sort of problem of under age drinking, which has become a feature of recent years. The problem is generally recognised as one which exists throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in the Australian Capital Territory, to which Senator Haines made specific reference, under age drinking is dealt with under the Australian Capital Territory Liquor Ordinance, which is administered by the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority. Currently a legislative review is taking place over a wide range of liquor issues, but there are difficulties in administering laws on under age drinking. The Minister accepts that this is a problem and it is receiving his specific attention. The difficulties in enforcing the under age liquor provisions of the ordinance have been highlighted in recent and pending court actions, as Senator Haines said.

In addition, the Australian Federal Police section of the Australian Capital Territory Federal Liaison Advisory Council has drawn the matter to the attention of the Minister for Territories and Local Government. In recognition of the social ramifications of under age drinking, the Minister has decided to refer the matter to the proposed Australian Capital Territory welfare inquiry. In due course the results of that inquiry will be published.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given that this is a severe social problem, can the Minister give the Senate some idea of what the phrase 'in due course' means? What is the timetable involved?

—I think the specific matter of the timetable and the approach to that problem should be answered by the Minister for Territories and Local Government. I shall draw Senator Haines's question to the Minister's attention and I hope I shall be able to provide a specific answer before the Senate rises today.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, refers to the current study into simplifying government departmental forms. Can the Minister advise whether the current study also applies to departmental information brochures? Will the Minister consider extending the expertise gained from this study to future government information and advertising campaigns?
—I have no knowledge to hand of the matters to which Senator Elstob refers. I will seek an early reply from the Minister for him.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, relates to the Sala case and the actions of the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy, in ordering the return of Mr Sala's passport against the wishes of the police involved in the case. Will the Attorney-General confirm the accuracy of a report in the Age of 3 April which attributes to Senator Evans, or his office, the information that Senator Murphy was told by a departmental officer on 29 May 1974 of strong police objections to the return of Mr Sala's passport? What other matters did the departmental officer bring to Senator Murphy's attention on 29 May or the next day? Was he told of Mr Sala's links with major crime figures? Was he told of suspicion that Mr Sala may be linked to an international drug smuggling operation? Was he told that representations on Mr Sala's behalf had come from the firm of Morgan Ryan and Brock?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing in the Age report to which Senator Archer refers which is not consistent with what I have already told the Senate on the numerous occasions on which I have responded to questions on this matter, and nothing which I need to correct. As to the latter run of questions, I do not believe that the then Attorney-General was told anything more than that there was a concern that the passport may have been forged, a matter to which I have referred on numerous occasions, and I do not resile in any way from that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Attorney-General of the day was aware that there was concern about this, but the reason he made his decision, nonetheless, was that which I indicated, that he believed it was inappropriate for mere suspicions, unaccompanied by an actual charge which for whatever reason had not been laid, to justify the continued open-ended detention of the person in gaol. No doubt he was also aware that representations in relation to Mr Sala had come from the firm of Morgan Ryan and Brock because there had been a telegram to that effect delivered to the Attorney, as I have said in this place, some days before that discussion took place.

I do not believe there is any foundation for believing that the then Attorney was aware of any of the other matters to which Senator Archer refers. But I will check that and give him a further answer if the facts are any different from those I have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to the recently advertised off-shore petroleum acreage and to his statement last week that he hoped to be able to make some announcement about applications for exploration permits in that acreage this week. Is the Minister now able to advise the Senate of the results of advertising that off-shore acreage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Senator Chaney asked me a question about this last week and I said that I would release the results after contacting the two relevant State Ministers. Twelve off-shore areas were advertised last November, 10 off the Western Australian coast and one each off South Australia and Tasmania. The applications closed on 23 March. It should be noted at the outset that all these permit areas had previously been allocated and either surrendered or cancelled. In respect of the 12 areas, a total of five applications were received, two for the Tasmanian acreage, one for each of the two Bonaparte Gulf areas, and one application for a small part of one of the eight Exmouth Plateau areas.

ANSWER.PARA: The interest in the Tasmanian area is encouraging and reflects, in a significant way, the results of the marine geophysical work carried out by the Bureau of Mineral Resources in the Bass Basin region a couple of years ago. That same work has been a significant factor in attracting experienced companies to farm in existing permits in that area.

The BMR's deeper seismic survey work has provided the geoscientific framework which has been of great value in reassessing the Basin's potential and has assisted in planning future detailed exploration. Recent advances in seismic technology have also improved the prospects of defining attractive drilling targets in the prospective but largely untested Bass Basin sequences.

The response in relation to Western Australia, especially the Exmouth Plateau, is disappointing and probably reflects the increasing perception that whatever hydrocarbons are in that area are more likely to be gas than oil. It would also appear that for the most part the exploration companies have decided not to take up less prospective acreage, at least at this time. It has been suggested in the Press that they prefer to focus their attention on the impending release of more highly prospective areas between Australia and Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. Following his refusal to make available to me the guidelines for classification of video tapes and discs for sale or hire, I ask: Firstly, will he reconsider his refusal? Secondly , if not, will he inform the Senate why the Senate or indeed the people of Australia should not know what is in those guidelines so that they can understand how the members of the Film Censorship Board are asked to reach their decisions and, thirdly, will the information be available to me on my application under the Freedom of Information Act?

—The guidelines to which Senator Walters refers are at this stage, on my understanding, simply draft guidelines prepared by the Chief Censor , Ms Janet Strickland, for the guidance of her officers. They have not yet been the subject of discussion or agreement by the Federal and State Ministers responsible for censorship. Hopefully they will be as a result of tomorrow's meeting in Sydney. The reason why I was not keen to make the material available to Senator Walters was not just to protect her from exposure to material of a potentially salacious kind, but rather because I thought it was appropriate that the Ministers in question have an opportunity to determine their position on it before the material becomes broadly available. As to the question of whether the material would be available under FOI, I expect it probably would be. Senator Walters is welcome to try to find out. I will certainly reconsider the question as to whether the material should be made--
—Haven't those been made public?

—They may well have been. We are pretty relaxed about freedom of information in this Government and certainly, on matters of genuine public interest and importance, such as this is, we are all too willing, once the policy process has worked itself out, to put material of this kind into the public domain. One would only wish for and hope that the result of putting this material in the public domain would be a slightly more rational and less twisted debate than the one we have heard over the last 48 hours. But I live in hope that a supply of information will contribute in due course, maybe with a change of generations in the Opposition benches, to a more rational consideration of these matters. I will certainly give further consideration to the matters which Senator Walters has raised.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Since the Film Censorship Board has had to classify X rated videos as from 1 February, I presume the Board is already using those draft guidelines. Why is the Minister saying that they are not yet in place? Why is he saying that they have yet to be decided upon? Why is he not allowing the people of Australia to understand what guidelines the Film Censorship Board is at this moment using to classify X rated videos? Is he frightened of the people of Australia realising what the guidelines are indeed all about?

—I have nothing further to add to my previous answer except to say that yes, it is the case clearly that the guidelines to which Senator Walters refers have been used by the Chief Censor and her officers since the new system came into place on 1 February. But they have not yet, to repeat, been discussed or certainly endorsed by the Federal and State Ministers, and to that extent I do not believe it is appropriate, until we have had a chance to look at them, that the material be made more widely available than that. But with a little bit of help from Senator Harradine, Senator Walters does not seem to have had any difficulty in getting access to the material, and clearly it has not improved the quality of her contributions to this debate, having had that access .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: IMPROVEMENT OF WATER SUPPLY IN SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the appropriation, as part of the Government's community employment program, of $20m this financial year for country towns' water supply improvement programs. I ask the Minister: What progress has been made in the selection of projects and in the commitment of funds under the program in South Australia? Will the program provide benefits to a number of centres in the mid-north and upper south-east regions of my State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire specifically asked what progress had been made in projects which have been approved under this new program for supplying better quality and/or more abundant water to country towns, which was introduced by the present Government. It has recently been announced that the Commonwealth will be providing just over $1m to provide a decent water supply for Coober Pedy, in the north of South Australia. That amount will be supplemented by contributions of, in round figures, $500,000 from the local community and $500,000 from the State Government. This is something, of course, that has been badly needed for a very long time, and something for which I might add the people of Coober Pedy can thank primarily their local member, Mr O'Neil, who pushed the Coober project very strenuously with me and with the Government. Secondly, of course, they can thank the present Government for having had the imagination and initiative to introduce a program such as this. It was something that was conspicuously lacking in the programs of previous governments which were much more interested in throwing away, for example, $20m on the Mitchell River dam project in Victoria which the Victorian Government has already torpedoed just to oblige a few of Peter Nixon's friends, or $5m on an engineering investigation study for the Bradfield scheme and for turning back coastal rivers in northern New South Wales, which ought to be regarded as employment creation schemes for consultants based principally in Brisbane.

ANSWER.PARA: Previous coalition governments had wilfully neglected over many years the great need both for a water supply in the absolute sense, and a supply of better quality water which exists in very many towns, particularly in the eastern and south-eastern parts of Australia. That long standing defect has been remedied by this Government. While I could go on at greater length, in closing I do want to put on the record that in New South Wales 17 projects have already been approved ; that is actual or improved water supplies for 17 country towns, and for 42 in Victoria, four in South Australia, 24 in Queensland and 12 in Tasmania. As yet in Western Australia no projects have been approved because the water supply position traditionally has been somewhat different in that there is, over most of the south-western part of the State, a pipeline, laid many years ago, which has supplied most of those country towns. It is difficult to find country towns in Western Australia which do not have a reasonable water supply. I have just yesterday put to the Western Australian Minister, a proposal, the details of which I do not intend to elaborate on at this stage, as to how we may overcome the problem which has been encountered in Western Australia, and that is, finding potential projects which meet the overall guidelines laid down for this program.

Finally, I should have mentioned earlier, in a specific response to Senator Maguire, that in the mid-north of South Australia, among other towns that have been supplied or will have their water supply improved by this initiative are, notably, Clare and Port Augusta.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Has he considered whether the Prime Minister's possession of an amount of United States currency in Sydney on or about 21 February 1982 was in contravention of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations, or any other law? If so, has he taken any action concerning this matter? Has the Attorney given any advice to the Prime Minister or to any of his colleagues, or indeed to anyone else, about the Prime Minister's possession of this money?

—I have no knowledge whatsoever of the matters to which Senator Lewis refers. I have certainly had no occasion, as a result, to look at any legal or other matter that might arise from that, nor have I taken any action in relation to it.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to Press reports that the Government of North Korea has proposed talks with South Korea concerning the possibility of a joint Olympic team, a proposal first put forward by South Korea in 1981. Can the Minister inform the Senate of Australia's attitude towards this proposal and the possibility of reducing tensions in the Korean peninsula?

—Obviously the recent announcement about the willingness of North and South Korea to discuss the composition of a joint Olympic team is one that is very much welcomed by the Australian Government as an obvious and striking symbol or demonstration of an easing of tension in the troubled Korean peninsula. The Australian Government also welcomes recent moves among countries with a close interest in the Koreas, including Japan and China, to consider taking part in negotiations aimed at reducing tensions in the region generally. Whether these moves will come to anything we do not yet know but it is the desire of the Government to urge all countries involved to take a pragmatic and conciliatory approach and to explore to the fullest any possibilities for a change from the present historic situation of confrontation. In this respect it is the Australian Government's view that there is a need for the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to recognise the Government of the Republic of Korea as the legitimate representative of the South Korean people. Whatever the format of negotiations, they must involve direct contact between the North and the South on an equal basis if real and lasting progress is to be achieved. In the long term it is the hope of the Australian Government that the DPRK will be able to play a more co-operative role in regional affairs. However, after its responsibility for the Rangoon bombing was clearly established, the Government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs took the view that any change in our presently interrupted bilateral relationship would have to await an assurance that such unacceptable international behaviour would not be repeated.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of Senator Grimes's recent comments in Question Time that there needed to be reforms to the system of occupational superannuation in Australia, can the Minister confirm that the recent report in the Australian Financial Review that the Government is considering imposing higher levels of taxation on superannuation funds as well as taxing lump sum benefits, as already announced, is part of its policy? Will the Minister confirm that if tax at around 50 per cent is imposed on superannuation funds' income, the final benefits payable to members may fall to only one-ninth of the levels of benefit currently being enjoyed by them? Does the Minister agree that this would be tantamount to destroying the system of occupational superannuation in this country and would impose intolerable burdens on the social security system in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen that report in the Australian Financial Review to which Senator Messner referred, nor do I have any advice on this matter from the Treasurer. I can only say that I have no knowledge of a proposal to impose higher levels of tax on superannuation funds. It is my understanding that they are exempt from tax.
—Only in some circumstances.

—For practical purposes, anyway, they are exempt from tax, so though suggestion of a higher level of taxes may be technically correct in some instances it is rather misleading in the full context. I can say that last year the Government, when assessing both the methods of dealing with the enormous prospective Budget deficit it had inherited from the irresponsible administration which preceded it, was compelled to look at a wide variety of means of both reducing expenditures and increasing revenues. At that stage we had the option, in looking at the existing very generous treatment of superannuation schemes, of imposing a tax on lump sums drawn when an employee took out his or her entitlement or, alternatively, taxing the income received in the hands of the funds. As is well known, the Government's decision at that time was to impose a tax which would gradually become more significant on lump sum payments from those funds. As far as I know there is no current proposal to tax the income in the hands of the funds. That was an alternative.

ANSWER.PARA: As for Senator Messner's final comment, about the enormous burden on the social security system, it ought to be noted that the treatment for taxation purposes of superannuation schemes which existed up until the election of this Government imposed an enormous burden on all the other taxpayers of Australia because in total the taxation benefits of those superannuation schemes amounted to about $2 billion a year. It ought to be borne in mind that because of those very generous concessions other taxpayers-I suppose in some cases the same taxpayers, but taxpayers in general-were required to pay $2 billion a year more in income tax than they would otherwise have had to pay. So while the Opposition is attempting to big note itself with superannuitants and superannuation funds, the corollary of its proposal ought to be noted; that is, if the Opposition's attempts to big note itself are ever successful and more concessions are provided in this area, everybody else will have to pay more tax to make up for the tax revenue forgone. That will happen if the Opposition's ostensible policies or beliefs are put into practice. It ought to be noted that perhaps there is a benefit for some in the line that the Opposition puts but there is a cost to all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister acknowledge that more than half of the $2 billion tax deduction of which he spoke is due to the contributions made by employers on behalf of employees, and that in the event of those tax deductions and tax rebates being abolished, there being no occupational superannuation available, people would automatically claim more than that sum on the society security system.

—In answer to the first part of the question, I think the employers' contribution is approximately half. Senator Messner apparently thinks that comes out of thin air. From where do the employers get their contributions? Sooner or later they get it by adding to the prices they charge for their goods and services. Senator Messner apparently has a cargo cultish belief that the employers' contributions are obtained without cost to the rest of the community. In regard to the second part of the question, concerning even greater demands on the social security system, it is possible that under some circumstances there would be. While the system which the previous Government apparently was resigned to allowing in perpetuity prevailed, the people who had obtained benefits through the taxation system, amounting in total to $2 billion a year and who at the end of their superannuation scheme took a lump sum, 95 per cent of which was free of tax, still put in a claim for social security payments as well.
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh to bring his remarks to a conclusion.
—I am winding up, Mr President. This Government, to its credit, took steps last year to end the pernicious system known as double-dipping.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister seen Press reports concerning proposed talks between the Portuguese and Indonesian governments and Fretilin about a possible peacekeeping force in East Timor and a referendum on the future of East Timor? The report suggests that Australia would be asked to become involved in this process. Has the Government received any such request and if it does receive such a request what response will it make?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Portuguese Foreign Minister Jamie Garmo is reported to have said to a committee of the Portuguese Parliament on 28 March that informal contacts between Portugal and Indonesia have taken place on the situation in East Timor. The Foreign Minister noted, however, that such contacts have not been considered diplomatic negotiations. The Foreign Minister is quoted as saying that it is necessary to develop a diplomatic dialogue between Portugal and Indonesia within the provisions of the mandate conferred on the Secretary- General of the United Nations. It is also reported that the Government of Portugal intends to give further impetus to the issue of East Timor, and an overall decision of the situation is now being awaited.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of Australian participation in these talks, I do not have any information as to whether Australia has been expressly asked by anyone to do anything in this respect. If I am able to get any further information on that matter I shall supply it to the honourable senator. Australia has taken the view that the principal forum for the consideration of the East Timor issue has been the United Nations. The Australian Government has consistently supported the efforts of the Secretary-General of the United Nations to achieve a lasting settlement of the East Timor issue. At the last sessions of the United Nations General Assembly it was decided, as we know, to defer consideration of the issue until later this year. The Australian Government remains hopeful that the emergence of a less divisive and more co-operative atmosphere may ultimately lead to a satisfactory lasting settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to that part of the resolution passed by the women's caucus of the Australian Union of Students at that body's annual council in January that stated that married women are prostitutes and to the news release issued subsequently describing marriage as a form of prostitution. Will the Minister, on behalf of the Government and the community, immediately dissociate the Government from this expression of view by the Australian Union of Students? Will he, on behalf of the Government, specifically deny that marriage is a form of prostitution? Will he confirm the honourable place of marriage as the basis of most Australian families?

—I am not sure of all of the details contained in that interrogatory which was directed at me. Let me say on behalf of the Government that I affirm that married women are not prostitutes, that marriage is not a form of prostitution. I was asked to make some other denials on behalf of the Government. I do not remember the precise details of them, but I make them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ARMY FIRING RANGE: SHIRE OF COBAR

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a question asked in the Senate on 3 April 1984 and directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It concerned the effect on the Sydney-Moomba gas pipeline of the proposed Army firing range in the shire of Cobar. Is the Minister aware that the proposed firing range would result in the compulsory acquisition of two million hectares of land which would include a great number of rural properties, many of them soldier settlement blocks? Does the Minister see any conflict between the Army proposal and the original purpose of the war service land settlement scheme ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that I have received representations in relation to this proposal by the Army, which has the tentative endorsement of the New South Wales Premier. In particular, it has been put to me as Minister for Veterans' Affairs that the proposed acquisition does frustrate the arrangements and operations of the soldier settlement scheme which was introduced in 1945 by the Labor Government to provide for the settlement of suitable and eligible ex- servicemen on the land. The scheme arose from the concern of the Labor Government at the time over the wider question of what could be done for ex- servicemen and women after their service in World War II had ended and they returned to civilian life. The soldier settlement scheme was designed to regenerate rural industries which had been seriously affected during the war years. The Department of Defence is seeking to acquire two million hectares of land in the western part of New South Wales as area to be used for field training exercises, including live firing, up to brigade strength.

ANSWER.PARA: In a joint news release of 24 March 1983, the Minister for Defence, the Hon. G. Scholes, and the New South Wales Premier indicated that land in the Cobar area would be subject to an extensive study and survey with a view to the possibility of its being used as a large scale manoeuvre area. Since that time representations have been made to me, to which I have responded by writing to the Minister for Defence. I understand that the Department of Defence does not intend to submit the proposal for the Government's final consideration until 1986-approximately two years away-because of the complex social and economic issues involved and the need therefore to study it in some depth. However, it seems clear to me that some soldier settlement blocks will be affected by the proposal. Since the proposal is so recent, I have not had an opportunity to consider it other than in a superficial way. In the circumstances, I have asked the Minister for Defence, as part of the ongoing process of consultation which this Government is bound to follow, to take into account the interests of those veterans who would be affected and also to consult with the Australian Workers Union which has expressed a public view on the matter. Members of that union in the shearing and grain growing industries will be affected by the proposal. Therefore, wide-ranging problems may arise from the proposal. That is why the Government will delay its decision at least until 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate who today is representing the Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment. Whilst I realise that the Leader of the Government may not have all the details to respond to this question, nevertheless the question is concerned with matters that I understand would have been considered by Cabinet. Therefore he should have some knowledge of them. Is it a fact that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment will shortly be determining a number of appointments and re-appointments to the Australia Council? Will the Minister consider making the membership of that Council more widely representative and dispersed both geographically and by occupation and qualifications? When does the Minister anticipate making an announcement on the future membership of the Council? Before making any appointments or re-appointments, will the Minister table in Parliament the attendance records of the present members of the Australia Council?

—I understand it to be correct that a number of appointments are to be made to the Australia Council in the near future. I am asked whether the Minister will have regard to a spread of background and interests and so on in making those appointments. I am not privy to the Minister's state of mind on that matter, but I will ask him to do that and convey the burden of Senator Martin's question to him. As I understand it, the Minister will be going overseas in the next two weeks, but I believe that announcements will be made about some appointments to the Australia Council in approximately a month's time . In respect of that part of the question which asks whether the Minister will publish attendance records of the existing members of the Australia Council, I thought that information was available in the Australia Council's annual report. Perhaps it is not. I shall certainly ask the Minister whether he will consider adopting the course suggested.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of growing dissatisfaction in provincial Queensland about some Federal Government consultative committees conducting public hearings in Brisbane only? As more than half of Queensland's population lives outside the capital city, is it possible to ensure that such hearings are conducted in north, central and western Queensland to demonstrate the Federal Government's commitment to regionalism? When it is not possible for these committees to visit provincial cities, will Government departments ensure as standard procedure that travel assistance is available so that there is some regional input to policy consultation?

—I understand how people in north Queensland feel about this question, and I sympathise with them. I think the course of conduct of committees that Senator Reynolds describes is outrageous. Of course, whether it was appropriate for a particular committee to go to north Queensland or whether it was appropriate for it even to go to Brisbane would depend very much on the task set for and the composition of that committee. I am sure those are matters that ought to be taken into account. I will convey the honourable senator's request, as indicated in the question, to the appropriate Minister and see whether I can obtain an answer as quickly as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and refers to the Government's revision of the Repatriation Act. Is it true that two officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs addressed a meeting of representatives of the Returned Services League and Legacy held in Melbourne recently on the purposes and intent of a Bill to be known as the Veterans' Pension Bill? Is it also true that these departmental officers told the meeting that no totally and permanently incapacitated pensions would be granted to people over 65 years of age from a particular date; that from that same date the allowance of $4.10 to wives of TPI pensioners would be phased out, with these women being given a lump sum payment based on their entitlements; and that certain TPI pensioners were at risk of losing their TPI pensions because of a means test which would be introduced with the new legislation? If these assertions are true, can the Minister explain why officers of his Department would make such statements in light of the statements that the Minister has made that no decisions have been made and in light of his reply to Senator Colston's question on 30 March 1984?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an on-going review of the Repatriation Act, to which I have referred in other questions over the last six or eight months. That legislation would have been presented for the consideration of the Parliament in the current session except that the veterans' organisations requested that it lie on the table for a period, to which I agreed in principle without necessarily agreeing with the length of time. As I say, it was the Government's intention to introduce the legislation. The reason for that is that ex- servicemen and women are being disadvantaged by the various interpretations that are placed upon an Act which was written in 1920. Obviously the Act requires modernisation and rationalisation in respect of its application to an ever- increasing number of people who are applying for benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Macklin was kind enough to provide me with a copy of his question about half an hour before Question Time began so that I could have an opportunity of checking the facts that he has presented in his question to me. Having checked the information to which he alluded, I give to Senator Macklin and indeed the Senate a categorical assurance that the statements were falsely attributed to my departmental officers and in no way represent the views of either the Department or the Government.

In answer to the specific questions which the honourable senator raised, I think that he will be aware that under the decision of the Full Federal Court in what is known as the Bowman case, a ruling has been established that to be eligible for a TPI rate a veteran must be prevented from continuing in employment by his or her war caused disability. This test will not be changed in the new legislation.

With respect to the second question that Senator Macklin raised, a proposal has been discussed by the advisory committee on the repatriation legislation which would give recipients of the dependant's pensions the option to commute the pension to a lump sum equivalent to three years' payments. An additional option was suggested at a conference between Sir William Keys, the Prime Minister and me last week, that the dependant's benefit be paid to the veteran so that one sum would be paid rather than two particular pensions paid to the same address.
These matters are still under consideration, but none of the proposals have been put before the Government at this point. So there is absolutely no substance in the allegations that have been made.

The answer to the honourable senator's third question is that to the best of my knowledge no proposal has been discussed at any time since I have been the Minister for the means testing of the TPI pension. I think that if Senator Macklin reads closely the letter upon which he based his question he will find that there is a misunderstanding in the statement regarding the TPI pension and the means test which, of course, as the honourable senator is aware, will apply to service pensions when the matter of the assets test is ultimately considered by the Parliament. There is no proposition either by the Government or in the proposed legislation review that a means test be applied to the TPI pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to recent claims by some self-help groups for the adult unemployed in South Australia that they are failing to deliver an adequate service because of lack of funding from the Federal Government. In view of the very desperate situation many of these projects are experiencing at present, and in view of the relatively long time spent in unemployment by mature age people, will the Minister consider providing funding to these self-help groups in the next financial year? If not, what can the Minister do to ensure the survival of these very worthwhile support groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the problems facing the mature age unemployed and the financial restraints under which self-help groups operate. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has asked the Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs specifically to examine the employment training and retraining needs of mature age unemployed, particularly the longer term older unemployed, and to look at the existing programs relating to that section of the unemployed work force.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department will be making a submission to that Committee of Inquiry. One of the aspects of the submission will relate to the question of the disabilities of mature age unemployed. That Committee will complete its review by the end of this year. In the meantime, I suggest to Senator Foreman that it might be helpful if he advised those groups which are endeavouring to assist older workers who are in the unemployed category that special assistance might be available under the Commonwealth employment program and that such special assistance would be available through Commonwealth Employment Service offices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy: Has the Government or some group of senior Ministers decided to abandon the idea of imposing a resource rent tax on the Fortescue oil field in Bass Strait and settle instead for a new special levy? If so, what are the reasons for the decision? Does the Minister agree that the imposition of an additional impost by way of special tax levy effectively negates the arguments which the Australian Labor Party has advanced since 1977 about the need for a profit as opposed to a production tax approach to resource development? Does the Government intend to pursue the resource tax rent concept for other discoveries?

—Obviously Senator Chaney has been reading the newspapers. He is not following the example set by the one-time occupant of his position of Liberal Party leader in the Senate, Senator Withers, who boasted that he never read the newspapers. Senator Chaney has not taken over that rather slothful, indolent habit. Senator Chaney will have to be a bit more patient. He is not going to get a definitive answer to that sort of question. I am not going to fuel or deny newspaper speculation.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister indicate when the industry and indeed the rest of Australia will be informed of decisions which are having a significant effect on activity in Australia?
—With the caveat that the Government will not be held rigidly to this timetable, I would say in the order of three or four weeks.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware that the State Electricity Commission of Victoria , in a report recorded in the Age in December, claimed that putting power cables underground for the Yarra valley and Merri Creek valley is too expensive at $36m and so power lines will be put above ground at the cost of $5m? Is the Minister aware that this year the Victorian State Electricity Commission estimates its payments for the Mount Macedon and East Trentham fires will amount to over $100m and that the Electricity Trust of South Australia may well face enormous compensation payouts after the findings of the inquest into the Ash Wednesday fires? Does the Minister agree that $30m outlay to prevent possible fires and subsequent hideous costs in dollars and lives is not unreasonable compared with the outlay? Given that the Federal Government's payment of many millions of dollars as compensation to Victoria and South Australia after the recent bush fires mean that the Federal Government has a real concern to promote the prevention of further loss of life and huge expenditure, will this Government give consideration to raising these issues with the Victorian Government, the South Australian Government and indeed all State governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At one stage-I think it was last year-I had a piece of paper lying around with some information on this matter. It does not seem to be here any more. But the figures quoted by Senator Crowley have sufficient merit to warrant some further investigation of this. Of course, it is a matter either for the various electricity commissions or the State governments which ultimately control them, not for the Commonwealth Government, to make this sort of policy decision. It is the practice in at least some States, Victoria being one of them , that the electricity commissions pay insurance premiums to protect themselves against claims such as those lodged last year and in previous years. Indeed, I remember one case when there was a fire in the Western Districts and the discredited former Prime Minister's brother-in-law collected $180,000 in full compensation for the loss caused by the fire, then double dipped with a 4 per cent loan from the Commonwealth and State governments.

ANSWER.PARA: I will ask the Department to do a study on the apparent economics of burying power lines or continuing to pay insurance premiums against the risks of liability should overhead lines cause fires. Depending on the outcome of that review, I may or may not seek to raise the matter at a future meeting of the Australian Minerals and Energy Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time yesterday Senator McIntosh asked me a question about the compilation on a national basis of statistics on industrial accidents. I am now in a position to provide the following further information to the honourable senator. The Australian Bureau of Statistics collects occupational health and safety data through State offices. However, this data is generated from information provided under workers compensation legislation in each State. Because of differences in the legislation, coverage and classification of workers and methods of presentation, there is great difficulty in using this data to paint a national picture. Also, the statistics collected relate only to people covered by the State workers compensation legislation and do not cover large numbers of employees, such as most self-employed persons, Commonwealth Government employees or employees covered under separate legislation. The standardisation program initiated by the ABS has resulted in some upgrading of the available information . Despite these initiatives, while it must rely on existing administrative systems, it will not be able to produce the type of data sought by the many users in the field. The Government has established an Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission which is investigating these dificiencies amongst other issues in this area.

—At Question Time yesterday Senator Peter Rae asked me a question relating to the testing by Customs in Melbourne of imported fabrics, which was supplementary to a question asked on an early date. I can now provide the following further answer to Senator Rae. I undertook to investigate a claim that the Melbourne branch of the Australian Customs Service is refusing to accept reports of the Australian Wool Testing Authority on the composition of certain fabrics. The Melbourne branch of the Customs Service has accepted as recently as yesterday afternoon Australian Wool Testing Authority test results on fabrics. The Service can only recognise the results of the analysis of goods where samples have been drawn under the supervision of an officer of the Customs Service in accordance with section 218 of the Act and the regulations thereunder. It is a fact that some importers have submitted to Customs reports of analyses by the Australian Wool Testing Authority, but on samples of goods not subject to the control of Customs. The Australian Customs Service, while not doubting the technical validity of such analyses, does not accept them for official purposes.

DEBATE.TITLE: 'THE STRATEGIC BASIS OF AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE POLICY'

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time yesterday Senator Messner asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, who authorised the distribution of the Defence Committee document 'The Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy'. The answer is as follows: The distribution of the document was authorised by the Chairman of the Defence Committee, who is the Secretary of the Department of Defence, for those copies issued within the departments of Defence and Defence Support, to the members of the Defence Committee and certain of their senior officers, to senior intelligence authorities and to the Secretary of the Department of Finance. The Minister for Defence authorised the issue of copies to the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. The distribution of copies for Cabinet was authorised by the Cabinet Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator MacGibbon asked me a question concerning statements made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the retiring Chief of Defence Force Staff, Sir Neville McNamara, on the nature of the super-powers' strategic arsenals. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer: The essential point is that the super -powers' nuclear forces are asymmetric. In strategic weaponry, for example, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has more land based intercontinental ballistic missiles than the United States of America, whereas the United States has more missiles on board submarines and more long range bombers than has the Soviet Union. These differences mean that attempts to quantify such abstract notions as the theoretical destructive potentials of the various components of the super-powers' nuclear arsenals, and to make comparisons between their respective overall destructive capabilities, are fraught with difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: The obvious conclusion is that we should not waste time in unproductive, complex and frequently confusing argument over who is or is not ahead, whatever that means. It would be better to recognise that both super-powers have sufficient capability to destroy both themselves and the world many times over and that it is far better to work unremittingly, as the Government does, for real progress in arms control and for disarmament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday a question was asked by Senator Boswell of Senator Gietzelt, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, concerning coastal surveillance issues. Since that now falls within the portfolio of the Special Minister of State, I am able to reply to him as follows: With regard to the first part of the question, the Government has not done a sweetheart deal with Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd. It is proposed that the areas to be covered by Skywest be extended but with retention of current flying hours. This is a matter for negotiation. It was deemed administratively more simple to vary the scope of Skywest's existing contract than to cancel all contracts and draw up a new one. The simple fact is that there is, as a result of the Department of Health's reduced requirements for littoral surveillance, necessity for less hours to be flown. There was therefore no need to recall tenders when existing contracts would suffice.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of Senator Boswell's question related to alleged deficiencies in Skywest's strike aircraft radar system. The answer is that radar operates regardless of whether it is day or night. The Nomad aircraft did not conduct regular night surveillance either. It was used on trial night surveillance exercises and the Special Minister of State has said that the investigations of this will continue.

Senator Boswell's third question was premised on the assumption that search and rescue was one of the major puposes of the Government's coastal surveillance program. This is not the case. It is the responsibility of a number of State and Commonwealth agencies. Assistance will be given with this whenever it is sought.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISIT TO JAPAN BY AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Japan. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report relates to the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Japan from 23 October to 29 October last year led by Mr Scott, a member of the House of Representatives. This report highlights many of the advantages that accrue to members from such visits. The only possible way that members of this Parliament can adequately be informed of other nations and of the factors that influence their relations with Australia is through visits of this nature. Members of this delegation were able to obtain comprehensive explanations of many of the matters which are of primary importance to Australia and Japan and to witness at first hand the mechanics of these matters. After all, Japan is Australia's largest trading partner and it has many other things to offer in terms of cultural heritage and tourist dollars. If Australia wants Japan to provide a market for its goods and it wants both Japanese people and goods to come here, it is essential that members of the Federal Parliament have a knowledge of what is entailed and take a vital interest in international trade, especially the Japanese trade, and in the Japanese people themselves. Ill-informed discussion on international issues by members only detracts from the input into decisions which affect the very sensitive balance that Australia and Japan particularly have evolved on two points, trade and tourism.

It is a visit of this kind that reinforces links that have taken years to build and refine to their current standard. Just as the Japanese must inform Australians of Japanese ways, and they do this by coming to Australia and seeing what Australia has to offer and how readily those offerings fit in with their way of life, Australians must also participate in reciprocal arrangements and inform the Japanese of Australian opinions and decisions by taking them to Japan .

I have every confidence that the members of this delegation are far better informed by the visit than through any studies they might have made elsewhere. Likewise, I am convinced that the delegation created a good deal of interest in Australia and what Australia could provide. In this regard, I can only reiterate how extremely worthwhile and beneficial these exchanges are and how grateful I am to the Presiding Officers of the Japanese Diet and particularly to the Japanese House which invited us for extending the original invitation. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighth report of the Publications Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Elstob)-by leave-agreed to:
That the report be adopted.

That the Senate take note of the paper.
