DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF AUSTRALIA'S PEACE TIME COASTAL SURVEILLANCE AND PROTECTION ARRANGEMENTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Senator Peter Rae:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this report and ministerial statement on coastal surveillance I want to express concern regarding the attitude of the Federal Government to the surveillance of the Great Barrier Reef and the treatment of Queensland companies in this regard. The statement which was brought down by the Government is of particular importance to the people of Queensland and I suppose for that matter to everyone who lives in northern Australia. The statement by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) is remarkable for what it does not contain. It does not say that surveillance in Australia has been downgraded along the Great Barrier Reef. It does not say that lives could be at risk because search and rescue operations are no longer to be part of surveillance duties. It does not say that the proposed radars to be fitted to the 15-year-old Shrike Commanders will have a capacity to search only 120 degrees to one side of the aircraft. I wonder what might happen to somebody who was lost at sea on the other side of the aircraft.
—Why don't you get Joh to go up and look out for them?
—I am sure if my husband were flying up there he would do a very good job, Senator Button. He was in an aircraft race there just recently. Unfortunately, he did not win.
—I feel sorry for people who beat him, Senator.

—Nothing happened about that. I want to keep on with my speech on this subject. The latest surveillance aircraft has the capacity to search 360 degrees in all weather day and night. The report certainly does not address the plight of the 80 people who will be put on the dole queues. That is a problem in these days of unemployment. The statement does not refer to Mr Beazley's findings on page 4-9 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Five State Governments (NSW, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia) and all of the Commonwealth's relevant Departments considered that the present surveillance and protection system was . . . adequate . . .

That quote relates to the present surveillance system. Finally, the statement does not refer to the conclusions reached by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in its 1982-83 report. That report states:

The professionalism of the crews and their use of sophisticated technical equipment, such as 360 degree search radar and a global navigation system, ensure that the reports are accurate, comprehensive and not greatly affected by poor visibility.
A recent development has been the use of a Coastwatch Nomad aircraft for night surveillance. The 360 degree search radar and global navigation system are essential for this purpose.

What the statement makes clear is that an inferior radar system is to be used which has less than half the capacity of the present system. To top it off, the statement indicated that no tenders have been called and government funds are being spent at the whim of a Minister without the test of public scrutiny.

Many people in north Queensland are very concerned at what they see as cutbacks in aerial surveillance. In view of the incursion of Indonesia into Papua New Guinea and the defence cutbacks in so many areas I consider that we definitely need aerial surveillance. There is also an increased need for surveillance because of the amount of drugs being flown into north Queensland. Mr Beazley, in his report, said that almost 50 per cent of Customs follow-up emanated from the Great Barrier Reef reports and 100 per cent of prosecutions over a period of two years came from the same source. Yet the Federal Government maintains that new arrangements will enhance concentration on drug smuggling in northern Australia. Mr Beazley also stated that visual surveillance adds to information on patterns on the Great Barrier Reef. Our radar operators maintain that 70 per cent of contacts are made via radar, I feel that the Government certainly should be very concerned at maintaining vital air surveillance and giving better protection to the people of the north.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five minutes is quite insufficient in which to discuss a report of such urgency as the report on Australia's peacetime coastal surveillance and protection arrangements. I believe that debate on the report should be adjourned and brought on again when the Senate meets in three weeks time when sufficient time will be available to debate this report much more widely. When one inquires of the Parliamentary Library as to copies of the report one is told that they are not available and will not be available for 10 days. So it seems that some people have copies of the report and some do not.

SPEECH.PARA: The Beazley report as I will term it is a very interesting report and inquiry carried out by the Minister for Aviation. Obviously, he fully realises the necessity not only for a review but also for stepping up surveillance in the north. He says in that report:

In particular, the review also found that greater efforts probably need to be made in northern Australia to counter drug smuggling. This would be done while maintaining effective levels of surveillance against breaches of quarantine, fisheries, environmental and immigration regulations.

If this is to be the result of this inquiry, I commend the Minister. Honourable senators may recall that for a long time now I have indicated that I believe that the surveillance and the security of the north are quite insufficient. I believe that the number of Customs officers is stretched far too thinly around the northern coast. I believe that for surveillance to be carried out only in the daylight hours is quite insufficient and I note the thought that there should be night surveillance. This is only reasonable because it is only a little while ago that the people on the north coast used to set their watches by the time that the surveillance aircraft flew along the north coast. How ridiculous. Of course there are reports now of unusual movement along the north coast. When I say 'unusual movement' I mean that there have been reports of the sound of aircraft at night when no aircraft have been reported in the area. There have been continuing suggestions that there are signs of aircraft landing on the 900 or more small or remote strips throughout the north where no one lives. There are reports of tyre tracks on those strips without any reason.

I note also that the Beazley report has put the responsibility for surveillance in the hands of the Federal Police. I support that move also. Putting responsibility into the hands of the Federal Police will give it strength and recognition of a much superior role than it now has. I notice also that a standing committee will be formed in which various organisations-Federal State and Territory-will participate. The Government has decided that a coastal protection unit will be established within the Australian Federal Police with responsibility for directing and co-ordinating overall coastal surveillance response and enforcement. The unit will operate within the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre, which is an extremely wise move because very strong liaison will develop with the Department of Transport which is responsible for the maritime safety, search and rescue and associated functions.

I can say no more on this report in five minutes other than, as I said, that I find it most interesting. I think it is a carefully prepared report into which a lot of thought has gone. I have no doubt that other honourable senators who are interested in northern coastal surveillance and security will support me in my call to have debate on this report adjourned today and have it brought on again for debate in some three weeks time, on the first Thursday, under General Business, whereupon we will be able to debate it more fully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear Senator Kilgariff being critical of coastal surveillance under the present Government as I was in the last four or five years of the Liberal Government. However, it is very pleasing to note that he does see a move towards an improvement of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, the Federal Government's new coastal surveillance arrangements offer a well co-ordinated and effective approach to safeguarding our nation against breaches of quarantine, fisheries, Customs, environmental, immigration and health regulations. I do not think there is any doubt that the report of the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) on Australia's peacetime coastal surveillance and protection arrangements is by far the most complete and thorough set of recommendations we have ever had. I commend also the establishment of the coastal protection unit within the Australian Federal Police. This means that officers will be readily available not only to detect offenders but also to apprehend them when they are detected. Honourable senators will recall that under the old system offenders could only be detected and reported. This certainly was not a satisfactory situation.

In response to this unsatisfactory situation, a major review was undertaken of how our nation's surveillance needs could not be met. I think it is worth noting that the Beazley review worked in very close consultation with the surveillance needs expressed by Federal government departments and both State and Territory government departments. In line with their well considered needs, it was decided to rationalise contract aerial surveillance arrangements. The existing 21,000 hours per annum were cut to 14,600. But I make the point that these reductions were achieved after discussions with all government departments which make use of the coastal surveillance facilities. As has been mentioned by my colleague, previous arrangements were that surveillance flights occurred regularly and along the coast. New arrangements mean that flights will be random and will be out from the coast to detect offences before the offenders reach the shore.

Much has been made of the detrimental effects of the system's rationalisation in terms of lost jobs and terminated contracts. This is no more so than in the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory News had a field day over recent events. Monday's editorial is a scathing criticism of the new policy. It says:
That--
That is, the coastline from Karratha in Western Australia to the Great Barrier Reef--
is an enormous area to patrol, the business of providing effective surveillance, complicated.

But we must note that Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd currently provides civil surveillance along the Western Australian and Queensland north coasts and the addition of the Northern Territory sector will not be a difficult management task. Skywest has 11 sophisticated Rockwell Shrike Commander aircraft in service every day on coast watch duties from Broome in Western Australia to Townsville, plus three back-up Shrike Commanders located at Townsville, Bamaga and Broome. Some of these aircraft and the personnel from them will be redeployed into Darwin as a result of the changes.

Skywest is a rapidly expanding company which has only recently taken over East- West Airlines and H.C. Sleigh Ltd. It is well on its way to being the third biggest airline in Australia. The company's expansion in the Northern Territory will, I am sure, have significant benefits for the Territory. I hope the Northern Territory Government gives every assistance to the new contractor. There was a reason why the contract did not go to tender. Skywest's existing contract runs until March 1986 and with the reduction in requirements by the Government, that firm can meet all the existing work load. Furthermore, the assessment of the Department of Transport in the light of its experience in the field of coastal surveillance since 1978 was that no other firm would be able to redeploy its resources with the necessary expertise in the time available. I should point out that the Federal Government took note of the benefits and economies of the current private contract coastal surveillance system. Had the Government not upheld the principle of the contract system, the loss to the private aviation industry would have been substantial.

In another article, the Northern Territory News claims that the report gave scant attention to the frequency of aerial surveillance for the detection of quarantine breaches. The report in fact recommended the retention of the user pays principle. The Department of Health, relying on experience of many years, judged that it could maintain a safe level of surveillance with a reduced number of flights. That internal review was undertaken by the Department of Health in 1983. There are many other matters that I would like to deal with in respect of this report but I think it appropriate that I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I intend to adjourn the debate at the conclusion of just a very few words on the subject of surveillance. I think that all Australians should be aware of this enormously important matter which covers a very wide field and which is referable in particular to the north-east, the north-west and the north of this continent. Surveillance is significant in the control of drug trafficking in this country. As we were discussing only a day or two ago, it is equally significant in quarantine terms in the control of various diseases which affect both plant life and animal life. It is also of great significance in our method of combating possible on-shore and off-shore terrorist attacks against facilities in this country. Surveillance also has a relevance to our widespread fishing industry and to the illegal entry of persons to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is also significant to remind ourselves, as Senator Bjelke- Petersen did, that five States and the Commonwealth itself are of the opinion that the measure of surveillance, generally speaking, is acceptable. Yet, there is equally the view that it is certainly no more than should be expected. We should be concerned that there appears to be a downgrading of surveillance activity, in spite of the encouraging reference by Senator Robertson to the new Sky West Shrike Commander aircraft. My information seems to indicate that this aircraft does not compare favourably with the Nomad aircraft in terms of a capacity to survey the coastline and reach significant distances off-shore and in terms of highly sophisticated radar equipment. Yet the Nomad aircraft has been abandoned for search and control work. As Senator Robertson indicated, there are some reasons for this. However, I wonder why, as I have been advised, no tenders were called. It seems unreal and unreasonable that a decision should have been arrived at without looking at competitors which could supply the equipment necessary to perform the surveillance necessary in that part of Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 April, on motion by Senator Martin:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate- (a) draws the Government's attention to the campaign by Amnesty International against torture and the evidence provided of the practice of various forms of torture in the 1980's in at least 98 countries;
(b) calls on the Australian Government to assert influence to dissuade governments from continuing to use or to connive in the practice of torture within their national boundaries;
(c) urges the Australian Government to support the United Nations Voluntary Fund for victims of torture; and
(d) requests the Australian Government to seek the expediting of the completion of the proposed international covenant against torture.

I trust that the motion will have the support of the Senate and will be part of the continuing campaign which Amnesty International is waging on the pressing problem of torture in this world. I will explain the points of this motion and make some general remarks about the position of torture in other countries. I will be supported by other speakers from all political parties who are also pledged to this campaign.

The Amnesty organisation has of course been campaigning against torture and other vices of a similar nature in this world for many years, but it is now launching a new campaign. It is basing that campaign partly on the evidence which has been accumulated. It deals primarily with torture in the 1980s. It remains a very bad and serious problem. Yesterday the Amnesty organisation published a report entitled 'Torture in the Eighties'. It is a horrifying record of the extent to which torture is taking place throughout the world. Indeed, torture occurs in 98 countries. Because there are many countries large and small it is important to realise that those countries in which torture takes place represent 85 per cent of the population of the world. They are the larger countries of the world; torture in fact occurs in all five continents, with the one blessed exception of Australia, the continent which has the opportunity to produce this book on behalf of Amnesty International. Thus it can be seen that the problem is very widespread in the world.

Since 1980 the Amnesty organisation on a world-wide basis has investigated and taken action on behalf of 2,687 torture cases covering a total of 45 countries. As honourable senators will see, there are many other countries where Amnesty would wish to take the same sort of action. Thus the first part of this motion is designed to bring forward this campaign, to urge people to read this report, to act in accordance with its recommendations and to try to stop torture throughout the world.

The second part of the resolution relates to the Australian Government and the influence it can exercise as a democratic decent country to help the termination of this 'disease' which is a breach of all the things civilised communities should stand for. We know that respective Australian governments from time to time have taken strong stands on human rights issues and they are to be encouraged to do so. I particularly urge this Government, as I hope this Senate will, to do so in respect of torture in accordance with the terms of this motion .

In the last few days there has been some Press speculation about changes in the present Government's policy in regard to human rights. There has been a suggestion that the Government's policy might be somewhat 'toned down' to quote an editorial. I was pleased to see yesterday the clear statement by the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, in answer to a question asking whether the Australian Labor Party would dilute its strong support for human rights in its foreign affairs platform. He answered in this way:

Accordingly, I respond by declaring that there is absolutely no change in the attitude or the practices of this Government as against the declared intentions, attitudes and practices of the Labor Party in this Parliament when in opposition .

The view which has been taken on a completely non-Party basis for years is that human rights remain an important part of foreign affairs policy for Australia. As one of the few democracies in the world, we take that stand most strongly. To complete that assurance one has only to read the statement which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made to the Amnesty group at its last annual meeting two months ago when he said:
The Government attaches a strong priority to human rights issues.

The Government has pursued a number of cases of political prisoners and has supported relevant United Nations initiatives on human rights. We have expressed concern about human rights violations to a variety of governments of different ideological persuasions and in different areas of the world, whose relations with Australia are of differing degrees of closeness.

One welcomes that and also the continuing use of the influence of Australia in dealing with governments, particularly in respect of this problem. It is prevalent in nations which are close to us and countries with which we have strong economic and cultural ties. The third part of the motion relates to the support which we urge for the United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement from the Department of Foreign Affairs giving some information about that fund.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
UN VOLUNTARY FUND FOR THE VICTIMS OF TORTURE

The United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture was established through General Assembly resolution 36/151 of 16 December 1981 to receive voluntary contributions in order to provide humanitarian assistance to victims of torture and their relatives.
The Voluntary Fund is administered by the Secretary-General with the advice of a Board of Trustees composed of five members appointed by the Secretary-General and acting in their personal capacity.

The Secretary-General stated in a message to the first session of the Board of Trustees that the Voluntary Fund would 'provide an excellent opportunity to demonstrate to the peoples of the world that the United Nations, in addition to its role as the conscience of mankind in promotion respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, is able to respond in a concrete way to the needs arising from violations of human rights''.
So far the fund has attracted a limited degree of international support, mainly from Nordic countries as follows:

Greece 5,000 Luxembourg 2,019.84 Netherlands 45,000 Norway 100,000 Sweden 150,000 Individuals 200

TALK.START.PARA: —That short report points out that not a great amount of money has yet been contributed to the fund. The money has come mostly from European countries, particularly Scandinavian nations. Useful contributions have been made to the fund and it is important not only that torture should be stopped but that something should be done to help the victims of torture-not only the people who are injured but their families and others who suffer as a consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth part of the motion, with which I shall deal in a little more detail later, relates to expediting the completion of the proposed international covenant against torture. It has taken, one might say, a tortuous route in trying to get to the position of becoming a covenant. It has been discussed by international organisations over the years. It is sad to see the way in which reservations are held by some countries and the nitpicking that takes place as to the terms of a covenant which should be in existence. The adoption of a covenant alone will not be adequate to deal with the position, but it puts on an international plane the offence felt by the civilised world against torture. We should try to get such a covenant in place as soon as possible. Australia has played a fairly effective and positive part in securing this covenant and it now needs to be pushed along.

I turn from the motion to say a few words on the subject of Amnesty. No doubt other members of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International will give the Senate more specific details. I hope the honourable senators will read the group 's report to appreciate the gravity of the situation. Torture has been a long standing problem in the world. It is certainly not new. Up to the eighteenth century it was fairly prevalent. For many years after that torture declined sharply. Unfortunately, in the twentieth century, and in the time of the last World War, there were dreadful examples of torture, often leading to people's deaths. Following that war international organisations and the United Nations, in its Declaration of Human Rights, proceeded to take steps to try to ensure that this should not happen again. Unfortunately in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s other countries have come to adopt the practice of torture. Dictatorships of all sorts that prevail in the world have been determined to obtain information from prisoners and to use the torture weapon to do it.
The definition of torture adopted by Amnesty International is:
The systematic and deliberate infliction of acute pain in any form by one person on another or on a third person in order to accomplish the purpose of the former against the will of the latter.

It is a matter in which the power of the State and of its police forces can be misused for the purpose of obtaining information. It is not only states that are the offenders. Often independent organisations within a country inflict torture. It is not merely a matter of dealing with states as the states do not often control the situation within their own territory. Amnesty International in its 1981 report said:

Torture is used extensively to obtain information, forced confessions and to punish, intimidate and terrorise. Torture humiliates the victim and dehumanises the torturer. Among the techniques reported during the year were: hanging people upside down and pouring water into their nostrils; electric shocks; beating the soles of the feet; smashing toes and fingers with a hammer; rape; forcing prisoners to eat live frogs and beetles; pushing people's heads into a bathtub filled with water, blood, vomit, excrement and food; deprivation of sleep; mock executions; and threats against relatives, including children. In some countries certain methods, such as flogging and amputation, were carried out in public.
That gives a rough series of examples.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt it was amputation without the benefit of anaesthetic.

—There is of course no benefit of anything like that. There is a great variety of modern skills which can be used in the carrying out of torture. The opportunity has been taken by some organisations to create pre-conditions for torture. The Amnesty report points out that the accumulated evidence also gives a clear picture of the pre-conditions for torture. Emergency or other special legislation that allows wide powers of arrest and detention may facilitate torture. Suspects can be held on the vaguest of suspicions. Crimes against the state are given broad elastic definitions. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Torture often occurs during a detainee's first days in custody. Those vulnerable hours are usually spent incommunicado, when the security forces maintain total control over the fate of the detainee, and deny access to relatives, lawyers or independent doctors.

As we all know, torture has become a skill which many countries have perfected in recent years. The fact that torture has such influence in the world is known partly because of the work of the Amnesty organisation and its splendid research team in London and the work of other organisations, such as the International Commission of Jurists, who have managed to expose so many of the things that have been done. The work of such organisations also owes a lot to the bravery of informants, of victims, of people who have made statements. People have presented themselves so that doctors are able to see the results of torture. These things and the bravery of non-government organisations in countries practising torture have had an effect. People have risked their own lives and have put themselves in danger of being subjected to torture by standing up and speaking. There are many martyrs to this cause. However, it is fortunate that information has come along and often had the effect of causing governments to take action to save themselves from international humiliation.

Torture can never be justified. There can never be a case for torture. Sometimes states try to find explanations for torture and cite the security situation. However, I repeat that there can never be any justification for the use of torture. It is an offence against the inherent dignity of human beings and we know it must be stamped out. In regard to the form of such torture, there is a great variety. One sees in the report, examples of the blinding of people in Bihar in India when 35 people were blinded by the police. One can find records of the misuse of psychiatry in the Soviet Union as well as the use of torture in Timor by the Indonesian authorities. The report draws attention to the statement in the secret Indonesian army manual of which Amnesty obtained possession which says:
If the use of force in interrogation is required there should not be a member of the local population present to witness it so that the antipathy of the people is not aroused.

I am sure that that form of explanation applies to many other countries too. One of the unfortunate situations is that whereas in democratic countries, such as in Europe, human rights organisations are able to do a lot when occasional incidents of torture are found, regrettably this is not the case in the Americas . The American convention of human rights applies to all the American countries, but little has been done there to curb the practice of torture. A change can occur when a government is overthrown or is voted out in occasional democratic elections. One then obtains some exposure of the situation in that country. Regrettably, otherwise countries deny any torture in their ranks. They proceed to support resolutions deploring torture in international assemblies while at the same time practicing it. I think only one country in South America, Costa Rica, has no evidence of torture being used.

Let me say this about the international efforts which are being made, which I hope we will support. For three decades all kinds of resolutions have been carried and all kinds of covenants have been agreed to, for instance, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights; the Geneva Convention, dealing mainly with the prohibition of the use of torture in war; and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, of Article 7 which forbids torture. There are many other efforts. There are at the moment two new international instruments which are proposed and which will be useful in themselves and of which Amnesty urges support. The first is the draft convention against torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, which I have mentioned already, and which would give legal, binding force to the standards included in the declaration against torture for states which ratified the convention. It would establish universal jurisdiction, meaning that an alleged torturer could be brought to justice wherever he or she might be and whatever the nationality of the perpetrator or the victims. It could provide that no one shall be forcibly returned to a country where he might reasonably be expected to risk being tortured. That, in itself, would be a very valuable document to be accepted by the world community.

The second is the draft body of principles for the protection of all persons under any form of detention or imprisonment, which would establish additional safeguards. It could provide, for example, that relatives should be promptly informed of the whereabouts of prisoners, that prisoners should be promptly informed of their rights, that there should be regular, independent visits of inspections to places of detention and that there should be inquests into deaths in custody. These are I think very important standards for the world community to adopt.

Let me say finally that in the report before us are 12 specific proposals which Amnesty makes and to which I invite the attention of honourable senators. I will read the headings briefly. They are all valuable suggestions. The first is: ' Official condemnation of torture'-that the authorities in each country should demonstrate their opposition by such declarations. The second is: 'Limits on incommunicado detention'-that detainees should be able to contact people outside who can help them when they are in prison. The third is: 'No secret detention'- that there should not be secret centres kept where people can disappear. Disappearance is one of the terrible problems in this world. If we do not know where the person is, it is very difficult to take any steps. The fourth is: ' Safeguards during interrogation and custody'. This is something which obviously needs to be improved in most countries. The fifth is: 'Independent investigation of reports of torture'-not by the Government concerned but by people and bodies and international bodies outside. The sixth is: 'No use of statements extracted under torture'-it being forbidden in law to use in legal proceedings those confessions obtained through the use of torture. The seventh is: 'Prohibition of torture in law'-making it a punishable offence which can be dealt with under criminal law. The eighth is: 'Prosecution of alleged torturers'-the idea of this being that there should be no haven for torturers, that wherever they are in the world they can be prosecuted for actions which are crimes against humanity. The ninth is: 'Training procedures'-it should be specifically ensured that officials who have custody of or who interrogate prisoners, do not use torture. The tenth is: 'Compensation and Rehabilitation'-for victims of torture. I have mentioned in the motion that we propose something of a practical use in that way. The eleventh is: 'International response'-governments should use all available channels through intergovernment mechanisms to investigate all reports of torture and to try to facilitate the stopping of it. The twelfth is: ' Ratification of international instruments'-such as I have referred to.

Those are the practical conclusions which this terrifying report brings to our attention. I see the media are here in no strength today. The regrettable thing is that the Australian media want to report this Parliament only when we scrap and squabble and not when there is some unity and some desire to seek out something of national and international importance. I hope the media will take an interest in this campaign. I hope they will take note of what people are saying here today, and will do their duty to promote in Australia a better knowledge of the situation abroad and add resolution, because it is political will throughout the world that will be necessary to ensure that torture comes to an end. We must have the political will. Our governments must have the political will. We must have some courage of our convictions when other people suffer for their lives for their convictions. I urge honourable senators to support this motion and to do what they can to spread the knowledge of this problem throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Missen. I think my contribution will be brief, and I will try to take an approach that will avoid duplication. It seems to me to be unnecessary in this debate, and for that matter in any other, for people to get up one after another and say the same thing. I have no doubt that colleagues on both sides of the chamber will deal with the Amnesty International report 'Against Torture' in detail and give information about the proposed campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen drew to attention in his contribution that we are looking at this in a bipartisan way. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the motion calls for some action. In other words it is not one of these motherhood motions with which everybody agrees and then does very little. It is also not a motion to ease our consciences, such as with our once a week Christians who are good for one day of the week and then go away and enjoy themselves, shall we say , for the rest of the time. We are looking for three specific actions from the Government. I think it is worth while reading those again, although Senator Missen has read the motion. It states:
That the Senate- (b) calls on the Australian Government to assert influence to dissuade governments from continuing to use or to connive in the practice of torture within their national boundaries;
(c) urges the Australian Government to support the United Nations Voluntary Fund for victims of torture; and
(d) requests the Australian Government to seek the expediting of the completion of the proposed international covenant against torture.

The first part of the motion deals with the report on the campaign. I believe the report is an excellent document, and I commend it for the study of all honourable senators, particularly the early part of it. I believe that its matter of fact style is far more dramatic than an emotive style. I think the examples which are put forward in a very matter of fact manner shock us more than if they were described with emotive language. Page 4 of the report sums up what we might call the philosophy or the goals of the campaign and sums up the report itself. It states:

Torture can be stopped. The international legal framework for its abolition exists, as do the investigative methods to verify and expose it. What is lacking is the political will of governments to stop torturing people. It is as simple and as difficult as that. Amnesty International hopes that this new report about torture as well as its continuing campaign against torture will contribute to creating this political will so that our generation can banish torture from the earth.

One might ask how we should define torture. It is very difficult to get a precise definition, although one is given in the report. Perhaps we could simply say that the key elements of the definition are that there is some sort of mental or physical suffering or pain. There is a recognition here of the psychological torture which affects people. I personally believe the psychological torture to be the most abhorrent. Unfortunately it is the most successful. There are numerous examples given throughout the report of psychological torture with drugs and without drugs. It is interesting to see the refinements that have been introduced, particularly in the 'without drugs' section of the psychological torture. I suppose this is the sort of thing that has been popularised, if one can use that word, by spy stories and films that come before us. The second element is the deliberateness of the act. In other words it must be intentional, not simply part of war or not simply part of the application of 'normal' law and order. The third element is the fact that the act had purpose. The purpose in most cases is to get information or to get a confession from someone or to indicate to the people watching the torture, or seeing the effects of it afterwards, that torture has been carried out.

The examples that have been given in the report would chill the blood simply by reading them through. They seem to be directed against an individual or through an individual. The torture is effected on a person to inflict pain on him, or is inflicted on someone else to cause suffering to him. In other words, the torture might be effected on a wife to make a husband confess or give information, or it might be carried out on children to make parents give information. There is no mention of group torture; of the situation in East Timor, for example, where people were starved to death by the Indonesians. It seems to me that this would meet the requirements of the definition as it is explained in the report. It was a deliberate attempt to starve people to death and it was done with a purpose-to suppress the so-called uprising. It was clearly done to inflict suffering on the people of East Timor and to indicate to them who would be the masters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge the contribution made by Senator Kilgariff, who agrees with the proposition. Mention is made in the report of the rape and beating of Tamils in Sri Lanka. That also seems to meet the criteria but I suppose because each of the cases was taken individually we came to consider them all as an individual case. I put the proposition to the Senate: Why is this motion necessary; why is it necessary for Senator Missen to come into this place , to put such a proposition and for others to support it? That is a question we ought to contemplate. What are some possible answers? Is it simply apathy-the great Australian malaise, 'she'll be right', or the 'couldn't care less' syndrome; it has nothing to do with us and we could not care less what happens outside our shores? I find it rather disturbing to think that we had a debate yesterday, which ran on into today, about children seeing tapes which were regarded as undesirable for them. There was a great deal of heated debate on this issue. Yet, to use the same sort of analogy, we seem to be quite happy for children to sit and watch their mothers being raped-not see pictures of it. This does not arouse the same amount of heated debate as looking at some pornographic rubbish that is brought into our country. That is the level at which we have to consider this matter. Surely one is far more obscene than the other.

SPEECH.PARA: The second proposition might be that it is nothing to do with us at all. Certain rationalisations are brought forward in support of that proposition: 'I believe in the philosophy of live and let live'; 'I believe in minding my own business'; and 'I don't interfere with others and I don't want them to interfere with me'. That is the sort of rationalisation normally used by a person who lives in an enlightened country, who is well fed, well housed and safe from the sort of torture-since we are looking at that particular issue-that goes on in the rest of the world.

The next proposition might be: 'Well, it doesn't happen in Australia so it is not our concern'. Mind you, I think it is fair to say that some of the acts by some police against what they call troublemakers might qualify. I can think of a number of teenagers who have been tortured by some police-certainly not all-so that they might take certain actions or provide confessions at appropriate times . Certainly acts against Aboriginal people would qualify, even at present. Certainly in the early days, and even in the not so early days, Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, and no doubt in the rest of Australia, were tortured. We should be ashamed of this, and we are, but we ought to recognise it . The next proposition is: 'Well, those countries are different; they are not the same as us. If their governments allow it, it must be okay'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or life is cheap, in fact.

—Yes. 'They have a different religion and their religion allows this sort of thing to happen, so it must be all right and we shall accept it'. An extraordinary proposition put by some people is that the people in those countries are of a different colour and do not feel the same as we do, perhaps they do not feel pain the same as we do, and other such complete and utter nonsense. These are the sorts of rationalisations used. Unfortunately another approach might be what we call the 'so what?' syndrome. I am convinced that we in Australia have become desensitised. We pretty much compare what we see happening overseas to a movie or a television show we have seen. The same syndrome applies in regard to appeals such as Austcare and Freedom from Hunger with which some of us are associated. We find it more and more difficult to convince people, because they are becoming immune to suffering, that they ought to assist others less advantaged overseas. We show them pictures of babies dying and pictures of hundreds of people starving to death, and they shrug their shoulders. They are what I call desensitised. Unfortunately, a good deal of this desensitisation is as a result of the news-not films and commentaries but just seeing the brutality of actions overseas which are conveyed to us so explicitly on the news media. I do not want to be accused of criticising any of the media in particular but some of the things that we see on television are far more obscene than the extraordinary actions we are likely to see on videos.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course another group will say that it is necessary to maintain order. Others , in maintaining order, will say: 'We need to get information to keep down subversion, we need to torture this person because we have to find out where the rest of his companions are'. The same group of people would say they need an example to deter others. I believe this is one of the most dangerous rationalisations that can be used-'We need to set an example; if we chop off this man's hands, other people might not thieve'. He certainly will not do it again, but does it deter anyone else? We accept this proposition. If a person is flogged, others will see that flogging and may be deterred from action. In the Sri Lankan situation, as it has been reported to me-I can only give the information second hand-some groups seem to think that if they rape the women of the village and brutally attack the men the others in that same village will say they now recognise who are the masters and will not get involved in any more ' uprisings'. We have to be wary of this justification. The last group I want to mention briefly is the group that says 'Well, there is nothing we can do about it'. I suppose that is the most common point of view of the lot-'We are very disturbed about it; we have read about it and are shocked by the incidents and by the brutality and by the way man can be inhuman to another man but there is nothing we can do about it because it is outside our sphere of influence'.

The report itself gives the lie to that. It basically says two things: Firstly, that we can do something about it and, secondly, that we have a responsibility to do something about it. Why a responsibility; why an obligation? It is difficult to comment on this without using text from the scriptures; so many of them spring to mind. I will avoid them, for two reasons-the case stands on its own without their use, and some people feel that if one uses text from the scriptures it weakens the argument and frightens some people away. Why should we be concerned about these matters? Firstly, I believe we should because we are citizens of the world. A philospher once put the proposition which basically can be summed up as 'inhuman action against a fellow creature diminishes me as a person'. It was much better said than that but I cannot remember the quotation. I am sure that honourable senators will recall it. If an inappropriate action is taken against another human being, it diminishes me as a person. Surely it is better to stamp out actions which are against the conscience and often law of the country in which it happens. I will look in a few minutes-others will do so also-at the way in which we can do this. The second reason is that I believe that as a citizen of an enlightened country-I use that word very carefully-with all of the advantages we have, we have the same obligation to bring succour to those people who are wracked by disease, to bring food to those people who are hungry, as we have to try to avoid the torture of people by their fellow men.

The report calls for broad action. I refer to a couple of specific points. Firstly, I think that through education we can develop a sensitivity to suffering. I am aware that attitude change is one of the most important but most difficult areas of all in education. In this case, I indicate that education is not at all confined to schools. In fact, the major role of education in this area will be outside the school, because it is the attitudes of parents at which we must look. The attitudes of the parents will be reflected in the children. We have to find out why people have become insensitive. When we find that out, we have to develop some sorts of programs that will counter this acceptance of violence and suffering that we have in our community.

I think also we must publicise examples of torture. This publication of detail seems to be the best deterrent. I suppose it is a little like one seeing a police car on the street when one is driving one's car; one automatically slows down a little. What I am saying here is that if the community and the country itself have a conscience which is opposed to torture-an examination of the report reveals that there are many countries like this-we ought to publicise to its people what is happening in the country so that the collective conscience of the people of that country will cause the necessary action to be taken. Some will say that we should not interfere with our inter-country relationships. They say that we should not say things about a particular country because that country might think harshly of us. The response I make to that suggestion is the same sort of response I made to similar comments made in respect of East Timor. I am convinced that the courage and integrity of a country will be respected by others if that country has the courage to speak out. I am still convinced that the situation in East Timor would not have happened, that the degradation and suffering there would not have happened and that there would not have been the subjugation of the people by another state, if we had stood firm simply by making firm, courageous but quite clear statements.

Let us look at the possibility of the reduction of aid or assistance to countries that violate the Convention. Again many people will say that such action would affect our relationships with other countries, but surely we have the right to say to a country to which we are giving a lot of aid that we believe its actions in a particular area are inappropriate. Many Tamil people have suggested that we stop giving aid to Sri Lanka because, according to the Tamil people and the Sinhalese people, the Sri Lankans are attacking the Tamils. Of course, that proposition would not receive much support from the Department of Foreign Affairs under any government. Nevertheless, it is a reasonable proposition. People in the East Timor region will say that we seemed to give a lot of aid to Indonesia, even aid that could be used against the East Timorese, at a time when the Indonesians were taking an action that we believed to be inappropriate. In this regard we might consider also whether we want as friends states that condone torture and whether we want to assist those states. That is a matter worth thinking about.

The final suggestion I make is that governments make a direct approach at a government to government level. In the words of the motion governments could ' use influence to dissuade'. Some people would say that that is a naive approach. I do not believe that that is so. Judging from a comment I read in this morning' s newspaper, certainly a person from Sri Lanka holds a belief similar to mine. The newspaper report reads:
The Tamil problem in Sri Lanka was like a family dispute, a spokesman for the Eclam Tamil Association, Mr Sara Pavan, said in Canberra yesterday.
If a husband and wife were fighting, it was often a neighbour who could intervene-and Australia could act as a neighbour in the conflict between the Sinhalese and the Tamils.

Some people might not think the analogy is a good one; many would be reluctant to interfere in the affairs of a husband and wife. I do not wish to joke about this serious matter. The proposition that is put forward is that a friend will try to assist. I believe that a great deal more can be done than is being done. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting the motion put forward by Senator Missen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We live in a world in which we are told, I think reliably, that more than one-third of governments now use torture on some sort of regular basis as part of the disciplinary apparatus that they like to inflict on their own people. That is a very sad point upon which to reflect, because it indicates that the world is not improving but, as in so many other areas such as education and public health with the spread of the ancient killing diseases, the world is going backwards. I do not believe that the practice of torture ever stopped in the world, but at least for a brief time it was believed by most people on the planet that torture ought not to be an instrument of policy and that every opportunity ought to be taken to end it. Of course, the world went through the dreary centuries when torture was used regularly. We were able to get to the stage briefly where at least it was under some sort of control. That gain was won with great difficulty. We are now at the stage where we are at grave risk of losing completely the ground we have gained.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for that reason that I regard this debate as being so very important and why I regard the work of Amnesty International as being so important. Amnesty International tries to hold the battle line in an area which is of great consequence to every human being. Surely it should be part of the expectations of life in this world that every human being should be able to live through his life without being exposed to mental or physical torture. I would have thought that to an ordinary human being whose view was not at all perverted the whole idea of torture would be repugnant. Since the majority of human beings would share that view-I am confident that they would-it ought to be possible for the human race to get together, as it has done before on this issue and similar issues, to ensure that this terrible drift back to the use of torture is diminished and, if possible, ended.

Senator Missen during his contribution to the debate referred to Amnesty International's 12-point program for the prevention of torture. I wish to comment on two or three of those 12 points because they seem to me to be of particular importance. The first of those points deals with the official condemnation of torture. That point is rightly put first by Amnesty because it seems to me to be one of the most vital and important areas that we could consider. It reads:

The highest authorities of every country should demonstrate their total opposition to torture. They should make clear to all law enforcement personnel that torture will not be tolerated under any circumstances.

I think that refers to the authorities in every country looking at the situation in their own country. If that situation could be achieved, torture would not happen. Influence has to be brought to bear somehow on those higher authorities to make them understand something that I believe is very true, namely, that torture may present to them an attractive way of securing the compliance of the population and to induce a climate of fear sufficient to achieve the political ends of the particular regime but that in the long run and even in the short run it is simply not worth those objectives, and that such a regime will not be on a firm foundation for very long if it has to rely on that kind of suppression of its own people.

The second point in the program to which I refer is No. 3 and is headed 'No secret detention'. It seems to me that the secret nature of torture is one of its most unpleasant aspects. What occurs is that a person going about his or her business at home, already knowing that he or she is under suspicion, perhaps being in some degree of fear, is simply taken away at night or in the early morning. The rest of society does not know what has happened to that person. But we know Amnesty International's work has been terribly important to the world because it has brought to public attention all over the world just what does happen to these people who are taken away in covered vans at night. It is important to those people and to the world in general that that is known. We have to try to get to the bottom of secret detention where it is occurring-the whole idea of people being arrested and taken away and society not knowing what is happening to them. The whole force of law should be encouraged to be brought to bear in these countries to ensure that whatever has happened to a person who is accused of a crime or is detained is brought to the clear light of public knowledge and publicity. I believe if that could be done the incidence of torture would be very much less, because it is one of those unhealthy and unwholesome things that breeds in secrecy. The seventh point in Amnesty International's program is headed 'Prohibition of torture in law'. It reads:
Governments should ensure that acts of torture are punishable offences under the criminal law.
In accordance with international law, the prohibition of torture must not be suspended under any circumstances, including states of war or other public emergency.

In other words, there is not really any reason or grounds for rationalising torture. There is no reason at all for saying that there is a national emergency ; that this has been done or that has been done and, therefore, we have to torture people to achieve our objectives. The eighth point, under the heading, ' Prosecution of alleged torturers', states:

Those responsible for torture should be brought to justice. This principle should apply wherever they happen to be, wherever the crime was committed and whatever the nationality of the perpetrators or victims. There should be no ' safe haven' for torturers.

In the countries which use torture there are now safe havens for torturers. Who are the torturers? Presumably they are people of warped minds since they are prepared to administer this type of peculiar agony on other human beings, either mentally or physically. Not to put any fine point on it, these people are criminals. They are people of a criminal, evil and obscene nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are even trained in criminality.

—As the honourable senator said, these people of an already perverted nature are trained to go further in this sort of activity. They sit there secure, because of the protection of the regime in their country, and indulge in carrying out their worst and most depraved instincts on other people. That, of course, is their objective. I think that is a very important point to make. These people do not torture other people because they think they must do it for the state, that it is a patriotic duty. Of course they do not do it for that reason. They do it because they are evil, criminal types to whom the state has given the opportunity of indulging their depraved appetites. It is as simple as that. Any state which unleashes that kind of thing on the world and on its own people is carrying out an immensely dangerous activity which I think is to be deplored. I think that when one looks at it from that point of view one can see how serious and dangerous it is.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look into history, we can see that other activities of the human race were finally or substantially abolished in the world-there again, not completely -because of public reaction against them. I think of slavery. Slavery was not abolished because of any particular battle for rights on the part of the slaves, nor because of an initiative or action by the majority of people. It was because a relatively few dedicated people who felt terribly strongly on the issue and who were in a position to make some input to world opinion did so. They went on relentlessly without any thought of giving up until they succeeded. Through those people that institution of slavery was substantially, certainly in most parts of the world, overcome. I think that we may see the model that Amnesty sees it must pursue. Amnesty must attract the membership, the attention and the assistance of as many men and women of good intent as it can. Those people, being members of Amnesty, then have a duty to fulfil its objectives as far as they can. What an unpleasant duty it is to hear, think and read about these things. This is something which is painful and repugnant to any normal human being. Nevertheless, that must be done if there is to be a clear understanding of what goes on.

I support the comments made by Senator Robertson that we ought to properly consider what is going on in our own backyard, that what is closest to us ought to be of some concern. I support his comments about what is happening in East Timor. I have spoken many times in the Senate on the subject of East Timor. Honourable senators will know my views well enough, so I will not repeat them at length other than to say that one of the most unpleasant aspects of the East Timor operation is the assault on a whole people in secret. Whenever anything like this goes on one finds that the government concerned goes to great lengths to make sure that nobody else knows about it. That in itself is a very telling comment on the activities of such governments, because they are not prepared to justify their actions in the public fora of the world. The fact that they will not do that obviously begs the question and indicates that something is terribly wrong. Of course, there is something terribly wrong in East Timor. As I have said again and again-I will go on saying it as long as I am here-it remains a terrible indictment on the conscience of Australia that this small community which is so close to us has murdered a number of our own citizens in cold blood- the journalists who went there-and has given no reason or justification whatever and does not propose to do so. That regime has killed virtually a third of the Timorese people, to whom we owe a debt of honour because they helped our soldiers in World War II and to whom we have every kind of duty which we have betrayed. That is something which no person in this country should ever forget. It is on the conscience of all of us.

That takes me to my next point, which is that torture and brutality are the inexorable consequences of war, revolution and social dislocation caused by violence. I believe a society of human beings which is unaffected by such things and has what I would call a normal way of life, that is, happiness, a reasonable degree of freedom and pursuit of its own affairs within the scope of normal rivalry-that is fair enough-is not inclined to become a torturing nation. The fact that our own country is not a torturing nation is an indication of that. I am not being smug in saying this-things could get worse here at any time-but at the moment we are not that way because of the conditions of life we have. That visits a particular responsibility on those of us who interest ourselves, or say , as we all do here, that we have some kind of influence on world affairs and on world zonal rivalry.

Too often that zonal rivalry is rationalised in this way. We will say to ourselves: 'This administration in this country or that country is evil or oppressive. We know that country uses torture; we know it attacks other people; we know it is doing things which are wrong and evil, but we are prepared to rationalise and accept it because we use the principles of the end justifying the means. These people have to be supported. These repressive and unpleasant regimes have to be supported in the interests of the zonal balance of power'. Here again I believe we must recognise our own obligations that if we support, without comment, organisations and nations near to us, which it seems to be in our strategic interest to support, without commenting on and accepting their transgressions, we are committing a crime against the human race. That again-I return to the point I made earlier-is a good reason for continuing to insist on having some knowledge and thought about the evils being carried out by Indonesia against the East Timorese.

The Australian Democrats wholeheartedly support Senator Missen's motion. In 1972-that is, 12 years ago-Amnesty launched its long term campaign to have torture abolished throughout the world. The project is an ambitious one. Any effort that the Australian Government can make to further it will be time, money and effort very well spent. Although we do not believe torture is practised by our governments, symbolically it would be very helpful to Amnesty's campaign if the Australian Government publicly attested and stated its wholehearted support for the 12-point program and our absolute determination to adhere to the program 's 12 principles. I think this is something which, while it may not seem necessary, is something that we could well consider doing. I ask the Government to consider that course of action purely for its psychological and public relations value and to impress on those countries which do use torture that not every country does, for its own good reasons.

I think that most of us in this country are quite unaware of the extent to which torture is practised throughout the world. It is universally condemned, but the growth and the extent of it is quite alarming. The diabolical variety of tortures which it is possible for the human mind to develop is very sinister. I do not think that it is necessary to sicken anybody with the intimate details of the various forms of torture. I do not propose to do that, but I commend any honourable senator who is interested in finding out about the true horror of these things to get hold of a copy of some of Amnesty's material and look at it so that they understand the true nature of this problem.

I wish to comment briefly on Amnesty's origins. Amnesty began in quite a small way. It began in 1961 with a newspaper article entitled 'The Forgotten Prisoners ' by British lawyer, Peter Benenson. One man wrote something from which Amnesty came. I believe all good intentions in the world tend to come initially from one person, as everything has to have a beginning. Benenson urged people everywhere to begin working impartially and peacefully for the victims of political persecution. The article stated:

Open your newspaper any day of the week and you will find a report from somewhere in the world of someone being imprisoned, tortured or executed because his opinions or religion are unacceptable to his government.

Within a month more than a thousand people from various countries had sent in offers of practical help. That is interesting as it shows just how many people in the world have the good intent and desire to do something about these things. What started as a brief publicity effort became a growing international movement which now has more than half a million members, supporters and subscribers in over 160 countries and territories. Those people come from every walk of life and reflect a very wide variety of views and politics. It is interesting that the Amnesty Parliamentary Group in this Parliament consists of honourable senators and members of all political parties. Of course, that is as it should be. They are able to carry out activities which transcend our political differences which may preoccupy us from time to time.

Of course, the Parliamentary Group is not a very precise concept. The President of the Victorian section of Amnesty International approached a number of members and senators here in 1970 and from that came the Parliamentary Group. As a group , it looks at political torture and imprisonment of parliamentarians and ex- parliamentarians. It is right and proper that we should do that because they have a special affinity with us and we have with them. The activities of the members of the group, when proposed, were being seen as encompassing:
1. Reading and noting any material on human rights sent them by Amnesty;
2. Where appropriate, on their own initiative or at Amnesty request, promoting in Parliament debate on 'Amnesty issues';
3. Similarly, supporting or promoting legislation or international initiatives in support of Amnesty issues;
4. Individually or as a group, interceding through channels or directly with governments when requested by Amnesty;
a number of us do that by letter-
5. Keeping Amnesty informed of moves in Australian Government circles and overseas which would be of interest;

The last point involves informing Amnesty of coming visits by international figures of note, who might be able to advise Amnesty on furthering its objectives, and how best to approach members of mission who come here-and perhaps trying to influence them. I put that in by way of a brief commercial and suggest to any honourable senators who are not members of Amnesty International that they ought to become so in their interests and in the interests of humanity . The Australian Democrats agree with Amnesty International that human rights are a human responsibility because wherever they are violated, no matter where it is, people are the victims.

In his fine speech, Senator Robertson made the point very eloquently and quite passionately that people are the same everywhere. It is very evil and wrong to have the suggestion that because a place is overpopulated it is good to have a few people killed off, that where Asians are involved, because they do not feel pain the way we do it does not matter, and all such monstrous rubbish which people go on with to rationalise their position. That cannot be tolerated. But, of course, the people who are violated need practical help. The protection of human rights is an international responsibility which major powers and world bodies accept. Where they are failing is at government level. The principles of accountability are there. Not enough work has been done. Not enough determination has been exerted by the individual governments of the United Nations to put to shame those countries which use torture or to raise the matter often enough, persistently enough or annoyingly enough to persuade those countries to change their ways. We support without reservation Senator Missen's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the motion moved by Senator Missen in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate- (a) draws the Government's attention to the campaign by Amnesty International against torture and the evidence provided of the practice of various forms of torture in the 1980's in at least 98 countries;
(b) calls on the Australian Government to assert influence to dissuade governments from continuing to use or to connive in the practice of torture within their national boundaries;
(c) urges the Australian Government to support the United Nations Voluntary Fund for victims of torture; and
(d) requests the Australian Government to seek the expediting of the completion of the proposed international covenant against torture.

I am pleased to associate myself with this motion. I am proud to be an executive member of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International which has been referred to by Senator Mason. Of course, I note that Senator Missen, the mover of this motion, is the Chairman of that group. I am pleased to associate myself with the work of Amnesty International and in particular its campaign to eradicate torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, wherever they occur.

The report details instances of such torture occurring in some 98 different countries. It claims that more than one-third of the world's governments have used or tolerated torture or ill treatment of prisoners in the 1980s. A more shocking condemnation of the world's society than that I simply cannot imagine. It is important also to appreciate that this is not a sudden whim of Amnesty. It is part of a continuing program which dates back to at least 1972 when Amnesty International launched its campaign for the abolition of torture, following it in the next year, 1973, with a report on that subject. Ever since that time it has worked to expose cases of torture and to bring pressures on governments to act. One method it has adopted that deserves particular publicity on this occasion is what is referred to as its urgent action network which was established in 1974. It encouraged some 30,000 people from 47 countries to participate by writing to governments and expressing concern on behalf of some 1 ,143 individuals in 32 countries who were deemed to be in danger of torture. It is a practical way in which Amnesty has been able to involve the citizens of the world in expressing their concern to governments at the intolerable behaviour that has taken place, which regrettably is continuing. Despite the good work of Amnesty, it is of course very difficult to assess what has been achieved. If one looks at this report and the extent of the number of countries in which torture is practised, and the many thousands of specific instances contained therein, it might be said that very little has been achieved. However, it is worthwhile to note that this report indicates some encouraging signs. At the international level it reminds us that we now have the declaration on the protection of all persons from torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I briefly remind the Senate of Article 3 of that United Nations declaration, which is in the following terms:

No State may permit or tolerate torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Exceptional circumstances such as a state of war or threat of war, internal political instability or any other public emergency may not be invoked as a justification of torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

That is important. It is a point that has been made by previous speakers, that no circumstances can justify torture. It is inhuman behaviour and an affront to the dignity of man and in no circumstances can it be tolerated. We should be aware also that in 1975 the United Nations put down its declaration against torture. Before the United Nations presently there is a draft convention which is referred to in the motion moved by Senator Missen. It is a draft convention which Amnesty indicates at page 3 of its report it believes can be of very considerable assistance to the world community in outlawing torture and other forms of inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It can play a worthwhile role in the development of that convention and the process of persuading states to sign and ratify it in due course. That is what Senator Missen is seeking in part of his motion today and it is something that I commend to the Australian Government.

In the meantime Amnesty acknowledges the role of other international achievements, particularly establishment of the Human Rights Committee in 1976 pursuant to the terms of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Its report-I do not have time to detail it now-indicates some specific ways in which the Committee has been able to assist the world community in this very important task. It might be worthwhile, however, to remind the Senate of article 7 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It states :

No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. In particular, no one shall be subjected without his free consent to medical or scientific experimentation.
Amnesty makes reference to article 5 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights under which the United Nations Commission on Human Rights was set up. It states:
No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

Working groups have been set up by that Commission and have examined situations in southern Africa, Israel's occupied territories and Chile. It is also interesting to note from the report that special rapporteurs of that Commission have moved further. Work has been carried on in the international communities and the international covenants, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, make clear the international situation that torture is clearly internationally illegal.

It is also worth noting the acknowledgement of Amnesty International as to the role of regional organisations such as the Organisation of American States, the Council of Europe in the work it has done in this regard and also the Organisation of African Unity although in that regard, I think what might be said might be related more to its potential to assist in relation to Africa than what it has been able to achieve because the report reminds us that, although the African Charter on Human and People's Rights was adopted in 1981-article 5 of which prohibits torture and cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment or treatment-the Treaty will not come into force until a majority of member states ratifies it. As of May 1983 only seven of the 51 member states had done so.

I think there is another case where perhaps the good offices of the Australian Government and the good standing that it has within the African continent can be put to worthwhile use in putting the arguments to African states about the importance of ratifying that Treaty and complying with its provisions. The problem, of course, is the lack of enforcement machinery. Whether states act depends upon political pressure. It underlines, I believe, the importance of the use also of all available bilateral channels to stop torture and to comply with the findings of these international human rights bodies. I am pleased that this point was taken up by Senator Robertson. At a bilateral level we have opportunities through our diplomatic offices, through our aid and through trade to attempt to persuade other countries as to our attitudes on matters such as torture and the totally unsatisfactory behaviour that we regard it to be.

We should have suggested in this report-I think it is worth considering-the encouragement of our embassy officials to collect information in the countries in which they operate. We should have also suggested that we send observers to trials. That is a process that we have adopted in a small way which I think can be developed further in the future. We should be prepared to come out and name and condemn those countries in which torture is a practice. As Senator Robertson said, we should not be afraid to do so because of any detrimental effect that that might have on our bilateral trading position, for example. We should not underestimate the international political embarrassment in making these statements and in making the world community aware that torture is still a practice that is taking place in so many countries of the world.

Amnesty International also looks at the tremendous role being played by international non-governmental organisations. I think that should be mentioned also in this debate. I recall Senator Missen mentioned the excellent work and contribution being made by the International Commission of Jurists. We should also mention the work that has been carried on in this field by the International Committee of the Red Cross which receives particular mention in the report for the role that it can and does play. For example, at page 46 of the report we are reminded that in 1981 alone the International Committee of the Red Cross visited 489 places of detention. Between 1971 and 1981 its delegates carried out approximately 15,000 visits in some 80 countries. It is concerned with the conditions of the prisoners' detention. Its delegates attempt to establish the facts about those conditions including allegations of torture and of cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

We should recognise the work these international non-government organisations are carrying out.
