One that I have particular interest in and which I have raised in the Senate before is Lawasia's human rights committee and the work that it is doing to protect lawyers throughout the Asian region in the roles that they carry out in protecting the rights and freedom of people in their countries. We should recognise the role that these groups carry out. There is certainly a role for us and our Government to play in encouraging the good work they are doing.

The report of Amnesty also recognises the role being played by national groups. This is an area that probably does not receive quite as much attention as perhaps it should. It makes mention of such organisations as the Detainees' Parents Support Committee in South Africa. It gives particular credit to various bar and medical associations throughout the world that have played active parts in attempting to suppress torture within their countries. It makes mention specifically of the Human Rights Society of Pakistan and the work it has done. It makes mention of the Civil Rights Movement of Sri Lanka and the Legal Aid Institute in Indonesia and the work it has done and is doing in relation to the unfortunate, totally unsatisfactory situation in Indonesia at the moment with large numbers of persons being abducted, tortured and killed without trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Always doing this at great danger to themselves, too.

—As Senator Missen indicates, they are always doing it at great danger to themselves. The work of these groups should be commended and encouraged by the Australian Parliament. Church groups have also been specifically mentioned in the report and deserve our recognition and support for the work they have done.

SPEECH.PARA: The Press deserves some credit. I know it was mentioned earlier in this debate but it seems to be difficult to enthuse to the Press in debates in the Senate on Thursday afternoons. Nevertheless the report indicates the important role that the news media is carrying out in this regard and gives particular credit to it. At page 2 of its report, Amnesty International states:

The news media carry many more items about torture and other human rights abuses than they did a decade ago, not necessarily because there are more such abuses in the 1980s than earlier, but because more independent organisations are investigating these abuses and because editors and journalists are more concerned to conduct their own research into torture allegations and to report on their findings.
I believe that should be recognised and encouraged.

Despite these signs of promise that Amnesty has identified and which I have mentioned today, the report does evidence a continuing use of torture to an extent that can only be described as shocking. It is governments that are responsible for torture and it is only governments that in the end can effectively prevent it. We are looking at a dual situation, equally to be condemned. We are looking at a situation where there is a conscious decision to torture by some governments and also where there is a lack of will by many other governments to stop torture. What Amnesty International has done therefore is to list a set of legal and administrative safeguards and remedies that any government can introduce if it seriously wishes to abolish or prevent torture and ill-treatment.

I remind the Senate that clearly a simple legislative prohibition is insufficient because torture is already prohibited by the laws or constitutions of at least 112 countries, regrettably, many of which are detailed in this report as still having torture carried out within their areas of responsibility. But where the political will exists there is no doubt that a government can stop torture. Conversely, if few objectively verifiable preventive and remedial measures have been taken then it is fair to conclude that a government's opposition to torture is less than serious.

That, I think, leads to the most important and constructive part of the report because it attempts to detail a list of preventive measures which a government that is serious can take in order to prevent torture taking place. It also lists a series of remedial measures which a government can take which are important in that they will deter future ill-treatment. I do not have the time today to detail these measures but I will simply run through the list that appears in the report. I commend them to honourable senators for more detailed consideration. Preventive measures include: Official directives condemning torture, which in so many places simply does not occur; restrictions on incommunicado detention-the access of the detainee to lawyers, for example; domestic legislation, which makes torture a criminal offence-I remind the Senate that the United Nations declaration against torture calls on each state to ensure that torture is an offence under its criminal law; the repeal of provisions of emergency legislation which diminish detainees' rights-in many cases as indicated in this report, torture is facilitated by the existence of states of emergency whether or not such states of emergency really are necessary; the encouragement of a regular system of visits to places of detention-by such groups as the Red Cross; training in human rights norms for all security agents; an attempt to separate the detaining authority from the interrogating authority; notification to detainees of their rights; the urging of a commitment to an independent judiciary, and the prohibition against the waiving of certain rights- unfortunately in some places it is possible for somebody who has been arrested to waive his right to appear before a court in a specific period of time. Amnesty says that such a right to waive should not exist, for obvious reasons and, I believe, it makes sense. Amnesty says that medical safeguards should exist, records should be kept by the detaining authority as an important indication of whether a state is determined to ensure that proper behaviour occurs within that authority; the procedures an interrogating authority may use should be clearly outlined and obvious, and there should be a code for treatment of detainees. Amnesty also recommends ratification and declarations concerning international human rights norms and mechanisms, something that I mentioned earlier. Under 'Remedial measures' it indicates that it is important to take remedial measures to provide a satisfactory complaints machinery and other domestic legal remedies.

In conclusion, I say that this report is helpful not only in that it sheets home the blame to governments rather than individuals but also because it alerts us to the methods, the victims and the agents. It points out a clear picture of accumulated evidence of the preconditions for torture. It shocks us with the methodology of torture and it is prepared to name governments where torture has occurred. But as I indicated, it is also particularly helpful in setting out a constructive program for improving the position. The Amnesty International report invites all concerned individuals and organisations to join in promoting its program. I am pleased to do so and I urge the Australian Government to do so .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As normally happens when we have a debate of this nature and one is the last speaker, one finds that preceding speakers have used those parts of the report to which one wished to refer. I think it is an accepted fact on both sides of the House today that this is a very important motion that has been brought forward by Senator Missen. There are many areas throughout the world where violence and torture are practised and accepted perhaps as a 'way of life'. That is not to say that because we know that those various forms of torture exist we should ignore them. Nor is it to say that because they happen in other countries, setting aside the matters raised by Senator Robertson earlier, we should remain silent. Nor is it to say that we should not use the forms of this chamber and the other House to bring them to the attention of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Missen commented, it will be those people who read the Hansard of today's proceedings who are more likely to learn of our concern than those who read the Press reports, because there is only one member of the Press Gallery here. I understand that there has been only one during the whole of the debate. I do not want to castigate the Press but I point out to it that there is a role that the Press has to play in the area of 'human rights' as there is a role for it to play in many other areas of the society in which we live. One of the particular roles that the Press can play is to publicise those areas where torture is practised, where perhaps we have a means of offsetting to a certain extent some of those practices. One of the other roles that I would see the Press playing is that of highlighting to the people of Australia the genuine concern that members of the Government and of the Opposition, the members of this Parliament, are expressing about the reports coming through. We are all horrified at the report of what is happening in East Timor that was referred to earlier in the debate. I do not intend to go through that matter except to say that I find it a most disgusting element of our society but I recognise that it is there and nothing that we say today will change that situation. But if we can get enough people and enough governments saying it then we can change the situation.

The Amnesty International organisation has put out a number of publications over the years. It is interesting that its latest publication, Torture in the Eighties, brings out a number of the reports that Senator Missen and I certainly have had for many years because of our involvement with the parliamentary group of Amnesty International, highlighting the effects of torture and violence in a number of countries. It does not seem to matter, whether one looks at countries where there is a socialist goverment or whether the countries are republics, whether the country be in the Middle East, in Europe, the Africas, Asia or the Americas; the fact remains that someone, somewhere, has this means of physically or psychologically subjecting another human being to torture. For instance, the briefing paper circulated by Amnesty International says:

Revulsion at the extermination camps of the Second World War led to a convention outlawing genocide for all time and today's torture chambers demand a similar international response. The torture and ill-treatment can be stopped. The international framework for its abolition exists. What is lacking is the political will of governments to stop torturing people.

It is therefore on the government. Amnesty has said that it is a government responsibility. As a government, as a parliament, we should be taking every step we can to ensure that other governments know of our concern about the situation.

The plain fact is, as all have acknowledged, torture has been with us from time immemorial. Nothing has changed, just the methods have changed. Advancing technology has intruded even into the area of torture. There are now much more sophisticated means of torture than were ever dreamed possible even 10 or 20 years ago because of that change in technology. The kind of torture which is applied is more frequently psychological torture, not necessarily of a person but of a person who is forced to watch another person being tortured. I am reminded of the plight of women prisoners in Evin prison in Iran. One mother who was tortured by being held screamed that she was ready to confess when she could no longer stand the agony of her three-year old daughter being forced to watch. How does one gauge the emotional extent of the stress on that three-year old child? How does one measure the psychological torture of that mother, who was not only tortured physically by being beaten but tortured by the fact that she knew that her three-year old daughter was watching that torture. One has to presume that there is an element of madness in those who devise such means of torture.

There is a set method of torture, particularly against women, and it is normally in the form of rape. I mentioned a little earlier the role of the Press . One can pick up any daily newspaper in Australia, and in all probability one will see on the front page reference to a sexual violation of a female person. Some newspapers rehash a previous incident to sell more newspapers. Rape is the worst form of torture that perhaps a woman can experience. If it is taken out of the context of life in a 'relatively free' civilisation in Australia, and if it is put in a context where women are deliberately raped as a form of torture, it becomes a much more heinous crime. I do not belittle the other forms of rape that take place in a society such as ours. I am simply referring to the fact that it is a more heinous crime when carried out as a form of torture against groups of women rather than an individual.

Senator Missen said that torture is a disease, a breach of all things civilisation stands for, and that one sometimes has to question whether we are a civilised world because of what goes on. He called for the Government to have a strong priority on human rights issues. I have read some of the report, and because of the time constraints today I shall not go into it in great detail. However, I looked closely at some of the forms of torture used and at some of the countries that employ such methods. It does not seem to matter where one comes from in the world today, there is an acceptance that torture is a form of life. For example, I noted that in Iran the popular, if one can use that word, form of torture is whipping and amputation. In Yugoslavia the popular form of torture is to beat men on the genitals and then brag that they will never be able to father children. China, where little information has been made available , has suddenly come into prominence in this respect as a result of a number of articles which have been published in some of our more popular newspapers recently. In Afghanistan one woman who was held said that during detention she was continually interrogated and denied sleep for up to a week. One has only to think of that as a form of torture to realise what it involved. We sit in this place on Tuesdays to an extended hour late at night. I suppose to a lot of people parliament is a form of torture. Certainly listening to it may be! However, I ask honourable senators to imagine being denied the right to go to sleep for a whole week and the emotional effect that must have. That woman was then subjected to electric shock torture.

Look at the situation in Uruguay, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. Indeed, there is hardly a country that misses out in the report. The report makes clear that at present 98 nations practise a form of torture. Amnesty has collated information on 66 of those countries. One young boy aged 12 years was detained by security forces in Iraq from 25 February to 5 March a couple of years ago. His corpse was subsequently handed back to his family and was badly marked by torture. It was bad enough that the corpse was handed back, but so much worse that it was in a mutilated form. If anybody saw the mothers of the missing on television some months ago, they would have been impressed by the psychological torture that was exerted on those women who had no idea whether their families were alive or dead , whether they were being tortured or incarcerated.

In this situation Australia can play a singularly important role. Because of my concern in this area, which I have expressed on many occasions and which I do not need to repeat, and because of my work in the parliamentary group of Amnesty International, I contacted the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to tell him that I would be speaking on this subject. I was given an assurance by him that the draft convention of the United Nations on this subject is apparently now prepared. He informed me that if there were any suggestion of a weakening of that draft resolution, such a move would be strongly resisted by the Australian Government. That gives me a great deal of heart. I firmly believe that although the United Nations may not be everything we want it to be, we must recognise that it is the only body that could be considered to be influential, particularly in those areas.

One other matter that we must take into consideration when discussing torture, and the reasons for it, is that we now have a great disparity in society. There are the haves, who are very well placed, and the have-nots, whether they be individuals or countries. There are very influential countries which are financially independent and have the means of borrowing money on the world market. However, there are other countries that are destitute because they have no national security. If there is no national security, there is no individual security. Until we can bridge that gap we are not likely to be able to change things, to any great extent. But we can at least make our voices heard. We can say to other governments: 'What you are doing is not recognisable by us'. I have no compunction about holding a threat over people's heads. We should say to those governments that if they do not desist from torturing people, if they do not conform with what we consider to be a civilised manner of living, we will take such and such action. If it comes to that situation, I believe that is what we should be prepared to do. If there are other means of getting around it, I would prefer to see those go through, with the aid of the United Nations international covenant against torture. I understand that will be some way in the future, but there is nothing to stop us right now expressing the concerns of all the people in this place and in the other place about what is happening in the world. I commend to the Parliament the report by Amnesty International ' Torture in the Eighties'. It is not light reading but is very readable. It is not the sort of book one should take to bed after a very heavy day in this chamber, but it is certainly one everybody should read. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to this debate on behalf of the Government because it is I believe an important one. The Government very much welcomes the report of Amnesty International and the campaign against torture and has no quarrel at all with the general terms of Senator Missen's motion. The facts documented by Amnesty unequivocally demonstrate that it is vitally important to raise international awareness of the scope and gravity of torture. It is very disquieting to note, as did Senator Missen and Senator Coleman, that Amnesty names 98 countries in all in its report. The report gives detailed consideration of 66 of these in its global survey of countries which countenance torture and ill-treatment of prisoners.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has been consistently active in international efforts to bring an end to torture. We have, for example, made a significant contribution to the Working Group of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights which has been drafting an international convention against torture. That Commission adopted a draft text of the convention at its last session. This draft, with some few articles remaining to be agreed, will now be considered by the next session of the UN General Assembly. The principal remaining obstacle to agreement is the question of whether the implementation provisions of the convention should be mandatory or optional. Australia firmly favours the former option and the Government will be redoubling its efforts to see an effective convention with mandatory implementation provisions adopted at the Thirty-Ninth UN General Assembly.

Australia has also expressed strong support for the UN's standard minimum rules for the treatment of prisoners and the draft body of principles for the protection of all persons under any form of detention or imprisonment being negotiated within the United Nations General Assembly. Respect for the principles embodied in these instruments and other due process safeguards found in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights would have a major impact in reducing the incidence of torture. Australia has made representations on a bilateral basis in a number of countries where allegations of torture have been made. We shall continue to pursue our concerns about torture with individual countries as appropriate opportunities arise.

The Government does not underestimate the difficulties involved in taking effective action against torture. As Amnesty points out, the evidence of torture reflects not only in discipline and cruelty at grass roots administrative levels , but also in many instances conscious, calculated government policy to deal with dissent. An important beginning is to bring the problem to light, a task in which Amnesty has succeeded admirably. Another key step is to strengthen respect for internationally recognised safeguards for prisoners, including rights of access to lawyers and family as embodied in instruments such as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the standard minimum rules for the treatment of prisoners. The present administrators, the police and the military, require proper training and effective supervision.

While the emphasis should, of course, be on preventive action, the Government is also aware of the need for assistance for those who have suffered torture. The Government has therefore decided to contribute to the United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture next financial year, and the amount of that contribution will, I imagine, be announced in the Budget context. The fund is used to finance valuable work on the rehabilitation of torture victims whose long term suffering is often forgotten. The Government wishes Amnesty's campaign against torture every success. The Government values greatly the efforts of responsible non-government organisations, such as Amnesty, to protect and promote internationally recognised human rights and fundamental freedoms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There is no call for me to reply in this debate, but I merely wish to thank my colleagues of all political parties who have contributed to the debate, for their generous and individual contributions, and their support for the campaign against torture. I also thank the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), who was speaking on behalf of the Government, for his encouraging statement and the particularly encouraging news that there will be a practical demonstration of that in the contribution to the fund for the assistance of victims of torture. I trust that by the carriage of this motion-I trust the Senate will carry it-we will be able to demonstrate the strong feeling which we, as representatives of the Australian people, have on this subject and help towards eliminating torture in this world.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May 1982, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason's Bill, the Rainforest Preservation Agreements Bill 1982 [1983], has been introduced with the very laudable aim of promoting the conservation of Australia's remaining rainforest resources. Senator Mason is to be congratulated for his efforts in this very important area. However, we do have some difficulties with his Bill, which I shall state as briefly as possible. In its present form we believe it contains several definitional administrative and financial inadequacies. Briefly, the definitional inadequacies primarily relate to the concept of rainforest itself, which is undefined in the legislation. The difficulty is that environmentalists, geographers, botanists and almost everybody else disagree among themselves as to what rainforests are. There are many different kinds-sub-tropical, tropical, temperate and so on. For example, Queenslanders tend to laugh at Victorians or Tasmanians claiming that they possess rainforests. It is not a term of such precise scientific connotation, as I understand it, or denotation. I had better get corrected on that.
—Denotation.

—Denotation-that that term, by itself, is really terribly satisfactory when left as the centrepiece of a Bill of this kind. The administrative difficulties tend to arise out of the reliance adopted in the legislation on really joint action with the States. The essentially parallel approach here foreshadowed does depend on the goodwill of the States which may, of course, not be forthcoming, to secure the objectives of the legislation. There may, indeed, also be some constitutional problems flowing from the problems posed by section 99 which prohibits, among other things, a preference to a particular State. It might be argued, to the extent that the Bill is variable in its application, depending on whether the State in question has a rainforest, that there are some constitutional difficulties. That particular aspect of it may be over-exaggerated but it certainly needs further consideration before his legislation is passed in its present form.

SPEECH.PARA: The financial difficulties are largely those associated with the compensation provisions. The cost of acquisition and assistance that is contemplated by the legislation is not quantified and could be anything in the range from $2m to $ 200m. Naturally any government is going to be cautious about accepting a legislative commitment of that kind. In cases of acquisition there is the further difficulty that the valuation method and process is unspecified, leaving it doubtful as to by whom the process is to be carried on, whether or not the value of timber is to be taken into account, and so on. Moreover, the difficulty , as we discovered in the context of the Tasmanian dam case, is that any given valuation method may not stand up to the scrutiny of the High Court of Australia under section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution, which demands that any acquisition of a compulsory kind be on just terms. That creates all sorts of difficulties for this kind of legislation.

I am not saying that this legislation-nor is the Government-is necessarily incapable of remedying or amendment in some of these respects, but certainly the Government sees very real difficulties about accepting it in its present form. Moreover, we take the view, the rather larger view, that the Bill would not assist the aim we all share of promoting the conservation of Australia's remaining rainforest resources. It may, in fact, by being introduced at this time, be counterproductive to some of the measures the Government has already set in train and is planning. Those measures I will now, on behalf of the relevant Minister, Mr Cohen, endeavour to describe. No doubt the Government has been vigorously active in this area and there are a number of things occurring otherwise than in a legislative context.

The Australian Labor Party 1982 platform contained a very firm commitment to promote the conservation of rainforests, in recognition of the fact that they constitute a valuable and diminishing world and national resource. As the first step towards implementing this commitment, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen, as I said, convened the Conference on Tropical and Subtropical Rainforest Conservation in Cairns on 2 and 3 February this year. The conference was chaired by the Acting Secretary of his Department, Mr Galvin. It was attended by about 50 invited participants, representing the major groups with an interest in the question of rainforest conservation includ- ing the New South Wales and Queensland governments, the conservation movement, local government, the timber industry, unions and the scientific community as well as various Commonwealth interests. Mr Cohen opened the conference and attended much of it.

The conference proved to be a great success, I am told. It established that much common ground exists between conservationists, foresters, national parks authorities and persons engaged in rainforest timber industries. The Minister tells me he was particularly pleased with the level of co-operation and goodwill shown by the New South Wales and Queensland governments. At the end of the conference a statement was issued which was unanimously supported by the participants and acknowledged the need for a Commonwealth rainforest conservation policy. It stated:
is consistent with the National Conservation Strategy for Australia;
recognises the responsibilities of State and Local Governments;

provides a stable basis upon which future developments in the timber industry and in rainforest management can be planned, recognising commitments given to industry in the allocation of virgin rainforest timber resources;
recognises that Australia's future timber needs should be met without placing undue pressure on the rainforest resources of other countries;
seeks to ensure that adequate representative areas of all rainforest ecosystems and their genetic diversity are maintained in perpetuity.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was unanimous, wasn't it?

—That was unanimous. The conference agreed that any policy which calls for changes to existing practices should result from the fullest consultation between all interested parties-government, industry, unions and conservationists-and should take account of the need for appropriate structural adjustment assistance for the industry and employees whose livelihoods would be affected. Furthermore, the conference agreed that a co-ordinated national research program should be undertaken to provide the information necessary to allow management practices to embrace the elements of the proposed policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The conference supported Mr Cohen's suggestion that a working group be established to develop a set of policy options for the Government to consider. Action is under way to establish the working group. The Government is hopeful that, building on the agreement reached in Cairns, a policy will be developed that promotes the conservation of rainforests while catering for the needs of the industries and individuals involved in rainforest utilisation.

I repeat that the Government, while wholly sympathetic to the objectives of this legislation, given the moves that have been occurring that I have just retailed, does not believe that legislation of this kind, whatever its conceptual merits, is appropriate at this stage. Moreover, we see a number of difficulties, in particular in the drafting and formulation of it, such as to make it not possible for us to give this measure, whatever its initial attractiveness, our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak on behalf of the Liberal and National parties on this debate on Senator Mason's private member's Rainforest Preservation Agreements Bill. The Opposition will not be supporting the Bill. That is not because we are not supportive of the sentiments that Senator Mason has expressed in relation to rain forests; we are not supporting it for the same reasons that the Government is not. We think it is not a practical or workable solution and we think that there are other ways of handling the problem that we certainly face with rainforests. We also think that Senator Mason's Bill is too restrictive. The Bill itself provides only that there will be agreements between the Commonwealth Government and State governments so there is not prescription for any State government as to its attitude or behaviour towards rainforests. However, a schedule to the Bill sets out the form of the agreement. We find this defective and deficient for a number of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I state first of all the Liberal and National parties' attitude on the subject generally. The Attorney-General, Senator Evans, when speaking on behalf of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen), referred to the Conference on Tropical and Subtropical Rainforest Conservation held in Cairns. This approach of involving all interested parties-governments at all levels, people involved in the timber industry and those who are interested in conservation-is one that the Opposition supports. We note with interest the statement which Senator Evans has referred to. I draw attention to a couple of parts of that statement which are consistent with our views on the subject of rainforests. We note that the conference adopted the definition of conservation used in the world conservation strategy, noting in particular that it embraces 'preservation , maintenance, sustainable utilisation, restoration and enhancement of the natural environment'. We claim that the schedule to Senator Mason's Bill is in conflict with that definition of conservation. It is also-I will come to this later-in conflict with a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce on the subject of Australia's forestry and forest products industries. Its recommendations agree closely with the statement from the Conference on Tropical and Sub-tropical Rainforest Conservation.

One of the effects of the agreement in the schedule to Senator Mason's Bill would be to prevent any utilisation of declared and agreed areas after a period of a couple of years. We think that this is unrealistic in all cases and could actually be a deterrent to Commmonwealth and State governments reaching agreement on the management of rainforest areas. Senator Evans very properly pointed out that one of the biggest problems-it is not an insoluble one but is a very real one-is the problem of the definition of rainforest. There are several types of rainforests in Australia-tropical, cool-temperate and littoral. Rainforests often merge into surrounding vegetation and these transitional rainforest communities form significant habitats and buffer zones associated with mature rainforest. A variety of definitions may take narrow or wide views of what rainforest is. Therefore, one would need in any Bill on this matter some sort of agreement on definition.

I have received, as I am sure many other senators have received, a number of representations from individuals who are interested in supporting the thrust of Senator Mason's Bill. So far as the thrust of his Bill is to do something constructive to protect rainforests, that sentiment is one with which we agree. However, I reiterate that we do not agree with the definition in his schedule as to the best way to do what the Bill seeks to do. I have been approached by people who claim that there are still in existence a couple of areas in Queensland of what could be called virgin rainforest. I understand that that term in itself is a fairly controversial one; some people believe there is no such thing as virgin rainforest. I have certainly had it put to me that once a rainforest is disturbed it cannot be restored to its original condition. It can be restored to a satisfactory condition but it is unlikely, because of the very intricate connection of species, that we could get the rainforest back to its original condition. That being so, very little rainforest is left in Australia in that condition and probably none of our rainforest is capable of restoration to originality.

The suggestion therefore, that we might look at better management of rainforest areas is a more practical one. Nevertheless, there are rainforests in north- eastern Australia and adjacent Pacific islands which contain the greatest assemblages of primitive flowering plant families in the world. About one quarter of north Queensland rainforest flora genera are found only in that region. That means that we do have in Australia something that is of world importance, which is very precious and which therefore puts a heavy responsibility on us to make sure that we do proceed properly and with care. As I said earlier, large areas of rainforest have been logged and are being logged. Some would say that in some of the areas involved the method of logging and the conservation that goes with that logging are satisfactory. I have seen a few of those areas in Queensland and some of them are quite impressive.

The Opposition, without necessarily concluding what the outcome of this series of consultations will be, thinks that it is a sensible way to go about something that is important. Of course we are not committed to whatever the outcome might be because we do not know what the outcome will be. Whilst we agree with the Government on the need to follow this course, we are not necessarily committed to whatever conclusion the Government itself might draw.

The subject of land use is one that is very much involved with rainforest preservation and unless our land use decisions and methods improve Australia will have larger deserts and erosion will spread. Natural forest areas will continue to dwindle. Plant and animal species will become extinct. As I have indicated, some of the plant and animal species, in some of our rainforests at least, are unique. Another deficiency of Senator Mason's Bill is that it covers rainforests on public land only; it does not extend to private land. I remind the Senate that when we were in government we provided money for the purchase of private land which we thought was important for conservation reasons. This land was provided as national parks area. So we do have a commitment to national parks areas and when in government we faced the difficult issue of what has to be done about private land.

A further criticism that needs to be made of Senator Mason's Bill-perhaps it is one that he can come back to but it is a criticism that is open to be made at the moment-is that it provides for the Commonwealth and the States to be involved in an arrangement under which they share the costs of maintenance of agreed areas on a 50-50 basis. The great problem is that the Bill provides for absolutely no limit on such costs. The States will draw up a conservation program and determine what that will cost, and the Commonwealth Government will be committed to meet half of that cost. It may well be that there would be a view that that is not entirely appropriate, that there should be some sort of notional limit or some sort of idea provided of what sort of expenditure a government would be likely to have to meet if this Bill were carried. Of course, the Bill contains no enforcement provisions either, except it provides that there shall be an agreement.

I have already mentioned that the agreement referred to in the Schedule requires a cessation of all rainforest logging in the agreed areas within two years. It is entirely possible that at some stage in the future a Commonwealth government and a State government, or several State governments, will agree that an area should not be logged in the future. One needs to have a rather better basis for proceeding than is contained in this Bill. Neither the Bill nor the Schedule contains any guidance as to the grounds on which it is to be decided that an area is not to be logged at all. The provisions of this Bill would apply only to those areas that are not to be logged at all, in which case it would preclude agreement about many areas in relation to which the Commonwealth and the States might want to reach agreement. The other possibility is that all areas in relation to which the Commonwealth and the States might wish to reach agreement for the purpose of general conservation will be too restrictively treated.

I draw the Senate's attention to the recommendations of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce following its inquiry into Australia's forestry and forest products industries. I understand that the former chairman of that Committee, Senator Archer, has indicated his intention to speak in the debate on this Bill. I am sure that he, too, will make reference to this report. I do not intend to refer to it at length. I just want to place on the record the recommendations of the Committee in relation to rainforests. The Committee recognised that the issue of rainforests is a very difficult one but a very important one. The Committee recommended as follows:
All areas of rainforests in Australia be conserved, maintaining the characteristic diversity and vitality of the original forests.
Where publicly-owned rainforests are managed for timber production, management prescriptions must include as a minimum standard
the attainment of sustained yield as a high priority;
selective logging;
canopy retention provisions appropriate to the rainforest type;
marking by forest service staff of each tree to be removed;
tree marking to ensure the maintenance of the species mix of the forest in its original proportions.
Consistent with those recommendations, the Committee recommended:

The margin between royalties applying to rainforest species and those to other species be increased to ensure that rainforest timbers are used sparingly and only for purposes where other timbers and other materials are not suitable substitutes.

Apart from Senator Archer, Senator Coleman, who was also a member of that Committee, may wish to speak in the debate at some stage. I am sure that those honourable senators will expand on those points. I draw them to the Senate's attention at this stage to point out how strongly at variance with those recommendations is the Schedule to Senator Mason's Bill. The Committee recognised that some logging is necessary and, indeed, inevitable. Nevertheless, it recognised some very sensible conservation principles that ought to be applied to any logging that is carried out. I commend the recommendations of that Committee to the Senate and to people who are interested in this general subject.

Whilst I have commended the Government on moving into its conference format, it does have a couple of matters to answer for. I realise that Senator Gareth Evans was representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment when he read to the Senate some information that had been provided to him on behalf of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I would like a Government senator to address himself seriously in the debate to the issue of how the interest the Government has professed for some time in rainforests squares with its actual performance. When Senator Mason introduced this Bill originally, the Labor party in Opposition indicated that it would probably support the Bill if some amendments were made to it. Now it is no longer interested in moving amendments and it intends to oppose the Bill.

The Federal Government has been the centre of some controversy, as indeed has been the Queensland Government in recent months in relation to the Daintree area . It is an area with which I am a little familiar but, unfortunately, it is an area that I do not get to visit often enough. It is located in quite an exquisite part of Queensland. The Senate will recall that there has been some controversy in relation to the building of a road through that area by the State government and the subdivision for private sale of areas of that rainforest by a land developer. I have already covered the matter of this Bill not addressing itself to private land. I think that is a matter to which the Government must address itself. I indicated earlier that when in government the coalition parties did address themselves to this matter and on occasions it acquired private land for inclusion in national parks. The problems associated with rainforests on private land are very much an issue in the Daintree.

The Government in opposition professed, and it professes today, a great interest in rainforests. When faced with this issue of the Daintree, the Government really stands condemned. All that the Minister did in relation to that matter was to send one telegram to the Premier of Queensland, in which he expressed some criticism of what was happening at the time. I understand that the Premier of Queensland did not reply to that telegram. That may or may not surprise honourable senators. At that point the Minister washed his hands of the matter. He said that he really could not do any more. He said he had tried to do something about the Daintree, he had not received co-operation from the State Government, and that was that. The model of co-operation that the Government might be trying to follow by holding conferences on rainforests was markedly absent when it was faced with a real issue, and in recent times, the issue of the Daintree has been the issue concerned with rainforests. The Government simply decided not to pursue the matter any further.

I think it is a great pity that the Government did not try to enter into serious negotiations with the Queensland Government, the land developers, the local authorities who approved certain land development, and so on. I know it would have been late in the day for the Government to enter into negotiations, but the issue involving the development of the Daintree did not arise on the day that the bulldozers moved in to commence construction of the road; it had been an issue for some time. The Minister could have moved on it much earlier than he did. Given that he had not, when he finally moved in December, he hardly moved at all. He is deserving of criticism for his lack of genuineness concerning the issue involving the Daintree.

The time for debate on this Bill has almost expired. I do not wish to speak at any greater length. I wish to state the reasons that the Liberal and National parties will not be supporting Senator Mason's Bill. I wish to state our views on the subject of rainforests, both in government and in opposition. Whilst undoubtedly senator Mason will be disappointed that we will not be supporting his Bill, I trust that he will nevertheless recognise that we will be supportive of what we see as better types of moves towards assisting with the very difficult but very important issue of rainforest preservation in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that I view the preservation of Australia's rainforest as an absolute priority and so does the Government. The Rainforest Preservation Agreements Bill is an attempt by Senator Mason to establish an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States to preserve those recognised areas of Australia's rainforests. While I can accept the intent of Senator Mason's Bill, it has in essence been pre-empted by decisions and actions of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen , as already outlined in the Senate this afternoon by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans). Furthermore, there are certain inadequacies in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation contains clauses which are of some concern to me, because they assume that all State governments can, in fact, be relied upon to view the preservation of rainforests as supportively as does the present Federal Government. Historically, there is little evidence to support this optimistic assumption and, in reality, State government priorities can alter drastically in regard to the pressures put on them by the timber industry. Therefore, what is required in my view-it is also the view of the Government-is a much more water- tight agreement than is contained in the Bill. By convening the rainforest conference in Cairns in February the Federal Government has already clearly demonstrated its commitment to the preservation of Australia's rainforests. The Minister said:

The platform on which the Hawke Government was elected recognises that rainforests are a valuable and diminishing world and national resource, and contains a commitment to develop policies which will provide a balance between economic, ecological and recreational needs for Australia's forest resources.

In developing a proposal for a rainforest conservation policy I want to ensure that we prevent further degradation of our forests so that future generations will continue to have the same access to rainforest as we have today. If we can adopt a policy that will enable us to undo some of the damage already done, so much the better.

There is no doubt in my mind that the National Government has a role in protecting a resource that is part of our national heritage. At present rainforests are one of the most threatened parts of that heritage.

The communique which was issued after the Cairns conference endorsed the need for the Commonwealth rainforest policy which would realistically, in co- operation with the States, preserve Australia's rainforests. Following the rainforest conference in February, the Minister is setting up a working group to work out and cost a national rainforest preservation policy which will go to Cabinet for approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated under sessional order for the consideration of General Business has expired. Senator Mason's Bill, having been interrupted by sessional order will, under standing order 75, remain on the Notice Paper. As is the custom adopted recently in the Senate, it will remain in its present position on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL (No. 1) 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: TORRES STRAIT TREATY (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984TORRES STRAIT FISHERIES BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 39, page 26, lines 15 and 16, omit ', where it considers it appropriate to do so,'.
Clause 39 provides for a Protected Zone Joint Authority, which is referred to in the second reading speech. The clause reads:

The Protected Zone Joint Authority shall, where it considers it appropriate to do so, seek the views of members of the Joint Advisory Council established under Article 19 of the Torres Strait Treaty who are traditional inhabitants and Australian citizens on any matter relating to a Protected Zone Joint Authority fishery where the matter may affect the interests of traditional inhabitants who are Australian citizens.

I have already referred to the complexity of the legislation, the way in which the Protected Zone Joint Authority will work and the complications there are with the operation of the protected zone and so on. It seems clear that the legislation will work only with the utmost co-operation of all the parties involved. Unfortunately, because of the way clause 39 is drafted, the Torres Strait Island members of the Joint Advisory Council will not be involved to the extent which we in the Opposition believe would be desirable. The amendment would leave out after the words 'The Protected Zone Joint Authority shall', these words 'where it considers it appropriate to do so'. The result would be that it would be mandatory for the Protected Zone Joint Authority to seek the views of the Joint Advisory Council on all occasions where any matters arise which affect the interests of the traditional Australian inhabitants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment, for reasons which were stated with compelling effect by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr West, in the House of Representatives, which reasons I now repeat:

SPEECH.PARA: The text of the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill was arrived at after extensive negotiations with Queensland. Clause 39 was drafted in its present form on the understanding that the Joint Advisory Council would be consulted only on broad policy issues affecting the traditional inhabitants and on important matters which could not be easily resolved by other consultative processes. It was never intended that the three Islander members of the Joint Advisory Council be consulted on day to day fisheries management matters handled by the Protected Zone Joint Authority.

The amendment would oblige the Joint Authority to consult the three Islander members of the Joint Advisory Council about every matter which the Joint Authority was considering that was likely to affect the Australian traditional inhabitants. Given the role of the Joint Advisory Council, this would be clearly impractical. The Joint Authority has power under clause 40 (7) to establish advisory groups, the membership of which may include Islander and commercial fishing industry representatives. It is envisaged that this will be the principal mechanism through which Islanders will be able to express their views to the Joint Authority on detailed fisheries management issues.

Commonwealth and Queensland officials are already consulting with members of a consultative group formed by the Islanders themselves to discuss management of protected zone fisheries whether for traditional fishing or for commercial fishing. A similar consultative group exists for the commercial fishing industry . It is planned to continue and build on these consultative arrangements once the Joint Authority commences operating, to ensure that the interests of the Islanders and the commercial fishing industry are properly recognised and catered for. It is, therefore, necesary to leave clause 39 in its present form as it would be clearly inappropriate for the Protected Zone Joint Authority to consult the Joint Advisory Council on every matter under consideration by the Authority.
For those reasons I repeat, although we understand the thought that lies behind the amendment, we simply cannot accept it. It is quite unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I indicate that we will not be supporting this amendment. Unfortunately, we received notice of it only at the Committee stage. I believe the explanation that was given in the House of Representatives was indeed adequate. I cannot understand why the amendment was moved again in the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks concerning two of the criticisms which have been made of the legislation in the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The report was tabled yesterday. Because of the lack of copies I do not believe any honourable senator has received a copy. I realise there is a great shortage of time but I think it is important that, briefly, the matters which are commented on in that report ought to be drawn to the attention of the Committee. It relates to a number of clauses and to two particular items.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to move any amendments but to draw the attention of the Committee to these criticisms which have been raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. This is in connection with the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill. In the course of a Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest of 2 November 1983 we raised certain matters. We have had responses from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) since then that I think must be referred to in this chamber. With regard to clauses 12, 19, 20, 21, 22, 24, 25 and 26 the Committee had complained that there ought to be some form of review. These clauses all relate to a discretion in relation to the granting, endorsement, transfer, renewal or revocation of licences and of conditions which would apply to them. The Committee thought there should be some review of the merits. In fact the Attorney-General's Department has responded. I quote the relevant part of its response:
The Bill was introduced in its present form with the option of including review provisions at a later date, because of the difficulties outlined above--
It outlined the difficulties, as this is a treaty, in that Queensland has very strong views on this and there are difficulties arising from that. It continues:
and the need to have all the necessary legislation in place to enable ratification of the Torres Strait Treaty later this year.

It is the Commonwealth's intention that the Torres Strait legislation should in due course be brought into line with administrative review arrangements settled with the States for fisheries generally. However, from the Commonwealth viewpoint it is undesirable that the Torres Strait legislation-which affects relations with Papua New Guinea-should become the central issue in a disagreement that needs to be considered in the wider fisheries context.

The Committee acknowledged the response from the Department and sought to draw it to the attention of the Senate. I do that now in Committee. We regard it as inadequate that there are no such provisions for review in this Bill. It is interesting that the Government proposes to do something about that at a later stage. The second matter to which I wish to draw attention, and which is in the report which has been tabled but is not yet available to honourable senators, is one in relation to clause 57, a burden of proof clause. I will read the explanatory memorandum to give an idea of what the Government says this clause does. It states that it:
Confirms the persuasive onus borne by the Crown in cases where officers give evidence of their suspicions about certain matters of which only the defendant has knowledge.

The various matters in the Bill relate to whether the fish taken in a particular part of the zone were taken in that part for private purposes and whether the charge relates to fish taken in the course of traditional fishing. In relation to a person who gives evidence of an offence, that he suspects that those things have happened, the clause states:
. . . together with evidence of the grounds on which he so suspects; and
(b) the court considers that, having regard to the evidence, the suspicion is reasonable,
the fish shall, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, be deemed to have been taken in that area, for those purposes . . .
It is a deeming clause. One might say that it is in the form of an averment clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only evidentiary onus that is being placed, not a persuasive onus.
—That may be. What is said both in the explanatory memorandum and in the response from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is what the Attorney-General is saying now.
—I know. I rewrote the clause in Cabinet.
—Then I am sorry but we have to disagree with the Attorney- General and not just the Department.
—Are you going to fight about it?
—No, I do not propose to have a fight about it. I propose to draw the attention of the Committee to a different point of view.
—I have already had a fight about it with someone else.
—I am sorry that the Attorney-General won the fight.
—You should have seen the clause in its original form.
—I am glad I did not see it. It was probably too horrible to believe. In the statement which the Attorney has made in response to the criticism which our Committee made of this clause he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I would strongly support the statement in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill, that clause 57 (1) '. . . confirms the persuasive onus borne by the Crown'. It is erroneous for the Committee to suggest that the provision 'appears to require of the prosecution something less than proof beyond reasonable doubt'. This is so since, even if no 'evidence to the contrary' is presented by the defendant, the prosecution still has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the officer suspects on reasonable grounds the matters in clause 57 (1) (a) i, ii, or iii.
We dispute that and say that the Minister is in fact wrong. But then he stated:
On the other hand, if 'evidence to the contrary' is presented, then the prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt the existence of the matters in clause 57.
We agree with that part. But the Committee in its comment said:

The Committee while accepting the greater part of this opinion remains unconvinced that, in the absence of 'evidence to the contrary' presented by the defendant, the prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the officers suspicions were reasonable.

I draw attention to the clause which states that if no evidence is given, in the absence of the evidence it is deemed that some evidence is given by a prosecuting officer and then, if the court considers that is reasonable suspicion, it is deemed to be so. It is only if evidence is given that there is a need to prove it beyond reasonable doubt. I draw to the attention of the Committee the fact that a provision is being put in and, if one reads the burden of proof in criminal proceedings report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, to which the Government has not yet responded, one will see the great dislike of those clauses unless there is good cause for them. The fact is that in my view and in the Committee's view the explanatory memorandum and also the statement of the Attorney-General in respect of this clause are not accurate. It is like the curate's egg. Part of it is accurate and part of it is not. The attention of the Committee needs to be drawn to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief as I understand the Committee wishes to go on with other business. Senator Missen has given his own answer to the first problem. The Commonwealth wants to have Administrative Appeals Tribunal review proceedings, but the vagaries of the Federal system, which is so avidly supported by Senator Archer and others who are waving at me from the other side of the chamber make that impossible at this stage. However, I remind Senator Missen that the Ombudsman still has jurisdiction and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act still has an application. So the areas of decision making under this legislation are not wholly immune from administrative review.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the latter point that Senator Missen makes about clause 57 (1), I simply say that I beg to differ with him. I believe that the clause as presently drafted does confirm the persuasive onus as being borne by the Crown in proving beyond reasonable doubt the existence of any matters listed in the court which an inspector has reason to believe. The defendant under this clause has the burden only of presenting evidence to the contrary rather than proof to the contrary. This is a tricky and difficult technical area about which it is possible for reasonable men and women to differ, I readily acknowledge, and this is obviously something that we will have to go on debating. Incidentally in that context I hope that the Government will be shortly in a position to table its response to the excellent report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on the onus of proof. But the matters to which Senator Missen draws attention have been taken into account and we have done our best to get them right to the extent that it was possible to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly on this point, as Senator Missen said, the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was unavailable. This is regrettable because the last time we met there was much eulogy for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee reports and how useful they were for legislation. If honourable senators do not have them available when they are considering legislation in their party rooms, they are not able to make use of them at this stage of the legislation. Wherever the problem arose I hope that in future we will be able to solve it and make sure--
—A printing problem.
—Senator Missen assures me that it was only a printing problem and therefore one hopes that it may not occur again.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT TRUST FUND BILL 1984BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY BILL 1984BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 April, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill having made representations on behalf of a number of New South Wales refiners over the past 12 months. I briefly refer the Senate to the history behind the introduction of the Bills. In September 1970 the crude oil absorption scheme was introduced. This has had the effect over the past 14 years of creating a significant imbalance and inequity between southern refiners-that is, those companies refining in Victoria such as Shell Refining (Aust.) Pty Ltd, BP Australia Ltd, ESSO Australia Ltd and Mobil Oil Australia Ltd-and the northern refiners in Sydney and Brisbane, in particular Caltex Oil (Aust.) Pty Ltd, and Ampol Ltd. In Looking at how much the transportation costs are for those refiners, it is generally acknowledged that the average cost for Victorian refiners runs between 6c and 14c a barrel. It has to be understood, of course, that the reason that transportation costs are so cheap in Victoria is that those refiners had to bear the initial overhead costs of constructing and establishing a pipeline network. Nevertheless, Caltex, which of course runs the large Kurnell refinery in Sydney, claims that at present its transportation costs are approximately $1.15 per barrel to get the oil by ship from Bass Strait to Sydney. It estimates, therefore, that it is facing an annual competitive disadvantage of $22m. That is an enormous amount for any company to bear. It is something that its shareholders have had to bear. It has put pressure on margins such that over the last decade Caltex has lobbied successive governments. Prior to this day it has been unsuccessful.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem has worsened over recent years because shipping costs have risen so dramatically. Between 1975 and 1982 they rose from 35c per barrel to a dollar per barrel, which is an extraordinary increase in such a short period. The effect of the old system was that those refiners which had to use ships-that is, the refiners of Sydney and Brisbane-had a very serious disadvantage. The flat rate allowance system of the old absorption scheme had entrenched those inequities and, unfortunately, the New South Wales refiners in the main have had to bear that cost over such a long period.

The new levy of 20c per barrel on all crude oil produced from Bass Strait should go some way towards redressing that imbalance. It is a compromise; it is not what the northern refiners would say is perfect. Of course it means that the southern refiners will give up some of their advantage. Bearing in mind the equalisation scheme concerning costs to all capital city motorists for their petrol or oil, those northern refiners, although they may not say the measure is perfect, acknowledge that this compromise at least goes a large part of the way towards doing something decent for them.

We should examine for a second why there is a 20c levy now and not the 36c levy that existed prior to today. It should be noted that by adjusting the import parity price all refineries receive a reduction of 36c per barrel in the price of their oil, the same price as the rebate under the old system. In recognition of those costs to which I have been referring, the Government has reduced the rate from 36c to 20c. The Government's position reduces the inequities facing the northern refiners but it does not harm the sourthern refiners to any great extent. I note that there has been no real scream from southern refiners.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have lost too much blood.

—No, that is unfair. New South Wales is finally getting some equity out of the system. There are those who say that the federal system was designed to harm New South Wales in the first place and it has successfully worked to do so in some years.
—Never.

—Senators from Western Australia would always say that. Caltex, which has provided a number of honourable senators with material over the last few days, acknowledged in a document that I received yesterday that these Bills at least partially satisfy its demands. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: We commend the Bills as substantially correcting the inequity which had been institutionalised through past government regulation. It will now enable Caltex to be more cost-efficient and competitive in the market place and thus protect its employment and investment position in New South Wales.
If these Bills can achieve that they will have achieved something that the northern refiners, in particular Caltex, have been clamouring for for many years .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill. Indeed, we wish to see the Bills have a speedy passage. Both the Government and the affected industry would like to see the legislation in place. The Opposition takes the view that whilst this may not be a perfect solution to the problems which are dealt with by the legislation there is probably no perfect solution because in the case of the northern refiners it is true that they have substantial additional transport costs occasioned by the need to transport the oil from Bass Strait north, while in the case of the southern refiners it is fair to say that at least some of their facilities were put there because of the cost advantage which applied. They, therefore, invested their money on the basis of the existing system. To accept totally the argument of either the southern refiners or the northern refiners would result in an injustice to those whose argument was rejected. Essentially, the Government was faced with the need to find some sort of compromise. The Opposition does not necessarily endorse the precise allocation which has been made, but it accepts that there is some greater measure of justice in the arrangements which have been put into place by the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We are a little concerned at the fact that the legislation has been introduced at a time when the crude oil allocation system is under review. Of course, the matters that are dealt with by the legislation are very intimately connected with that system. We have put up with the inadequacies of the present system for about 15 years. Now it has been changed, perhaps half a year before the allocation system has to be dealt with. We see this as potentially short term legislation given the other changes which may come about. We note that nobody is totally happy with the proposed legislation. But the fact that nobody is totally unhappy is some indication that the Government has struck some sort of fair bargain.

A number of technical questions have been raised by the Opposition but in light of the sort of considerations which I have just outlined the Opposition does not believe that it should seek to amend the legislation. It has been queried why the payments to refineries should be on the basis of a notional rather than actual transport cost. I can see that there are good economic arguments why one might want to put it on the basis of notional costs. It has also been put to us that part of the 36c varies whereas the 20c is fixed and that is not very logical. Again, although one might want to pick that up if one thought that this legislation was gong to be in place for a very lengthy peiod, it does seem to the Opposition that is not necessary to deal with it given the uncertain situation about the future of the crude oil allocation system.

We are having this debate at a time when it is very easy for members of the Opposition and members of the Government to say: 'We have cut the baby in half and everybody has had some measure of justice'. But it is probably not much consolation to companies that are really suffering at the moment. Many of them have announced losses and are trading under very considerable difficulties. Over recent weeks we have had a series of such announcements. Caltex has indicated that it has lost $73.8m. There has been an indication that BP has lost just under $100m. Mobil has lost somewhere around $53m. So the spectre of large oil companies necessarily minting large amounts of profits is being laid to rest.

I do think that the Government needs to examine-we have raised this matter in the Senate before-some of the difficulties that are being imposed on the companies by government regulation at both the State and Federal level. The situation is that there is a petroleum pricing authority at the Federal level which is shortly to be replaced by another body. We have at the State level, under Labor State governments, a series of price control arrangements which do, I think, make the trading conditions of the industry extremely difficult. Although this is not a matter raised by this legislation. I raise it now simply to say to the Government again that the Opposition believes that the industry is being put in a quite unfair position. Although it is, in the short term, very satisfying politically to be able to point to the fact that a State government is holding down petrol prices below the level that the Commonwealth authority might permit, in the long term consumers must suffer if people are forced out of the business to the extent where there is really a lack of competition. At the moment, consumers do get a lot of benefit from price competition between the majors. In fact, oil companies cannot go on suffering the sorts of losses that have been made; something has to give and in the end that will affect consumers in a way which cannot be in their interests.

I simply use this legislation as an opportunity to raise this matter again with the Government and suggest that whilst it has State governments in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales which are of its same political colour, the Government might use its influence with those governments to suggest more rational and fairer arrangements for the companies. I commend the Bills and wish them a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak very briefly just to indicate the support of the Australian Democrats for the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill and also to support, in the main, the comments just made by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, but to disagree mildly with one aspect. I believe the legislation is appropriate even though a change is mooted for later this year to the whole formula and process of exporting to Australian bases. I believe that this legislation will have the effect of putting both the Government and all of the oil companies into a better negotiating position than would have been the case had these Bills not gone through. So I think it is timely that the Bills be introduced and passed by this Parliament at this time. The Democrats support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This problem has a very long and complex history. It is one which I understand on repeated occasions the industry has given indications that it would resolve itself but which it never seemed to be able to resolve. Therefore, the Government has taken some action, which we recognise is not beyond valid criticism, and indeed in these circumstances I do not think it is possible to devise any measure which is beyond valid criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make two comments in response to the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. I did consider the point that the allocation scheme is up for review at the end of this year and therefore it is possible that this legislation could have an effective life of only one year. But if we decided to defer this measure for that year and then found that the allocation system ultimately continued in similar form to that which it is now, the problem would still exist. For better or worse, we decided to act now.

The point that Senator Chaney made about price control and the losses suffered by Australian refiners and distributors is, I think, valid, but there is much more than price control involved. For example, I was in Surfers Paradise yesterday and noted that super petrol was selling at the bowser at less than 40c a litre. I do not think it is lower than that anywhere else in Australia, even though there are no price controls in Queensland. So there are a number of interacting factors in this industry, most of which I think can be substantially attributed to the fact that there is very substantial surplus refining capacity in Australia. I thank the Australian Democrats and the Opposition for their support. I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bills any further.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I would like to make some quick comments before someone takes a point of order on me. I just wish to make a brief response to the point made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh. I would accept what he said, that there are other factors in the matter that I raised and that competition for market share has certainly led to some heavy discounting. That does make some of the arguments of those who are concerned about the dual system of price control look a bit odd at first examination. I will quote just one paragraph from the annual report of the Chairman of Caltex Australia Ltd because I think it makes the point in a way which is quite appropriate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The State price controls have contributed signficantly to your Company's losses . Petrol discounting occurs in cycles and in different markets at different times. When prices are firming State Government controls constrain the upward movement and over time inhibit a gradual return to correct pricing in the industry.

The situation is, I suppose, that by putting a lower maximum price level it simply means that in the peaks and troughs business, the troughs remain low and the peaks are cut off, and so the overall trading conditions are affected in a way which does make it difficult for the companies. I accept the Minister's comment that there are other factors and factors such as the whole energy usage situation and the economic situation and so on all come into play. Price control is one of the problems but it happens to be one of those problems which are susceptible to government remedy; some of the others are not.
Bills agreed to.
